SubjectPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (18): cases
SARS - WORLDWIDE (18): CASES****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>In this update:[1] Worldwide - WHO[2] Hong Kong - DOH[3] Singapore - MOH[4] USA - CDC[5] Canada - Health Canada[6] Correction to names in SARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774*******[1]Date: 29 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: WHO SARS website [edited]<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_29/en/>From: 1 Nov 2002(1) To: 29 Mar 2003, 15:00 GMT+1Country:  Cumulative no. case(s)/  No. deaths/  Local chain(s) of transmission(2)Canada:   37/  3/  YesChina(3):   806/ 34/  YesChina, Hong Kong SAR:   470/  10*/  YesChina, Taiwan:   10/  0/  YesFrance:   1/  0/  NoneGermany:   4/  0/  NoneItaly:   2/  0/  NoneRepublic of Ireland:   2/  0/  NoneRomania:   3/  0/  NoneSingapore:   89/  2/  YesSwitzerland:   3/  0/  NoneThailand:   3/  1/  NoneUnited Kingdom:   3/  0/  NoneUnited States:   59 å¤/  0/  To be determinedViet Nam:   58/  4/  YesTotal:  1550/ 54Notes:Cumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.1. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002 to capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as being cases of SARS.2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which local chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided on the list of Affected Areas. [see [B] below]3. The reporting period from Guangdong Province is from 16 Nov 2002 to 28 Feb 2003.å¤ Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level, probable cases are reported by all countries except the USA, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.* One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR China occurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)  29 Mar 2003<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_29/en/>Country: AreaCanada: TorontoSingapore: SingaporeChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong SAR, Shanxi, Taiwan ProvinceViet Nam: HanoiAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS is/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.[C] Update 14 - Update on cases and countries 29 Mar 2003<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_03_29/en/>As of 29 Mar 2003, a cumulative total of 1550 cases and 54 deaths have been reported from 13 countries. This represents an increase of 65 cases and one death compared with the previous day.WHO infectious disease specialist, Dr Carlo Urbani, the first WHO officer to identify the outbreak of this new disease and treat the earliest cases in Hanoi, died of SARS today in Thailand, accounting for the additional death.The number of cases in Viet Nam remained at 58 for the sixth day in a row, indicating that the outbreak in Hanoi is well-controlled.The largest increases occurred in Hong Kong SAR China, with 45 new cases, and Canada, with 8 new cases. The United States of America reported 8 additional suspect or probable cases.[D] Dr. Carlo Urbani of the World Health Organisation dies of SARS  29 Mar 2003<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/urbani/en/>Dr. Carlo Urbani, an expert on communicable diseases, died today of SARS. Dr. Urbani, worked in public health programs in Cambodia, Laos and Viet Nam. He was based in Hanoi, Viet Nam. Dr. Urbani was 46.Dr. Urbani was the first WHO officer to identify the outbreak of this new disease, in an American businessman who had been admitted to a hospital in Hanoi. Because of his early detection of the disease, global surveillance was heightened and many new cases have been identified and isolated before they infected hospital staff. In Hanoi, the SARS outbreak appears to be coming under control.åÒCarlo was a wonderful human being and we are all devastated,åÓ said Pascale Brudon, the World Health Representative in Viet Nam. åÒHe was very much a doctor, his first goal was to help people. Carlo was the one who very quickly saw that this was something very strange. When people became very concerned in the hospital, he was there everyday, collecting samples, talking to the staff and strengthening infection control procedures.åÓDr. Urbani was married and the father of 3 children.Dr. Urbani received his medical degree from the University of Ancona, Italy, and did post-graduate work in malaria and medical parasitology. He was an expert in the parasitic diseases of schoolchildren. He was also a president of MÌ©decins Sans FrontiÌ¬res-Italy.åÒCarlo UrbaniåÕs death saddens us all deeply at WHO,åÓ said Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, WHOåÕs Director-General. åÒHis life reminds us again of our true work in public health. Today, we should all pause for a moment and remember the life of this outstanding physician.åÓ[We are very sorry to learn of Dr. Urbani's death.  A very sobering occurrence. - Mod.MPP]-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: 29 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Hong Kong Department of Health 29 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>Figures on atypical pneumonia------------------The following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the Hospital Authority:As at 1 PM 29 Mar 2003, a total of 470 people with pneumonia symptoms have been admitted to public hospitals. The 45 additional patients reported today include 3 healthcare workers and 22 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 23 were new patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.The DH has visited Amoy Gardens last night and performed screening of its residents to ensure their health. A medical surveillance post has been set up to address health concerns of the residents. Investigations including a detailed questionnaire study of the cases are being performed.As at today, 43 patients have been discharged from hospitals. A total of 53 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.An 85-year-old male patient with history of cardiac disease died in Prince of Wales Hospital this morning, bringing to 12 the total number of patients died with atypical pneumonia.The breakdown of figures is as follows:Nature Total Admission (The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)Health care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 156 (156)     24 of the patients were dischargedPatients, family members & visitors 314 (314)     19 of the patients were dischargedTotal admission 470 (470)     43 were discharged-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[3]Date: 29 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Singapore Ministry of Health 29 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5720>SARS - Situation UpdateAs of 29 Mar 2003, a total of 89 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of Health. The 3 additional patients, who are family members of SARS cases, are still traced back to the initial 3 index cases. This brings the total number of family members, friends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of hospital staff infected by SARS to 41. These 85 cases are all linked to the first 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3.To date, 28 patients have been discharged from hospital, 2 have died and the remaining 59 patients are hospitalised. All the patients are stable except for 13 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth index case.The fourth imported case reported yesterday is a 29 year old Chinese female who travelled to Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar 2003. While in Beijing, she became ill on 19 Mar 2003. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ 355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 AM. Accompanied by her mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency Department, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by ambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.Of the 49 passengers on board CZ 355, 31 (including the case) have been traced. They are all well. Home Quarantine Orders are being issued. The 9 crew members of CZ355 returned to China on 26 Mar 2003. The Southern China Airlines has taken action to bar them from flights for 10 days. The names of the remaining 18 passengers who we have still been unable to locate [can be found on the website at: <http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5720> - Mod.MPP]  The Ministry urges these persons or anyone who knows their whereabouts and the identity of the taxi driver to call 91788389 with the information.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[4]Date: 29 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: CDC SARS website 29 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>[A] CDC Extends SARS Travel Advisory; Offers Interim Infection Control Guidance<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r030329.htm>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) today extended its travel advisory for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) to include all of mainland China as well as Hanoi, Vietnam and Singapore. The previous CDC travel advisory was for only Hong Kong and Guangdong Province, People's Republic of China and Hanoi, Vietnam.CDC advises that people planning elective or non-essential travel to mainland China and Hong Kong; Singapore; and Hanoi, Vietnam may wish to postpone their trips until further notice. CDC has been working closely with the World Health Organization (WHO) to investigate cases of SARS. At this time CDC is not advising against travel to or from Canada because there is not evidence of widespread community transmission.CDC officials are meeting planes, cargo ships and cruise ships coming either directly or indirectly to the United States from China, Singapore and Vietnam and distributing health alert cards (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/travel_alert.htm>) to disembarking passengers.  In addition officials are assessing passengers returning from those areas for symptoms of SARS.CDC is also issuing guidance for patients with suspected SARS designed to prevent transmission of the illness to their family members and other close contacts. Health care officials are not certain how long a patient with SARS may be contagious to people with whom they have close contact.CDC recommends the following infection control measures for suspected patients with SARS in household or other residential settings:Infection control precautions should be continued for SARS patients for 10 days after respiratory symptoms and fever are gone. SARS patients should limit interactions outside the home and should not go to work, school, out-of-home day care, or other public areas during the 10 day period;During this 10 day period, all members of the household with a SARS patient should carefully follow recommendations for hand hygiene, such as frequent hand washing or the use of alcohol-based rubs;Each patient with SARS should cover his or her mouth and nose with a tissue before sneezing or coughing. If possible, a person recovering from SARS should wear a surgical mask during close contact with uninfected persons. If the patient is unable to wear a surgical mask, other persons in the home should wear masks when in close contact with the patient;Disposable gloves should be considered for any contact with body fluids from a SARS patient. However, immediately after activities involving contact with body fluids, gloves should be removed and discarded and hands should be washed. Gloves should not be reused, and are not intended to replace proper hand hygiene.SARS patients should avoid sharing eating utensils, towels and bedding with other members of the household, although these items can be used by others after routine cleaning such as washing or laundering with soap and hot water;Other members of the household need not restrict their outside activities unless they develop symptoms of SARS such as a fever or respiratory illness.[B] Excerpts from Update Telebriefing  Conference 29 Mar 2003<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/t030329.htm>We continue to regard the new coronavirus as the leading hypothesis for the etiology of this condition. The evidence is mounting from a number of international laboratories, that this is indeed the case; but we are also exploring other potential viruses as are our collaborators.  A number of things are in progress, including sequencing of the whole virus genome.We recognize that the disease is still primarily limited to travelers, to health care personnel who have taken care of SARS patients, and to close contact with SARS patients.  The affected travelers are those who have been in Hong Kong, in Hanoi, in Singapore, and in mainland China, for the most part.We believe, based on the investigations so far, that the major mode of transmission is through droplet spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes and droplets are spread to a nearby contact. But we are concerned about the possibility of airborne transmission across broader areas and also the possibility that objects that become contaminated in the environment could serve as modes of spread.  Coronaviruses can survive in the environment for up to 2 or 3 hours ,and so it's possible that a contaminated object could serve as a vehicle for transfer to someone else.For the people who are living in the household with the SARS patients, and who are otherwise well, there is no reason to limit activities at this point in time. The experience in the United States has not demonstrated spread of SARS from household contacts into the community and so we are not advising any restrictions on the activity of contacts at this point in time.  However, it's very important that contacts with SARS patients be alert to the earliest symptom of a respiratory illness. If they have any symptoms suggestive of an impending illness, they should contact a medical provider, alert them that they are a SARS contact, so that the health care system can advise them where to come and get evaluation, and prepare the delivery system to implement the appropriate infection control precautions so that others are not exposed in the health care setting.We also are updating our guidance to travelers. The travelers at risk for SARS are those who have been in mainland China, in Hong Kong, in Hanoi and in Singapore.  These travel alerts do not include passengers coming in from Canada. The epidemiology of the SARS in Canada is very different and there is not a risk from incoming travelers at this point in time.  WHO is not issuing any travel restrictions. We are not issuing any travel restrictions either, but WHO has also implemented procedures for screening passengers before they leave the country of SARS origin.Of the 62 cases under investigation [in the USA], 2 of those cases are in health care workers and there have been no further signs of spread in that particular cluster. 5 cases have been in household contact and the rest of the cases have all been in travelers coming in from SARS areas.  We are not experiencing any sign of community transmission at this point in time.In response to a question related to Hong Kong health officials reporting suspect cases from an apartment complex:  Information from Hong Kong does suggest that in at least one apartment complex there has been spread. [It hasn't been identified as yet] to what extent the individuals in that apartment have had face to face contact with each other, to what extent they might have contacted contaminated environments in that facility or to what extent airborne transmission could play a role.In response to a question on other modes of transmission and guidance for airlines: Preliminary guidance on appropriate means for disinfection of commercial aircraft as well as very specific and more focused guidance for disinfection of an aircraft that might be used in a medical evacuation of a high-risk or critically-ill patient [have been issued].In response to a question re: treatment guidelines: [There is] no evidence right now, that any specific anti-viral therapy, or steroid treatment, or other agents that are targeting this virus, are of any benefit to patients.In response to questions re: concern about community spread in the USA:  We recognize that there are at least some patients with SARS that are extremely efficient transmitters. For example, in Hanoi where there was one patient who was a source for health care worker transmission and approximately 56 percent of the health care [workers] who had direct contact with the patient appeared to have acquired SARS.In response to a question on evidence of coronavirus as the etiology: First, we have isolated the coronavirus from 2 patients, here, in the USA and elsewhere additional isolations are reported. We are using PCR or polymerase chain reaction technology to identify very specific pieces of the coronavirus in the secretions and fluids from many of the case patients. We have developed an antibody assay which detects antibodies to this new coronavirus with a high degree of specificity, some of the patients who have negative antibody tests at the beginning of their illness, subsequently, in paired serum have demonstrated development of antibody within days after their infection occurred. They are developing an immunologic reaction to this new coronavirus, strong evidence of infection.We now have 2 antibody tests that look quite promising and seem to be reproducible in different laboratories, and we're working to transfer diagnostic testing capacity to public health laboratories around the country, so that before too long, tests will be available much more locally.Laboratories in at least 7 other countries now have evidence for coronavirus.In response to a question on the period of infectivity of cases: One of the important studies going on is to look at passengers who traveled in airplanes with SARS patients, we have 3 separate cohorts of passengers who traveled on the same plane with someone we knew was incubating SARS or had SARS during their travel experience. So far, those studies have not identified evidence of transmission before people become sick but the numbers are small and we can't draw any conclusions at this point in time.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[5]Date: 29 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Health Canada - SARS website 29 Mar 2003 [edited]Update 14 - SARS  29 Mar 2003 5:00 PMAs of 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 37 cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario, British Columbia and Manitoba. There have been 3 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.The details of the cases to date are as follows:Ontario: 35 total cases. All cases have occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting.British Columbia: one person has been hospitalized with SARS after returning from travel in southeast Asia.Manitoba: one person has been hospitalized with SARS after returning from travel in southeast Asia.Due to the mounting concern about transmission of the SARS agent in non-hospital and community settings in the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; the People's Republic of China including the Hong Kong SAR; and Singapore, Health Canada recommends that persons planning to travel to these areas should defer all travel until further notice. Health Canada also recommends alternate routing be considered, when possible, if a traveller is transiting through the People's Republic of China including the Hong Kong SAR; City of Hanoi, Vietnam; or Singapore. Health Canada is aware that health authorities in these affected areas are making concerted efforts to contain the spread of SARS in their populations. Given the uncertainties of the current situation, Health Canada believes it is prudent to await the outcome of national and international control measures before undertaking travel to these destinations.On 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada deployed 2 additional staff to assist Toronto Public Health and the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation of SARS cases. This now brings the total number of Health Canada staff assisting in Ontario to 7. The department has also provided guidelines for infection control and recommendations on actions for public health settings.On 27 Mar 2003, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended new measures, related to international travel aimed at reducing the risk of further international spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The measures proposed by WHO on the screening of passengers presenting for international travel are under active consideration by Health Canada.  Health Canada has discussed this issue with the local airport authority in Toronto and we are putting together a plan. Health Canada is hoping to have something in place in Toronto over the course of the weekend.It is important to note that airlines operating international flights in and out of Canada have been carrying out long-standing procedures to prevent sick passengers from getting on airplanes.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[6]Date: Sat 29 Mar 2003From: Eugene Yeung <eugene@technoworks.net>Correction: The Department of Microbiology, Hong Kong University----------------------------------------------------------------I just wish to inform you of another correction: The virologist at Hong Kong University (HKU)is Prof. Malik Peiris (not "Professor Mark Peiris" as stated incorrectly by the Moderator in the ProMED-mail post entitled SARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774). And Prof. K. Y. Yuen is the Head of the Department of Microbiology of University of Hong Kong.-- Eugene YeungGovernment Virus Unit, HKSAR<eugene@technoworks.net>[ProMED-mail regrets this error in transcription and welcomes the  opportunity to set the record straight. - Mod.CP][Today's reports represent an increase in 65 cases and one death since yesterday's report, of which there are 45 new cases reported in Hong Kong.  Due to a time zone difference, the WHO statistics for the USA represent the number of cases reported yesterday (28 Mar 2003), whereas in the CDC update presented in [4] there is an increase in 3 cases in the USA.  With the exception of Hong Kong and mainland China, it still appears as though transmission is via close contact with active cases of SARS either in the health care setting or household contacts.  Information on the epidemiology of the cases in mainland China is still pending, and in Hong Kong there appears to be transmission in a housing complex, but the degree of contact between the cases is still under study.[see also:SARS - SubjectPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (19): etiology
SARS - WORLDWIDE (19): ETIOLOGY*******************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sun 30 Mar 2003From: "Christian Drosten" <drosten@bni-hamburg.de>Primers and Protocols for SARS-associated Coronavirus Identification--------------------------------------------------------------------[Dr. Christian Drosten is making the following information available in response to many requests from laboratories dealing with suspected or probable cases of SARS which do not feel at present sufficiently informed and involved.- Mod CP]Following our last posting in ProMED-mail [SARS - WORLDWIDE (16): ETIOLOGY 20030328.0774], we have received many requests to communicate our PCR primers and protocols for the detection of the coronavirus suspected to be linked to SARS. We are pleased to accede to this request on the understanding that ProMed-mail recipients are aware that:(1) The virus detected by this PCR is only suspected/has not been confirmed yet to be an etiological cause of SARS;(2) a negative finding in this PCR is not sufficient to exclude SARS;(3) healthy controls have to be tested before the test is used; and(4) the primers have not been published.The protocol is a preliminary one that is not yet thoroughly optimized. It yields clear positivity in respiratory specimens of both Frankfurt cases of SARS. The primers used are specifically targeting a fraction of the polymerase gene of the coronavirus found in these patients (refer to above mentioned posting for further details).The protocol is available on the Homepage of the Bernhard-Nocht-Institute, <http://www15.bni-hamburg.de/bni/bni2/neu2/getfile.acgi?area_engl=news&pid=620> .The primers are available from stock at Tib-Molbiol, a German biotech company based in Berlin. Aliquots of these primer stocks have been tested in our laboratory to rule out mis-synthesis. Contact and order via <ulass@tib-molbiol.de> or <dna@tib-molbiol.de>. We do not have personal orfinancial relations to this company.Those who are willing to establish this test can request from me (e-mail below) in-vitro transcribed positive control RNA that will be available from the middle of this week.--Christian DrostenVirology/Molecular DiagnosticsBernhard-Nocht Inst. of Tropical MedicineBernhard-Nocht Str. 7420359 HamburgGermanyPhone 0049-40-42818-421Fax 0049-40-42818-378<drosten@bni-hamburg.de.[ProMED-mail is pleased to assist in the rapid dissemination of this important information. ProMED-mail has no commercial association with the company supplying the coronavirus PCR primers - Mod.CP][see also:SARS - worldwide (18): cases  20030329.0783SARS - worldwide (17): cases  20030328.0779SARS - SubjectPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (20): cases
SARS - WORLDWIDE (20): CASES*******************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>In this update:[1] Hong Kong - DOH[2] Singapore - MOH[3] Canada - Health Canada******[1]Date: 30 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Hong Kong - Department of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>[A] Update on atypical pneumonia 30 Mar 2003The following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the Hospital Authority:An additional 60 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia were admitted to public hospitals as of 1 PM 30 Mar 2003. They include 6 healthcare workers and 36 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 18 were new patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.17 patients, including 12 healthcare workers and medical students of Prince of Wales Hospital, were discharged from hospital today. A total of 60 patients to date have recovered from atypical pneumonia and been discharged.Currently, 52 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.A 74-year-old female patient with a history of other diseases died in United Christian Hospital this morning. This brings to 13 the total number of patients died with atypical pneumonia in public hospitals.The cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals with atypical pneumonia is 530, starting from 12 Mar 2003.The breakdown of figures is as follows:   (The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)Health care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 162 (162)     36 of the patients were dischargedPatients, family members & visitors 368 (368)     24 of the patients were dischargedTotal admission 530 (530)     60 were discharged[B] Flight passengers urged to contact DH 30 Mar 2003The Department of Health (DH) on 30 Mar 2003 called on passengers who had travelled from Beijing to Hong Kong on flight KA 901(Dragonair) on 26 Mar 2003 to call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice on atypical pneumonia and surveillance. The hotline will be manned from noon to 5 PM 30 Mar 2003 and from 9 AM to 5 PM on weekdays.The plea was made as DH's investigation found that a Hong Kong man who had taken the flight developed symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome during his stay in Beijing. He was later confirmed to have contracted the disease.  DH has informed the Airport Authority and the airline. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplanes.  DH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 2 flights, for surveillance purposes.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: 30 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Singapore Ministry of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740>SARS: New measures at airport to curb importation of new cases; more patients recovering and discharged - 30 Mar 2003In yesterday's Press Release, MOH had informed that the fourth imported case left for Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar 2003. On 19 Mar 2003, she became unwell. Between 19-23 Mar 2003, she met and worked with 2 Singaporean colleagues, who have since returned to Singapore and are well. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ 355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 am. Accompanied by her mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency Department, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by ambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.Her mother and 2 colleagues have been issued with Home Quarantine Orders. Others who were served the Orders were 3 SATS officers, 2 SIR officers and 2 relations officers from the airline. We have identified a taxi-driver who said that he had ferried 2 women from Changi Airport to the Accident & Emergency Department, Singapore General Hospital on the morning of 26 Mar 2003. As a precautionary measure, a Home Quarantine Order has been issued to him.Following yesterday's press statement, we have been able to locate 10 more passengers. They are all well and quarantine orders are being served to them. In total, 40 of the 48 passengers (excluding the case) have been identified. There is a possibility that some of the remaining 8 passengers are no longer in Singapore. The names of the remaining 8 passengers who we have still been unable to locate are [see <http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740> for list of names.]The latest (fifth) imported case is a 17-year-old Indonesian male student who left Singapore on 15 Mar 2003 with his parents and his 15-year-old brother for Guangdong and Hong Kong. The family returned to Singapore on the night of 23 Mar 2003. On 24 Mar 2003, he was well and attended school at Bowen Secondary School. On 25 Mar 2003, he developed a fever and was seen at TTSH as an outpatient. He was given 5 days medical leave. He was seen again on 27 Mar 2003 and admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case. He stayed at home all this while. He was upgraded as a SARS case on 29 Mar 2003. His mother is also admitted to TTSH as a suspect case. His father and brother are well.Additional precautionary measures at Changi Airport to minimize the import of SARSTo minimize the import of SARS cases, Singapore is stepping up health screening procedures for passengers arriving at Changi Airport from affected countries. This is in view of new index cases that are traced to people who have traveled overseas.Additional Precautionary Measures For Incoming Passengers From 5 PM 31 Mar 2003 onwards, for all incoming flights from affected areas as identified by WHO, nurses will be present to check on passengers who appear unwell. Those who have fever, will be sent to TTSH for assessment.Additionally, CAAS has today issued a directive that takes immediate effect to all airlines operating at Changi Airport requiring them to ask passengers the 3 questions recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO) before allowing them to board the flight to Singapore. The 3 questions are :1. Do you have high fever of more than 38 degrees Celsius?2. Do you have one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing?3. Have you had close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with SARS or had recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS?Any visibly unwell passenger will be asked to obtain a doctor's certification before they are allowed to board the flight to Singapore.The above measures are on top of the health advisory cards distributed to all passengers coming from Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Guangdong.  MOH and CAAS will scale up the operations and implement the above measures to other affected countries as and when WHO updates the list.Additional Precautionary Measures For Outgoing PassengersCAAS has issued a directive to airlines in Changi Airport requiring all airlines to ask departing passengers the 3 questions recommended by the WHO. This directive takes effect immediately.  This is in addition to the health advisory cards which are distributed to passengers bound for Hong Kong, Hanoi and Guangdong when checking in for their flights.SARS Situation UpdateAs at 30 Mar 2003, the total number of people who have recovered from SARS and are discharged from hospital is 35. The remaining 53 patients are hospitalised.A total of 91 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of Health. Of the 2 additional patients, one is a healthcare worker who is still traced back to the initial 3 index cases, and the other is the new (fifth) imported case.So far, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and fifth imported cases. This brings the total number of family members, friends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of hospital staff infected by SARS to 42. These 86 cases are all linked to the first 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3. There are currently 36 suspected cases, 2 out of which are children.There are 12 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth imported case. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 29 Mar 2003. This patient had concurrent history of hypertension, diabetes, heart disease and a bacterial pneumonia.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[3]Date: 30 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Health Canada [edited]<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update15.htm>As of 30 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 98 probable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta and New Brunswick. There have been 4 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.Health Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect cases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country."Probable" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have a more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty breathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.A "suspect" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2 categories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, within 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases are being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a "probable" case of SARS (i.e., within one metre).The details of the cases to date are as follows:Ontario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. All cases have occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting.British Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 8 suspect cases.New Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.Saskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.Alberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.Manitoba is no longer reporting any suspect or probable cases.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Today's reports reflect an increase in 60 cases in Hong Kong, and 2 additional cases in Singapore.  The number of cases reported in Canada has increased from 37 to 98, but the latter figure is a combination of suspected and probable cases, whereas the 37 referred to only probable cases.  Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of the time of preparation of this update.With the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in mainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following a pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively ill case of SARS for transmission to occur.  One can't help but muse on the definition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas with high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in other areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with higher population density.  This moderator is reminded of studies conducted on the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early 80s.  It was generally accepted that polio was more of an "urban disease" with higher incidences observed in urban areas.  Results of studies on the baseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the rural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence.  Our interpretation of this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs. rural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly lower population density than urban areas.  In the highly populated districts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many western urban areas.  Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was more of a high population density disease.  Again, food for thought here... - Mod.MPP][see also:SARS - worldwide (19): etiology  20030330.0786SARS - worldwide (18): cases 20030329.0783SARS - worldwide (17): cases 20030328.0779SARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774SARS - SARS - WORLDWIDE (21): CASES**********************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[Due to length constraints, we have decided to split the daily updates soas to have shorter postings for the sake of those servers that rejectlarger postings.  As there are time zone differences in reporting areas, wehave chosen to post today's first update on worldwide cases to include theglobal report from WHO in Geneva and the country reports from Hong Kong,SAR, and Singapore, as it is now past COB (close of business) in thoselocations.  We are also including a few newswire briefs ofinterest/import. - Mod.MPP]In this update:[1] Worldwide - WHO[2] Hong Kong - DOH[3] Singapore - MOH[4] Newsbriefs     [A] Canada     [B] Belgium******[1]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source:  WHO SARS website 31 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases of Severe Acute RespiratorySyndrome (SARS)<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_31/en/>From: 1 Nov 2002(1) To: 31 Mar 2003, 17:00 GMT+2Country:  Cumulative no. case(s)/  No. deaths  Local chain(s) oftransmission(2)Canada:   44/  4/  YesChina(3):   806/ 34/  YesChina, Hong Kong SAR:    530/  13*/  YesChina, Taiwan:   10/  0/  YesFrance:   1/  0/  NoneGermany:   5/  0/  NoneItaly:   2/  0/  NoneRepublic of Ireland:   2/  0/  NoneRomania:   3/  0/  NoneSingapore:   91/  2/  YesSwitzerland:   3/  0/  NoneThailand:   5/  1/  NoneUnited Kingdom:   3/  0/  NoneUnited States:   59 å¤/  0/  To be determinedViet Nam:   58/  4/  YesTotal:  1622/ 58Notes:Cumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.1. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002to capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized asbeing cases of SARS.2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in whichlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are providedon the list of Affected Areas.3. The reporting period from Guangdong Province is from 16 Nov 2002 to 28Feb 2003.å¤ Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a nationallevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the UnitedStates of America, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.* One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of Chinaoccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.[B] CanadaAffected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 31 Mar 2003<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_31/en/>Country: AreaCanada: TorontoSingapore: SingaporeChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region ofChina, Shanxi, Taiwan ProvinceViet Nam: HanoiAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARSis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.[C] Hong KongSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) - multi-country outbreak -Update 15: 31 Mar 2003http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_31/en/The Hong Kong Department of Health has today issued an unprecedentedisolation order to prevent the further spread of Severe Acute RespiratorySyndrome (SADS). The isolation order requires residents of Block E of AmoyGarden to remain in their flats until midnight on 9 Apr 2003.The decision to issue the isolation order was made following a continuedsteep rise in the number of SARS cases detected in the building over thepast few days. Concern about a possible outbreak in Amoy Garden mounted onSaturday [29 Mar 2003], when 22 of Hong Kong's 45 new SAR caseshospitalized that day were determined to be residents of the estate. OnSunday [30 Mar 2003], 36 of the 60 new patients admitted to hospital withprobable SARS were Amoy Garden residents.Hong Kong health authorities today informed the public that a cumulativetotal of 213 residents of Amoy Garden had been admitted to hospital withsuspected SARS since reporting on the disease began. Hong Kong's outbreakbegan on 12 Mar 2003 when health officials first recognized a cluster ofcases of atypical pneumonia in the Prince of Wales Hospital.Of the 213 Amoy residents affected in the outbreak, 107 patients resided inBlock E. In addition, most of these 107 patients from Block E lived in flatsthat were vertically arranged. This suggests that SARS may be spreading inHong Kong according to a different pattern, still involving closeperson-to-person contact with bodily secretions from an infected person. WHOepidemiologists are considering the possibility that bodily secretionscontaining the causative virus might somehow enter common systems that linkrooms or flats together. This pattern of spread would be in addition to thewell-documentedface-to-face contact that has been seen in the majority of cases reported sofar.Earlier this month, Hong Kong epidemiologists detected an unusual patternof transmission among guests and visitors at the Metropole Hotel during thecritical period of 15 to 23 Feb 2003. Guests and visitors at a single floorof the hotel are thought to have spread SARS to Toronto and Singapore andto have started the outbreak in Hong Kong's Prince of Wales Hospital. Nostaff at the hotel developed symptoms.Amoy Garden is a large housing estate consisting of 10 blocks of 35-storeybuildings, where around 15 000 persons reside. It is located in KowloonDistrict. WHO has been informed that environmental samples have been takenfrom the affected flats in Block E and that investigations are under way todetermine a possible explanation for this apparent vertical spread of thedisease. Although the investigation is complex, results from testing of theenvironmental samples should be available within days and will helpdetermine the source of infection in Block E and the mechanisms by which thepathogen has spread.Hong Kong epidemiologists have identified a possible "index" case in theAmoy Garden outbreak. This is a patient, now hospitalized in Prince ofWales Hospital, who visited his brother, a resident of Block E, severaltimes before hospital admission.Mainland China---------------The WHO expert team spent the day in the Beijing Municipality Center forDisease Control and Prevention reviewing case records for all 10 casesreported in Beijing Municipality. Following the cases in Guangdong provincein late January [2003] and early February 2003, Beijing Municipality CDCofficials said an enhanced local surveillance system was established byadding 11 sentinel hospitals (out of 50 total hospitals) to report cases ofatypical pneumonia.The laboratory service was also geared up to receive specimens and carryout tests in secure conditions. Other preparation included stockpiling ofdrugs, setting up a public hotline, and holding 2 news conferences. Inaddition, CDC and hospital staff were trained in prompt reporting ofatypical pneumonia and infection control. An isolation unit wasestablished. CDC Beijing said that antibiotics and Ribovirin are being usedroutinely as treatment and prophylaxis.The team were told that contact tracing had begun as soon as the firstcases of atypical pneumonia had been recognized in Beijing and had beencarried out for all subsequent cases. 8 of the cases were imported (fromHong Kong and Taiyuan city, Shanxi province) and 2 were health care workerswho became infected trying to revive a 72-year-old man believed to havebecome ill after visiting a relative with SARS in a Hong Kong hospital.Besides the 2 health care workers, no other cases have been infected inBeijing.Discussions concerning a visit by the expert team to Guangdong Province arecontinuing with the Ministry of Health.Update on cases and countries:--------------------------As of today, a cumulative total of 1622 cases, with 58 deaths, have beenreported from 13 countries. This represents an increase of 72 cases and 4deaths since the last figures were compiled on Saturday [29 Mar 2003].The greatest increase in cases occurred in Hong Kong SAR. The additionaldeaths were reported in Canada (1) and Hong Kong (3). Germany reported itsfifth case, and Switzerland its third.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Hong Kong Department of Health  31 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>The following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and theHospital Authority:As at 1 PM 31 Mar 2003, a total of 79 patients with symptoms of atypicalpneumonia have recovered and been discharged from public hospitals.Of them, 19 patients, including 9 healthcare workers, were discharged today.Meanwhile, an additional 80 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumoniawere admitted to public hospitals. They include 2 healthcare workers and 64patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 14 were new patients and contactsof patients with atypical pneumonia.Currently, 64 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.A 79-year-old male patient with a history of heart disease died in Princeof Wales Hospital yesterday afternoon. Another 62-year-old male patient,who was very ill when admitted to Queen Elizabeth Hospital, passed away. Sofar, a total of 15 patients died with atypical pneumonia in publichospitals.The cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals withatypical pneumonia is 610, starting from 12 Mar 2003.The breakdown of figures is as follows:(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)Health care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 164 (164)     45 of the patients were dischargedPatients, family members & visitors 446 (446)     34 of the patients were dischargedTotal admission 610 (610)     79 were dischargedDirector of Health issues isolation order 31 Mar 2003-----------------------------------------Director of Health, Dr Margaret Chan, has ordered Block E of Amoy Garden inNgau Tau Kok, Kowloon Bay, to be isolated for a period of 10 days startingfrom 6 AM  31 Mar 2003 to prevent the spread of Severe Acute RespiratorySyndrome (commonly known as atypical pneumonia), a Government spokesmansaid.The decision was taken because of the continued steep rise in the number ofcases of infection in the building in the past few days.The order, designed to protect the health of residents and the community asa whole, was issued under the authority granted under Section 24 of thePrevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases Regulations, Cap. 141.The order requires residents of Block E of Amoy Garden to remain in theirflats until midnight on 9 Apr 2003.During the isolation period, no one will be allowed to enter or leave thepremises without express permission in writing of a health officer.Medical personnel from the Department of Health will visit residents' homesto conduct health inspections for them. Residents will be provided 3 mealsa day free of charge. They will also receive help and advice to conductthorough cleansing and disinfection of their flats. Staff of the HomeAffairs Department will be briefing residents on the detailed arrangementsto take care of their daily needs."We do understand that the measures that we have now taken will causeresidents great inconvenience. But because of the very specialcircumstances that we now face, we have no choice but resort to thisexceptional measure and we sincerely ask for residents' forbearance,understanding and support in joining the community's fight against thisdisease." the spokesman said.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[3]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Singapore Ministry of Health 31 Mar 2003 [edited]<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5800>SARS:  Situation update 31 Mar 2003More patients recovering and discharged--------------------------------One death due to SARS has been reported today. The patient had travelled toSarawak with her family from 15 Mar 2003 to 18 Mar 2003 and had developedfever when she returned to Singapore on 18 Mar 2003.She presented at NUH Emergency Department on 24 Mar 2003 with features ofpneumonia. At that time, the medical staff were unable to obtain from therelatives a history of contact with a patient with SARS and she had alsonot travelled to an affected areas. She was too unwell to be transferred toTTSH. Nevertheless, in line with MOH guidelines, she was treated as apotentially infectious patient and was warded in an isolation room. NUHstaff took all the necessary infection control precautions after heradmission, and the patient was isolated throughout her admission. She wasalso not allowed any visitors. She was transferred to the ICU on 24 Mar2003, where she was received intensive treatment under isolation.On 30 Mar 2003, one of her relatives gave the history that the NUH patienthad visited a non-SARS patient in a ward in TTSH on 12 Mar 2003. A patientin this ward was later found to have SARS. As the NUH patient herself wasvery sick, it was not possible to ascertain who she had come into contactwith. Despite intensive treatment, her condition worsened and she passedaway today. As a precautionary measure, this patient is being considered asa case of SARS. Contact tracing is being carried out.Apart from this case, there were no new cases of SARS reported. As at 31Mar 2003, a total of 92 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministryof Health. The total number of people who have recovered from SARS and havebeen discharged from hospital is 41. The remaining 47 patients arehospitalised.To date, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth andfifth imported cases. The cases in Singapore are still traced to the first3 people who travelled to Hong Kong and contracted SARS. The number ofinfected children still remains at 3. There is no change in the number ofpersons on the suspect list.There are 13 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourthimported case.Case of death on board the cargo ship, Kota Hasil from Hong Kong---------------------------------------------------MOH was notified of a case of an Indonesian crewman who developed highfever on 23 Mar 2003 while on board a cargo ship sailing between Taiwan andHong Kong, and who passed away on 28 Mar 203 while the ship was enroute toSingapore. The ship arrived in Singapore on 29 Mar 2003 and was anchored ina quarantine area. 2 doctors from Singapore boarded the vessel and examinedthe crew members. Although the history of the illness was not completelytypical of SARS, the doctors took all the necessary infection controlprecautions. All crew members were assessed to be well but have not beenallowed to come ashore. The body has been taken to the Centre for ForensicMedicine. The ship is scheduled to depart Singapore tonight after it hascompleted its cargo operations.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[4]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Newswire briefs [edited][A] Canada - from Canada.com 31 Mar 2003<http://canada.com/national/story.asp?id=B33A6DDD-F9E1-45D9-AD56-873246C74FD5>There are 2 probable and 3 suspected cases of Severe Acute RespiratorySyndrome at Toronto's Hospital for Sick Children.  There are no details onhow the children may have come into contact with the virus. [details willmost likely be available on the Health Canada SARS website once theinvestigation is completed. - Mod.MPP][B] Belgium - from expatica.com 31 Mar 2003<http://www.expatica.com/belgium.asp?pad=88,89,&item_id=30102>A soldier is believed to be the first Belgian [case] of  SARS. Thesuspected victim is recently-returned soldier who was based in theVietnamese capital, Hanoi. The unidentified male is currently receivingtreatment at a Liege hospital.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Today's global update from WHO (see [1] above) mentions an additional 72cases and 4 deaths since the last global update issued on 29 Mar 2003.  Theupdate from the Hong Kong Department of Health mentions an additional 80cases reported since 30 Mar 2003.  The data for case reports from Hong Kongcontained in the WHO update are for cases reported as of 30 Mar 2003 and donot reflect the additional 80 cases reported in Hong Kong as of 31 Mar 2003.The report out of Hong Kong re: the association of cases with a verticalblock of apartments in Kowloon is noteworthy, though it is still very earlyin the investigation to draw conclusions re: transmission.  We will befollowing this closely and will report information as it becomesavailable.  The decision to implement a quarantine of the residents of thisbuilding may seem severe, but given the many unknowns about SARS, and theobservation that there may be a different form of transmission other than"close contact" here as seen elsewhere, it is hard to be critical of theHong Kong Department of Health at this juncture.  Elsewhere transmissionstill seems to be following a pattern consistent with a need for closecontact with SARS cases.Roger Feldman MD <Feldmanmail@aol.com> has raised excellent questions aboutmore detailed epidemiologic information on this outbreak, such asage-specific case fatality rates, secondary attack rates, more details onthe clinical course, etc.  We have tried to present a synopsis of dataavailable to us at ProMED-mail, and we too look forward to reportscontaining more detailed epidemiologic data on this outbreak that we couldshare with our readers.  It needs to be highlighted that currentinvestigations use case definitions that are based on clinical andepidemiological criteria.  Clinical criteria include a disease spectrumthat is shared by many other etiologies, especially at this time of year inthe northern hemisphere, and the current epidemiologic criteria includecontact with previously identified cases or presence in geographic areaswith identified local transmission.  More definitive details will beavailable once an etiologic agent is definitively identified and laboratorytesting becomes available to permit confirmation of true cases of what isnow being referred to as SARS. We've learned a lot about this new emerginginfectious disease in a very short amount of time, but much more will belearned as more data become available. - Mod.MPP][see also:SARS - worldwide (20): cases 20030330.0791SARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786SARS - worldwide (12): correction Shanxi not Shanghai 20030327.0756SARS - worldwide (09): clinical features 20030326.0748SARS - worldwide (08): China 20030326.0747SARS - worldwide: cases      20030323.0722Severe acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713Severe acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (16) 20030322.0711Severe acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660Severe acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide      20030315.0637Acute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario)      20030314.0631Acute respiratory syndrome - East Asia      20030314.0630Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (02) 20030313.0623Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam      20030312.0602Undiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI      20030311.0595Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.0500Pneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452Pneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI      20030210.0357]..........................mpp/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (22): cases
SARS - WORLDWIDE (22): CASES**********************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>In this update:[1] USA - CDC[2] Canada - Health Canada******[1]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: CDC SARS website<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome report of suspected cases underinvestigation in the United States<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm> [website accessed 7:15 PM EST]These data were reported to the World Health Organization on March 30, 2003.*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>State: Suspected cases under investigation*Alabama: 1California: 14Connecticut: 1Georgia: 1Hawaii: 3Illinois: 2Kansas: 1Maine: 2Massachusetts: 2Michigan: 2Missouri: 2Mississippi: 1Minnesota: 3New Hampshire: 1New Jersey: 2New Mexico: 1North Carolina: 2New York: 10Ohio: 1Pennsylvania: 3Rhode Island: 1Texas: 3Utah: 4Virginia: 3Washington: 1Wisconsin: 2Total suspected cases under investigation: 69--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: 31 Mar 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Health Canada 31 Mar 2003[A] Summary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases:  Canada andInternational accessed 31 Mar 2003 7 PM EST<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030330_e.html>CanadaLatest Case Counts-------------------Since yesterday, 8 additional probable cases and one death have beenreported in Canada. A total of 44 probable cases with SARS have beenreported in Ontario and British Columbia, including 4 deaths (Table 1). Thenumber of probable cases by symptom onset date and type of exposure is alsoshown (Figure 1). One individual previously classified as a probable casein Manitoba is no longer being considered for SARS since a specific etiologyhas been identified.Recent Ontario Epidemiologic Findings--------------------------------The Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care has reported a total of42 probable cases of SARS. Of these, most remain hospitalised for isolationpurposes while six are in intensive care. Using the information currentlyavailable, the average age of probable cases is 46.3 years (n=35, range 17to 82 years), with 24 known females and 17 known males. The majority ofthose with severe illness or deaths have occurred in elderly patients withunderlying illness.While it is difficult to accurately determine the incubation period of theetiologic agent, given the fact that many of the probable cases in Ontariomay have multiple exposures, the current estimated mean incubation periodis 4 days (estimated range 2 to 10 days).It is believed that 4 generations of transmission have occurred. The indexcase in Ontario was an individual who travelled to Hong Kong and stayed atthe Metropole Hotel, where a cluster of SARS cases has since been reported.Upon return to Canada, disease transmission occurred in 4 members of theimmediate and extended family. A physician who had close contact withmembers of this family was also diagnosed with SARS. Following this, caseswere reported in individuals in a hospital setting where some of the firstcases were treated. Most recently, SARS has been reported in a few of thehousehold contacts of these hospital-associated cases. An isolated case inOntario was reported in an individual who had travelled to Asia, but didnot stay in at the Metropole Hotel.Based on the most recent epidemiologic investigations, nearly all of theprobable cases of SARS that occurred in individuals outside of the initialfamily cluster have been linked to exposure to the first hospitalised caseof SARS, on 7 Mar 2003. It is believed that disease transmission occurredmainly as a result of person-to-person contact. The initialhospital-associated cases are believed to have contracted the illness as aresult of unprotected contact with the initial cases prior to therecognition of SARS. Subsequent transmission is thought to have occurredbetween households of these hospital-associated cases, and between otherhealthcare workers. To date, there has been no evidence of transmission inthe general community.Other Reports--------------A Canadian with SARS [not counted in the official Canadian case count], whois currently hospitalised in Hong Kong, stayed at the Metropole Hotel. Thefirst identified probable case of SARS in British Columbia also stayed atthis hotel. The second probable case reported by BC today did not stay atthe hotel but was exposed to a SARS case while in Hong Kong. Bothindividuals are currently in isolation and no community transmission hasoccurred in this province.Ontario has declared a provincial emergency and SARS is now a reportablediseases under Ontario's Health Protection and Promotion Act. The provincehas introduced a number of public measures in an effort to contain thespread of SARS. Key public health measures include extensive contacttracing of persons who may have come in contact with SARS cases, isolationof suspect and probable cases, and voluntary home quarantine forasymptomatic contacts. Isolation wards have been established at hospitalsand health care staff are required to observe full airborne and contactprecautions. Health care staff across the province are now alerted to SARSand have implemented infection control practices to protect themselves andtheir patients in an effort to prevent any further infection.Health Canada is supporting Ontario in its SARS response efforts byproviding epidemiologic and infection control expertise, as well asemergency supplies as needed. Health Canada in collaboration with theProvinces and Territories has implemented enhanced surveillance for thedetection of SARS cases, alerted laboratories and initiated speciallaboratory investigations in an effort to identify the cause of SARS. Inaddition, Health Canada is working quickly to implement a screeningprotocol for international travellers in response to the WHOrecommendations to prevent travel-related spread of SARS. Due to recentconcerns regarding the possibility of transmission of SARS aboard aircraft,Health Canada has also recommended follow-up of all passengers on flightswhere a suspect or probable SARS case is identified. For regular updates onpublic health actions taken by Health Canada, please see the most recentupdate at:<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/index.html>Table 1 Cumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada, March 30, 2003Province/Territory: No. CasesBritish Columbia: 2Ontario: 42TOTAL 44Figure 1: Number of probable cases of SARS in Canada by symptom onset dateand exposure type from: February 23 to 30 Mar 2003  (n=37, excluding 7 forwhom onset dates are missing)[see epidemic curve at:<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030330_e.html>]International-----------Since 1 Nov 2002, 1557 cases of SARS (1513 outside of Canada) have beenreported to the World Health Organization. The majority of cases arereported from Guangdong Province and Hong Kong SAR China, Singapore andHanoi, Vietnam with Hong Kong presently showing the greatest increase incases. Cases of SARS in other parts of the world have occurred in personsor close contacts of persons who have travelled to these destinations. Asof 30 Mar 2003, 51 deaths have been reported outside of Canada, themajority (34) of which were reported in Guangdong Province of China. Thetotal number of cases and deaths in Guangdong was only recently reported inthe WHO cumulative international total.As of 25 Mar 2003, a cluster of 13 persons with suspected or probable SARSare known to have stayed at the Metropole Hotel in Hong Kong. These casessubsequently became index cases in several countries, including Vietnam,Singapore, the United States, Ireland, and Canada (MMWR Vol 52, No. 12,March 28, 2003). The visitor from mainland China, a medical doctor fromGuangdong Province who became ill a week before staying at the hotel, isconsidered to be the original source of the infection. No further caseshave been linked to the hotel.The majority of cases have occurred in people who have had very closecontact with other cases including household contacts and health careworkers.[B] Update 16 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 31 Mar 2003 8:00 PM<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update16.htm>As of 31 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately129probable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) inOntario, British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Alberta and New Brunswick. Therehave been 4 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in personswho have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the householdor in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update isbased on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.Health Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspectcases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country."Probable" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they havea more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficultybreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.A "suspect" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following twocategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratorysymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,within 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS casesare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or morerespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficultybreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a "probable"case of SARS (i.e. within one metre).The details of the cases to date are as follows:-----------------------------------Ontario is reporting 51 probable and 58 suspect cases. All cases haveoccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARScases in the household or in a health-care setting.British Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 11 suspect cases.New Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.Saskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.Alberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.Here are the most recent developments:-------------------------Due to the mounting concern about transmission of the SARS agent innon-hospital and community settings in the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; thePeople's Republic of China including the Hong Kong SAR; Singapore; andTaiwan, Health Canada recommends that persons planning to travel to theseareas should defer all travel until further notice. Health Canada alsorecommends alternate routing be considered, when possible, if a travelleris transiting through the People's Republic of China including the HongKong Special Administrative; City of Hanoi, Vietnam; Singapore; or Taiwan.Health Canada is aware that health authorities in these affected areas aremaking concerted efforts to contain the spread of SARS in theirpopulations. Given the uncertainties of the current situation, HealthCanada believes it is prudent to await the outcome of national andinternational control measures before undertaking travel to thesedestinations.For further information on this travel advisory, please see:<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/tmp-pmv/2003/sars0329_e.html>Effective 1 Apr 2003, Health Canada will launch an initiative to inform alldeparting passengers from the Pearson International Airport about symptomsand contact with persons with SARS through the Health Alert Notice (cherrycards).For more information on this initiative, please see: "SARS Screening ofTravellers To and From Canada"<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11factsheet1.htm>On 31 Mar 2003, Health Canada sent 2 mobile x-ray machines and processorsto Toronto for 2 isolation units that are being set up in non-hospitalfacilities.On 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada deployed 2 additional staff to assist TorontoPublic Health and the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation ofSARS cases. This now brings the total number of Health Canada staffassisting in Ontario to 7. The department has also provided guidelines forinfection control and recommendations on actions for public health settings.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[Presenting updated data is becoming a challenge as the time zonedifferences are impacting when data are submitted to WHO vs when databecome available on the various websites.  Hence, the above update refersto 69 cases reported from the USA as of 30 Mar 2003, whereas today's WHOupdate (presented in SARS - worldwide (21):cases) gave the USA report of 59(which was the number of cases reported on 29 Mar 2003).To further add to the challenge, the 2 above reports on the Health Canadawebsite were presented.  In the first report, there is presentation of datarelated to 44 probable cases reported as of 30 Mar 2003.  In the secondpart of the report, there is information related to approximately 129suspected and probable cases, creating a challenge to compare one day withthe next... (albeit in the 30 Mar 2003 SARS - Worldwide (20):cases update,the Health Canada website discussed 98 cases of suspected and probablecases of SARS, representing an increase of approximately 31 cases).In the first part of the report [A], the data from 30 Mar 2003 firstavailable on the website several hours ago are shown.  In this presentation,data on probable cases (44) are presented, along with some preliminary basicepidemiology -- out of 35 cases (in Ontario), the average (?mean) age is45.3 years with a range of 17 to 82 years; 24 females and 17 males.  Thereis also a description of the 4 generations of transmission in Ontario, withthe index case being an individual who was on the 9th floor of the MetropoleHotel in Hong Kong and is related to the cluster there.  Interestingepidemiologic data, still supporting the observation that close contact hasbeen necessary for transmission thus far in Ontario.It would be interesting to see similar epidemiologic data on reported caseselsewhere. - Mod.MPP][see also:SARS - worldwide (21): cases 20030331.0796SARS - worldwide (20): cases 20030330.0791SARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786SARS - worldwide (12): correction Shanxi not Shanghai 20030327.0756SARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives 20030326.0752SARS - worldwide (09): clinical features 20030326.0748SARS - worldwide: cases 20030323.0722Severe acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713Severe acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (16) 20030322.0711Severe acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660Severe acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637Acute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631Acute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (02) 20030313.0623Acute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam 20030312.0602Undiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.0500Pneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452Pneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357].............................mpp/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Netherlands (17)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - NETHERLANDS (17)**********************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Wed, 2 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: De Volkskrant, 2 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/1049173349838.html>Veerman increases stamping-out------------------------------Minister Veerman has ordered the depopulation of almost all poultry farmswithin the Gelders Valley. Veerman has announced that from now on, allpoultry farms within a 3 km radius of infected farms will be depopulated;until now, the radius was 1 km. The number of farms to be cleared is morethan 750, most within the Gelders Valley.  The total number of poultry farmsin the Netherlands is 3000, including 100 million chickens.  9 millionchickens have already been culled, a number that will now increase by atleast 2 million.In the meantime, fowl-plague virus has been detected in dead wild birds(ducks and crows). Within a few days it should become clear whether thisvirus is identical to the one causing the outbreak.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Many species of wild birds -- particularly waterbirds and seabirds -- areknown to be susceptible to avian influenza (AI). In fact, AI viruses areprobably ubiquitous in wild waterbirds, though infections in these birdsare generally subclinical. The confirmation of the alleged infection incrows will be surprising; available information from the relevantlaboratories will be appreciated.The Dutch Ministry of Agriculture announced on 2 Apr 2003 that thetotal number of "definitely infected" farms has reached 153, of which 7maintain pet avians. 43 farms are "seriously suspected", of which 7maintain pet avians. The current situation is detailed in a letter of 1 Apr2003 from Minister Veerman to the Parliament, available on the ministry'sweb-site:<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03098.htm>It mentions the registration of some 900 pet-bird farms, whereAI-susceptible avians are to be culled as well. The minister refers also tosurveillance in dead wild birds, mentioning positive findings in blood testsof some (no details on species nor of the tests used), indicating thatidentification of the virus type involved is expected within a few days. -Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Netherlands: suspected      20030301.0503Avian influenza - Netherlands (02): suspected 20030301.0509Avian influenza - Netherlands (03) 20030302.0528Avian influenza - Netherlands (04) 20030304.0540Avian influenza - Netherlands (05): OIE 20030304.0545Avian influenza - Netherlands (06) 20030304.0546Avian influenza - Netherlands (07) 20030305.0549Avian influenza - Netherlands (08) 20030306.0552Avian influenza - Netherlands (09) 20030307.0563Avian influenza - Netherlands (10) 20030310.0583Avian influenza - Netherlands (11) 20030311.0593Avian influenza - Netherlands (12): OIE 20030316.0653Avian influenza - Netherlands (13): international ... 20030316.0661Avian influenza - Netherlands (14) 20030320.0695Avian influenza - Netherlands (15) 20030325.0738Avian influenza - Netherlands (16) 20030327.0761]...............arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed.
