Archive Number20030418.0950
Published Date18-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement
AVIAN INFLUENZA - NETHERLANDS (21): PIG INVOLVEMENT***************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Fri, 18 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Excerpts from Letter VVA03.1238GM of 15 Apr 2003 from the Minister of Agriculture to the Speaker of the Dutch Parliament [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03124.htm>1. In my letter of 19 Mar 2003 I indicated that antibodies against Low-Pathogenic Avian Influenza [LPAI] were detected in Dinteloord. This was based on 3 positive results; all other 1297 surveyed poultry farms were found negative. Subsequent to these results, additional investigations have been carried out by the CIDC-Lelystad [the Central Institute for Animal-Disease Control]. This involved samples collected in 2002 and kept frozen in the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Utrecht. Virus isolation trials have demonstrated that the relevant virus was a low-pathogenic variant, confirming the presence in the Netherlands at the end of 2002 of an H7 LPAI virus. According to the tracing that was carried out, it is very probable that the infection has spread to the Gelders Valley by various contacts. Presumably, the virus mutated to become a highly pathogenic variant and caused the outbreak on 28 Feb 2003.2. In my letter of 5 Mar 2003 [see ref 20030306.0552] I indicated that the AI virus was initially found to affect humans; this was reported to you at the same time by the Minister of Public Health, Welfare and Sports. In order to find out whether the current epidemic may have caused infections in other animal species, I have started an investigation concerning the presence of Avian Influenza among pigs in mixed farms within the defense zone of the Gelders Valley. The first results show that many pigs have produced antibodies against Avian Influenza H7N7, which is the virus responsible for the current outbreak in poultry.It is known that pigs may harbour multiple viruses, hence enhancing the possibility of  virus mutation ("mixing vessel" theory) and infection of humans. At present, upon the advice of the Food and Non-Food Authority (VWA) in the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sports (VWS), the risks to public health by infected pigs are under assessment. This investigation should find out whether, and to what extent, further infection occurs among pigs. Aside from the effect of such data upon public health, they may also have consequences regarding the poultry industry and the repopulation of affected farms.Pending this investigation I have announced today a stand-still of the transportation of pigs and pig-manure within the protection and buffer zones. This concerns both mixed farms as well as farms containing exclusively pigs. This stand-still is directly supported by the advice of the Outbreak Management Team Influenza (OMT), responding to the VWS, and of the CIDC in Lelystad. A summary of the said investigation is appended [see 2].******[2]Date: Fri 18 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Dutch ministry of Agriculture, nature management and fisheries, 15 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03124c.pdf>Advise of VWA regarding Avian Influenza in pigs-----------------------------------------------On 13 infected poultry farms that also maintain pigs, the pigs were randomly sampled to investigate the occurrence of AI infection. It was demonstrated by the H7N7 HAR-test that in 5 of the said farms, a large number of the pigs had antibodies against the influenza variant responsible for the current outbreak in poultry. This has been confirmed by the EU reference lab in Weybridge, UK.It is thus most probable that this AI-virus, in some cases, can move from poultry to pigs. Pigs are often asymptomatic carriers of the influenza virus. Pigs are susceptible to both avian as well as human influenza viruses. The literature [supports the possibility of] transmission of the influenza virus from pigs to humans: in several known cases, avian and human influenza types have been transformed to new types in pigs (re-assortment).Following consultations with other relevant authorities, the VWS forwarded the following questions to the OMT staff for early investigation:1. What is the extent of H7N7 influenza-virus spread in pigs - within and among farms?2. Is there a possibility that the H7N7-virus appears in pigs together with human influenza types?The following activities have already been undertaken:1. Follow-up of the seroconversion in the 5 positive pig farms, including H7N7 serology in all pigs, as well as pharyngeal swabs (PCR) sampled throughout the farm, one sample per pen, at least 60 samples per farm. Attention should be paid to clinical ILI (influenza-like illness) symptoms (conjunctivitis, etc.).2.Serological surveillance in preventively culled mixed (poultry and pigs) farms as well as exclusively-pigs farms, currently limited to the protection zone in the Gelders Valley.3. Serological monitoring of positive farms, to investigate the possibly presence of other virus types circulating within the pig population.Pending the results obtained, the WVA, in consultation with the other authorities, will propose to the OMT staff additional investigational activities, and will advise on further control steps.******[3]Date: Fri, 18 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Reuters, 17 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=scienceNews&storyID=2585543>Bird Flu Spreads in Europe, Human Health Concerns---------------------------------------A severe Dutch outbreak of bird flu is seen spreading across Europe, mildly infecting humans and prompting fears that a mutated version of the virus could spark a flu epidemic in people, authorities said on Thursday.The Dutch Agriculture Ministry, grappling to contain a month-long outbreak that has spilled into Belgium and is nearing the German border, said there was a danger that bird and human flu could mix in pigs and produce a mutation against which humans have no resistance."It is possible. Until now avian flu has not been able to be transmitted from one person to another -- if it does...it could cause a large number of infections," World Health Organisation spokesman Iain Simpson told Reuters.  "There have been a number of influenza pandemics over the centuries, and the last one was in the late 1960s, so there is a view that we're overdue another one, although that doesn't mean it's going to happen anytime soon," he added.While the WHO, the global human health agency, said it was possible that the disease could turn into a serious human epidemic, international food and animal health authorities dismissed the idea.Several farm workers in the Netherlands suffered from eye infections caused by bird flu. The new worry is that the disease could mutate and jump to humans after several pigs were found to have antibodies to the avian flu.Nerves are jangling in Germany, as bird flu approached to within 1.5 kilometers of the German border on Thursday. French, British, Portuguese, and Spanish authorities were less concerned, despite worries that migrating wild birds could spread the disease. The chief form of transmission, however, is consumption of infected materials or feces."The situation is extremely precarious," German Junior Agriculture Minister Alexander Mueller said in a statement on Thursday.In the Netherlands, 15 million out of more than 100 million birds have been slaughtered as authorities battle to suppress its spread.German authorities have announced new measures to combat the disease, with orders to farmers to report any reduction in poultry flocks' performance, bans on pigeon racing, and appeals to people not to take pet birds on Easter holidays to the Netherlands and Belgium."We are now waiting and hoping," said Stefen Sallen, spokesman for the farmers' association in North Rhine Westphalia, the state next to the closest Dutch case. "It would be a terrible blow for us if it comes into Germany.""The most common method of spread of this virus is [the oral/fecal route]. While it's true that migratory birds could spread the disease -- that is always with us -- what's happened in this instance is that the virus has mutated from [one that infects] wild birds into [one able to infect] domestic poultry," said a spokesman for Britain's Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA)."We're always aware of the risk of avian influenza from migratory birds.  However, the outbreak from Holland doesn't necessarily mean the risk is heightened -- it's always with us," he added. "The danger of infection is actually much [higher] through poor biosecurity," he said, adding that UK farmers had been issued advice on maintaining [stringent] disease prevention measures.But British pig specialist Dr Michael Meredith said the spread via migratory wild fowl was inevitable. "There is a risk here -- if the virus gets into the wild bird population it will be very difficult to control," he said. Meredith also raised the possibility of a new virus hybrid. "Pigs have been kind of a mixing vessel for the big pandemics over the years. They're susceptible to avian flu and human flu. When the 2 viruses get together they can form a hybrid virus, which has the malignancy of the avian virus," he said.International food and animal health authorities dismissed worries of the bird flu turning into a serious human disease.The Paris-based International Animal Health Organisation (OIE) said there was no clear evidence of any risk to consumers.  "There is no way this could turn into a human virus like SARS," Alex Schudel, head of OIE's scientific and technical department, told Reuters.Peter Roeder, animal health officer of the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), said tough controls were now in place to curb the spread of the disease, but he could not rule out the possibility that wild fowl, such as ducks, geese, and swans, could spread it."The indications are that the avian flu is still spreading and is not under control," Roeder said, ruling out any link between the avian flu and SARS."There is no link at all," he said. "They are caused by 2 different agents. SARS is very clearly a very different virus from the avian flu virus."[Byline: Sybille de la Hamaide in Paris, Michael Hogan in Hamburg, Martin Roberts in Lisbon, David Brough in Rome]--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The letter of the Dutch Minister of Agriculture (which is the 12th since 3 Mar 2003 - see <http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/>), as well as its appendix (item 2), provide important epidemiological data on the evolving outbreak. The data still expected from the relevant Dutch research institutes are essential for accurate risk assessment, which may in turn inform the difficult decisions about further control measures, particularly the fate of pigs in (clinically) unaffected farms. As my colleague, Moderator Martin Hugh-Jones, remarks, "Logically there is no reason why these pathogenic mutations should always take place in Southern China. A possibility is not a probability, but it may behoove us to be aware of the chance in the coming weeks."This HPAI outbreak is now seriously threatening further spread in Europe, where a second country -- Belgium -- most probably has on its hands the first confirmed outbreak. It seems to have become since 28 Feb 2003 an epidemiological event of exceptional magnitude. In the meantime, 218 farms have been found infected, and additional 22 are considered "seriously suspected." As of 17 Apr 2003, the number of culled birds reached 15.7 million. All public events which involve possible contacts among animals (including horses, ponies, donkeys, cows, sheep, goats, and pigs) such as exhibitions, fairs, markets, auctions etc. -- are banned. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Belgium: suspected      20030312.0610Avian influenza - Netherlands: suspected      20030301.0503Avian influenza - Netherlands (05): OIE 20030304.0545Avian influenza - Netherlands (07) 20030305.0549Avian influenza - Netherlands (08) 20030306.0552Avian influenza - Netherlands (09) 20030307.0563Avian influenza - Netherlands (13): international ... 20030316.0661Avian influenza - Netherlands (18) 20030405.0834Avian influenza - Netherlands (19) 20030408.0855Avian influenza - Netherlands (20): OIE 20030416.09292001----Influenza A virus, basis of human virulence      20010908.21571999----Influenza H3N2, pig to human? - China (Hong Kong)      19991020.18761998----Influenzaviruses, porcine intermediation      19980830.17391995----Flu killing birds - humans next?      19950210.0054.................mhj/arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030419.0959
Published Date19-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN - NETHERLANDS (09): FATAL CASE*****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Sat, 19 Apr 2003From: R.A.M. Fouchier <r.fouchier@erasmusmc.nl>H7N7 in The Netherlands; first fatal human case-----------------------------------------------A 57-year-old veterinarian who visited a poultry farm affected by HPAI H7N7 infection (in Teefelen) died on 17 Apr 2003, as the result of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and related complications in a hospital in 's Hertogenbosch [Den Bosch], The Netherlands.On 4 Apr 2003, the veterinarian suffered from a high fever and severe headache without additional symptoms. On 8 April, when he first visited his family doctor for persisting fever, no signs of respiratory disease were observed and consequently he did not receive medication. Because he reported to have worked as a poultry veterinarian and had visited a farm affected by HPAI H7N7 on 2 Apr 2003, a throat swab and an eye swab were collected on 9 April and sent to the National Influenza Centre (NIC) for influenza A virus (H7N7) diagnostics. RT-PCR tests performed in 2 laboratories were both negative. These tests are routinely performed in the framework of the surveillance of A/H7-associated-illness in poultry workers during this epizootic [see ref 20030316.0656].On 11 Apr 2003, the man was admitted to hospital because of suspected pulmonary involvement, where he was diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia. He was moved to the intensive care unit a day later with deteriorating condition and was put on mechanical ventilation. On 14 Apr 2003 his renal function decreased and dialysis was started. Further deterioration was observed on 15 April, thorax X-rays revealing bilateral interstitial pneumonia. He was treated with doxycycline and ofloxacin. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed for diagnostic purposes. He died on 17 Apr 2003.The BAL sample was sent to the NIC, where a high virus load of influenza A (H7) virus was found, using a real-time PCR assay specific for the matrix and haemagglutinin genes. Testing for other respiratory viruses and bacteria are so far negative. In throat swabs collected on 11 and 13 Apr 2003 and sent to another laboratory, the presence of herpes simplex virus was indicated -- for which he was treated with Aciclovir.Postmortem specimens of the right and left lung were collected and also sent to the NIC. PCR analysis of these samples confirmed the presence of H7 influenza A virus. Serum samples collected on 11 and 17 April displayed a slight increase in H7-specific antibodies in haemagglutination inhibition [HI] assay. This result needs to be confirmed in additional serological tests.Since the beginning of the HPAI H7N7 outbreak in chickens in The Netherlands at the end of February 2003, 82 confirmed cases of human H7N7 influenza virus infections have been recorded. The majority (79) of these cases presented with conjunctivitis, of which in 6 cases influenza-like illness (ILI) were reported as well. One  person had ILI alone but suffered an eye injury, precluding evaluation for the typical ocular signs of infection. The other 2 individuals presented with very mild symptoms and could not be classified as conjunctivitis or ILI.We have found strong evidence for transmission of H7N7 influenza from poultry workers to family members on 3 occasions. These contacts developed conjunctivitis. One of them, a 12-year-old child, had significant ILI as well and was repeatedly positive for A/H7.This first death of a previously healthy individual, for which H7N7 HPAI is the most likely cause, demonstrates that the HPAI outbreak in chickens, due to frequent transmission to humans and probably pigs, is a major concern to public and animal health. Protective measures in humans that are in close contact with infected animals (vaccination against human influenza and prophylactic treatment with antivirals) and culling of affected chicken flocks and pigs is of utmost importance to control this outbreak. Most poultry workers that were diagnosed with A/H7 in the past 2 weeks have been non-compliant. The importance of stringent control is underscored by the fact that A/H7 infections have been detected in poultry workers that had been recruited from other countries, beyond reach of the public health authorities involved in the containment of this outbreak.It is important to note that in the intensive monitoring that is currently implemented, no co-infections with H7N7 and human influenza A viruses have been detected so far. To date, no significant genetic changes have been observed in virus isolates from humans, including the [3] human-to-human transmission cases. The neuraminidase subtyping and genetic analysis of the influenza A virus detected in the deceased veterinarian will be important in determining  whether this is a "normal" avian influenza virus or one with distinct genetic and biological properties.Ron Fouchier, Thijs Kuiken, Gerard van Doornum, Marion Koopmans and Ab Osterhaus, National Influenza Centre, Bilthoven/Rotterdam, The Netherlands.--Ron A.M. Fouchier, PhDDept. VirologyErasmus MC3015 GE RotterdamThe Netherlands<fouchier@mailrelay.fgg.eur.nl>******[2]Date: Sat, 19 Apr 2003From: Stephen M. Apatow <s.m.apatow@humanitarian.net>Source: Reuters, 19 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://asia.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=scienceNews&storyID=2592178>Dutch vet's death linked to bird flu virus------------------------------------------A Dutch veterinarian has died of pneumonia after catching the poultry disease bird flu, officials said on Saturday, raising fears that a mutated version of the virus could cause a SARS-type epidemic in people.The 57-year-old man died on Thursday in the southern city of Den Bosch, the Health Ministry said. He fell ill 2 days after working on a farm infected with bird flu, or avian virus.The World Health Organisation has warned that the disease could turn into a human epidemic, at a time when deadly Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is sweeping the globe.The Dutch have been grappling for a month to contain the bird flu outbreak that has spilled into Belgium and is nearing Germany, amid concerns that bird and human flu could mix in pigs and produce a mutation that humans have no resistance against.Scientists stressed on Saturday that preventative measures were in place, including guidelines for at-risk workers to take medication against bird flu and human flu. Transport restrictions have been introduced for pigs after several animals were found to have antibodies to bird flu, and millions of birds have been slaughtered.The veterinarian who died had not taken antiviral medication."This was a very unusual situation," the Health Ministry said in a statement. "Because the bird flu virus was detected in the lungs and there is no other possible clinical explanation, there are strong indications that the man died as a result of the bird flu virus."Scientists at Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam identified the virus in the veterinarian's lungs as part of the same H7 family as the bird flu virus, Dr Albert Osterhaus, who heads the virology department, told Reuters.Staff were now working on further [genetic] sequencing to see whether any mutations had occurred, said Osterhaus. "The doom scenario would be if animals or humans became infected with human and animal viruses and there was an exchange of genetic material," Osterhaus said. "The result would be a (new) virus against which there would be no immunity in the population."The chances of this happening were small, however, and measures already in place should prevent it happening, he added.The "Asian flu" and "Hong Kong" pandemics of 1956-1957 and 1967-1968, caused by new influenza strains, killed a combined 4.5 million people."Up to now avian flu has never acquired the ability to transmit from one person to another -- if it does it could cause a large number of infections," World Health Organisation spokesman Iain Simpson told Reuters earlier this week. "There have been a number of influenza pandemics over the centuries, and the last one was in the late 1960s, so there is a view that we're overdue another one although that doesn't mean it's going to happen any time soon."Bird flu had already infected a handful of farm workers. Most only suffered minor eye infections that were relatively harmless and easily treated. A couple had influenza symptoms, but those cases were treated successfully, Osterhaus said.SARS, which has killed 172 people and infected nearly 3500 around the world, [is caused by a] coronavirus, a completely different family, one of which also causes the common cold. "The only similarity is that it is a virus that spills over from an animal reservoir...but what allowed that virus to cross the species barrier we have no idea," said Osterhaus, whose team was among global researchers who pinpointed the SARS virus.Some people say SARS might have been the result of human and avian viruses mixing in Guangdong, China, where people live close to animals, but Osterhaus said this is just speculation.[Byline: Eric Onstad]--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[We are very grateful for the first-hand, authoritative, and detailed report of Dr Fouchier and his NIC colleagues.In addition to the worrisome "most likely" possibility that this tragic case was directly and solely caused by the H7N7 virus, there is another cause for grave concern -- namely the "strong evidence" for 3 human-to-human infections of the said virus.The expert team's remark on the "utmost importance" of pig culling is significant; as reported earlier, so far only avians have been culled, while steps related to the culling of pigs seem to be under consideration by the Ministry of Agriculture (see ref 20030418.0950).Some press items tend to confuse SARS and Avian Influenza, occasionally speculating that SARS is also caused by a mutated avian virus. Prof Osterhaus' explanatory remark is timely. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza, human - Netherlands      20030311.0594Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (02) 20030313.0615Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (03) 20030314.0628Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (04) 20030315.0643Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (05) 20030316.0656Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (06) 20030318.0674Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (07) 20030319.0687Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (08) 20030327.0762Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950].................mpp/arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM (06): CONFIRMED*****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat, 19 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Press release, Belgian Food Chain Safety and Environment Agency(AFSCA/FAVV), 18 Apr 2003 [translated from Flemish, edited]<http://www.favv.fgov.be/indexNL.htm>Fowl Plague in Meeuwen - Gruitrode confirmed--------------------------------------Laboratory tests have confirmed the focus of "classical fowl plague"[Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza -- HPAI] in Meeuwen - Gruitrode.No new control measures are necessary, since the initial measures wereadopted while assuming that the seriously suspected case was, in fact, HPAI.In the absence of new developments , the AFSCA/FAVV expects somealleviation of measures to be possible after this weekend, enabling therenewal of poultry slaughter liable to strict requirements. The transportof other animal species and of table-eggs might also be allowed. The exactinstructions are to be found on the agency's web-site as of Sunday, 20 Apr2003, evening <http://www.favv.be>.Rapid PCR tests, carried out on poultry from the 8 depopulated farms aroundthe infected focus, were found negative.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[A Reuters posting of 19 Apr 2003, citing a Ministry spokesman, reports:"A second outbreak of HPAI may have hit Belgium. The spokesman said thesecond suspected outbreak was in an area near the first affected farm, andhad already been sealed off. He did not indicate the exact location".<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsArticle.jhtml?type=scienceNews&storyID=2592344>.- Mod. AS].[see also:Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946]------------------------mpp/arn/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030420.0967
Published Date20-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN - NETHERLANDS (10): FATAL CASE****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat, 19 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Letter POG/ZP 2.375.366 from the secretary of health to the chairof the Dutch parliament, 19 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod. AS,edited]<http://www.minvws.nl/document.html?folder=393&page=19598>Avian Influenza---------------On Thu, 17 Apr 2003, a 57-year-old veterinarian died in the Jeroen Bosch Hospital due to serious pneumonia.  Since fowl-plague (Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza -- HPAI) virus was detected in the lungs while no other possible explanation for the described disease picture was found, there is a strong indication that the man's death is the outcome of infection with the HPAI virus.The veterinarian became sick 2 days after working on an infected farm. He did not use antiviral preparations. According to the Outbreak Management Team (OMT), which held a meeting Friday, 18 Apr 2003 evening, this is a very rare situation. Until now, HPAI has been causing only conjunctivitis; the death of the veterinarian  is an exceptional course. He had no conjunctivitis. Investigations should find-out if the virus has undergone changes which might explain this serious development. These are being carried out in the National Influenza Centre (Erasmus Medical Centre) in Rotterdam.Following the advise of OMT, the close contacts of the veterinarian are [as a precaution  being] treated with the antiviral preparation oseltamivir (Tamiflu). This is meant to prevent any further spread of the virus, including close family members, engaged physicians and medical personnel from the relevant hospital's departments and the pathologists.The OMT indicates that the antiviral prescription is effective in preventing human infections with the HPAI virus. They stress the necessity of all those involved in the culling activities and those living or working on HPAI infected or suspected premises, to apply the prescribed protective measures and take the antivirals. During the last 2 weeks, only few infection cases were recorded in culling personnel, mostly in persons who did not apply sufficient protective measures. Taking oseltamivir (Tamiflu) for extended periods has no drawbacks.The Municipal Health Services in the relevant regions will provide the antiviral preparations, as well as flu vaccines, to all those directly engaged with suspected poultry farms and people coming in direct contact with infected chickens.Netherlands maintains an intensive influenza monitoring system which is engaged -- cooperatively with the practitioners -- in the detection of flu infections, including avian flu viruses.On Tue, 15 Apr 2003, the Minister of Agriculture, Nature Management and Fisheries [LNV] informed you about the detection of  antibodies against avian influenza in pigs in 5 mixed farms in the Gelders Valley. Following the advise of OMT and BAO (Board of administrators; see footnotes), and after consultation with NLV, it has been decided to remove pigs from the relevant farms. This has been already begun in 4 of those farms --  the 5th to follow.Further investigations on those farms have shown that no further spread of the virus has occurred; no influenza virus was detected in any pig.Investigations on mixed farms where culling [of poultry only?!.- Mod. AS] had already preventively been carried out, as well as in exclusive-pig farms, show that spread seems most unlikely. The matter is under further investigation. The monitoring is continued on mixed farms.The movement restrictions, applied by LNV in pig farms within the protection and buffer zones, are to be maintained.The State Secretary for Public Health, Welfare and Sports,Drs Clemence Ross-van Dorp--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Obviously, the recent death of a veterinarian involved in the HPAI control activities, has triggered the final decision to cull pigs on infected mixed farms. The letter includes additional data on the fatal human case, as well as new epidemiological data on the situation on pig farms, where investigations are still continued.Communicable disease control in the Netherlands is undertaken by municipal health services (GGD). Coordination between the 54 municipal health services and the national service has since 1995, been controlled by Landelijke Coordinatiestructuur voor de Infectieziektenbestrijding (LCI), which draws up guidelines and coordinates outbreak management. LCI consists of a professional advisory team (Outbreak Management Team, OMT, consisting of five permanent members with clinical, microbiological, and public healthbackgrounds and sometimes other specialists), a board of administrators (Bestuurlijk Afstemmings Overleg, BAO), and a small professional helpdesk (bureau LCI). The OMT advises the Permanent Secretary of Health (Minister van Volksgezondheid, Welzijn en Sport) through the Bestuurlijk Afstemmings Overleg. Local professional clinical, microbiological, and public health staff report data and join in the discussions of the OMT. The BAO check advice for practical feasibility and decide on the policy to be implemented (under the responsibility of Minister van Volksgezondheid). - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza, human - Netherlands 20030311.0594Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (02) 20030313.0615Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (03) 20030314.0628Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (04) 20030315.0643Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (05) 20030316.0656Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (06) 20030318.0674Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (07) 20030319.0687Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (08) 20030327.0762  Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case  20030419.0959Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950]----------------------arn/dk*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030420.0971

SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian Influenza - Belgium (07)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM (07)******************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sun, 20 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Reuters UK 20 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsArticle.jhtml?type=scienceNews&storyID=2593446>Belgium Reports 2 New Suspected Bird Flu Cases------------------------------------------------2 new suspected cases of the highly contagious bird flu disease [highly pathogenic avian influenza -- HPAI] have been discovered in Belgian farms near the Dutch border, a spokesman for the national food safety agency said on Sunday.The disease has spilled over into Belgium from the neighbouring Netherlands, where some 11 million birds have been slaughtered since late February 2003 in an effort to control it."We strongly suspect 2 new cases of bird flu in Belgium," Pascal Houbaert, spokesman for the food safety agency AFSCA told Reuters, adding that all poultry within a 3-km radius of the affected farms would be slaughtered.This could amount to 270 000 birds on top of the 250 000 Belgium has already slaughtered after a first case was discovered in the eastern region of Limburg on Wed 16 Apr 2003.The new suspected Belgian cases were in Kinrooi, also in Limburg and in an area closely monitored by food safety authorities.Houbaert said that following the sudden death of a Dutch veterinarian [infected with HPAI; see ref 20030419.0959], the Belgian authorities have recommended that all those coming into contact with the animals take antiviral medicines.Belgium has banned exports of live chickens and eggs and stopped transport of all poultry and poultry products within the country. The European Commission has enforced the ban [throughout the] European Union until 25 Apr 2003.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the local press, the 2 new suspected farms are situated in Kinrooi, close to the first confirmed outbreak. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946]...................mpp/arn/pg/dk*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. Archive Number20030422.0985
Published Date22-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (08): OIE
AVIAN INFLUENZA, POULTRY - USA (CT) (08): OIE*********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 22 April 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Office International des Epizooties(OIE), Disease Information [edited]<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_23.HTM#Sec1>Avian influenza in the US, in a commercial poultry enterprise (follow-up report No. 1)-------------------------Information received on (and up to) 11 Apr 2003 from Dr Peter Fernandez, associate administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), Washington, DC (end of previous report period: 11 Mar 2003 (see Disease Information 2003; 16(11): 67 (14 Mar)).This report describes 2 outbreaks in New London County, Connecticut, affecting table-egg layer hens in 2 commercial operations managed by the same enterprise.Total number of animals in the outbreak:species / susceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughteredavi / about 2 900 000 / ... / ... / 0 / 0Diagnosis: see previous report.Epidemiology: no new cases have been detected.A. Source of agent / origin of infection: unknown at this time, but the virus isolate seems to be the same one as that known to circulate occasionally in live bird markets in the New York City area.B. Mode of spread: direct contact, fomites.C. Other epidemiological details:- The results of 2 rounds of area testing indicate that the virus has not spread either to other establishments within the same enterprise or to other production facilities in the state of Connecticut and surrounding states.- A pilot program of sequential depopulation to eradicate the H7 virus will be conducted based on the vaccination of recovered hens and of replacement pullets prior to placement on the affected establishment.- Strict biosecurity measures will be followed to ensure virus containment, and monitoring will be conducted to detect any mutation of the virus.Control measures:- Quarantine and movement control.- USDA-APHIS is working closely with the state of Connecticut to conduct epidemiological investigations, tracebacks, and area surveillance testing.- Vaccination.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:2003---Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (07)            20030418.0949Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (06)            20030321.0699Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (05):OIE        20030316.0652Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (04)            20030315.0651Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (03): confirmed 20030313.0620Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (02): suspected 20030313.0619Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT): suspected      20030309.05812002---Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & N. Carolina) (06) 20020821.5104Avian influenza - USA (West Virginia)               20020512.4184Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & N. Carolina) (05) 20020501.4065Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & N. Carolina)(03)  20020411.3931Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & North Carolina)   20020406.3895Avian influenza - USA (Pennsylvania)                20020109.32122001---Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT): correction     20011119.2843Avian influenza, poultry - USA (Connecticut)        20011107.2760]................pc/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030423.0990
Published Date23-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium (08)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM (08)******************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date:From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Press release, Belgian Food Chain Safety and Environment Agency(AFSCA/FAVV), 22 Apr 2003 [translated from Flemish, edited]<http://www.favv.fgov.be/indexNL.htm>Fowl plague suspected in Bree-----------------------------A rapid polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test has detected fowl plague [highly pathogenic avian influenza - HPAI] in a poultry farm with about 21 000 chickens in the municipality of Bree. The farm, as well as 5 other poultry farms in the new protection zone (3 km), will be depopulated. This is a total of about 100 000 birds. Non-commercial holdings will be culled as well, within a 1 km radius.******[2]Date: Wed, 23 Apr 2003From: Dick Hamilton <rihamilto@shaw.ca>Source: Reuters, via @gWorldwide, 22 Apr 2003 [edited]Belgium discovers fourth case of suspected bird flu---------------------------------------------------A fourth suspected case of the highly contagious bird flu was detected on a Belgian farm near the Netherlands border and just a few miles away from previous outbreaks, a food safety agency spokesman said on Tue [22 Apr 2003]."There's a new case of bird flu in the city of Bree," food safety agency (AFSCA) spokesman Pascal Houbaert told Reuters. All 21 000 chickens on the farm will be slaughtered as well as poultry within a 3 km (1.9 mile) radius of the affected farm, which lies between 2 other sites where bird flu was discovered last week.This could amount to 120 000 birds in addition to the 500 000 Belgium has already destroyed, after the first case of the disease was discovered in the eastern region of Limburg last Wednesday.Avian flu has spread into Belgium from its neighbor the Netherlands -- the EU's biggest poultry exporter -- where some 11 million birds have been slaughtered since the end of February 2003 in an effort to control the spread of the disease. [The official Dutch figure, as of 22 Apr 2003, is 18 million culled birds - Mod.AS].Infected birds display symptoms of depression, a halt in egg laying, a loss of appetite, and swelling and discoloration of combs.Last week a Dutch vet died from pneumonia after working on a farm infected with the virus. Since the vet's death, Belgium has stepped up its public health controls, vaccinating all staff working on infected farms and requiring staff to take antiviral drugs.Belgium has banned exports of live chickens and eggs and briefly halted transport of all poultry products within the country. The European Union has enforced the ban at an EU level until Friday, but a European Commission (EC) spokeswoman said the current ban would probably be extended.Officials said the EC had planned to hold talks with veterinary officials from Belgium, the Netherlands, and most likely Germany on Tuesday. EU veterinary experts will meet to discuss the crisis on Wednesday.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[All 4 current outbreaks in Belgium are adjacent to the Dutch border. Bree is situated about 5 km north east of Meeuwen, where the first Belgian outbreak was detected last week, and 10 km to the west of Kinrooi, where the second and third outbreaks were reported on Sun, 20 Apr 2003.More detailed information on the Belgian policy regarding vaccination and preventive medication of persons engaged with HPAI-infected or suspected poultry could be useful. As recently experienced in the Netherlands, all those involved should be clearly instructed, and given adequate background information, especially regarding the safety of antiviral drugs. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian Influenza - Belgium (07)            20030420.0971Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946]..................arn/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030423.0991
Published Date23-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11)
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN - NETHERLANDS (11)*****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Wed 23 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Radio Netherlands Wereld Omroep, 22 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.rnw.nl/hotspots/html/dut030422.html>Fear of fowl pest mutation--------------------------With 2 cases of fowl pest [highly pathogenic avian influenza - HPAI] now reported across the Dutch border, the authorities in Belgium are taking no chances. After imposing a transport ban in the affected areas, they have stepped up an emergency vaccination campaign to protect people from the virus that causes fowl pest in chickens. All non-professional chicken-rearers and others coming into contact with the animals are now advised to get an anti-flu injection or to take antiviral medicines.The move comes after a Dutch veterinarian died of pneumonia last Thursday after catching avian flu while working at an infected poultry farm. The 57 year old vet had not been vaccinated or taken antiviral drugs. His death has fueled fears that the virus has mutated to a human strain in much the same way as an animal disease is believed to be the origin of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). [Though there has been speculation, so far there are no scientifically-based data indicating SARS' origin in animals. - Mod.AS]Experts, however, are playing down the chances that fowl pest could cause a full-blown epidemic in humans. A World Health Organization spokesman said on Saturday that the disease did not appear to spread easily from human to human.Dutch virologist Ab Osterhaus commented on national television that mutation of the virus was theoretically possible but practically improbable. He explained that this would require the exchange of DNA in a human simultaneously infected with avian influenza and a similar human variety. With the flu season over, the chances of that happening were remote, he said.In another interview this morning, Dr Osterhaus described the special emergency measures taken by Belgium as "overkill". "The preventive treatment of those few additional people doesn't make much sense," he remarked. In his view, the approach adopted by the Dutch government should be adequate, if followed meticulously. This means that all those involved in the fight against fowl pest are obliged to take special precautions, including vaccination and the use of antiviral drugs.******[2]Date: Wed, 23 pr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Ministry of Agriculture, Nature management and Fisheries (LNV) press release, 22 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/dossiers/vogelpest/>Independent inquiry into the death of a veterinarian----------------------------------------------------State secretary Ross (VWS) and minister Veerman (LNV) have decided to carry out an independent inquiry into the circumstances of the death of the 57 year old veterinarian in Den Bosch from serious pneumonia. Since fowl-plague [highly pathogenic avian influenza - HPAI] virus was detected in the veterinarian's lungs, and while no other explanation for the progression of his disease has been found, there is a strong indication that his death is the outcome of infection with the HPAI virus.******[3]Date: Wed, 23 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Ministry of Agriculture, Nature management and Fisheries (LNV) press release, 20 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.minvws.nl/zoeken.html?folder=548&envelope=1317§ion=21>Questions about the antiviral medication oseltamivir (Tamiflu)--------------------------------------------------------------1. What is oseltamivir (Tamiflu)?Tamiflu is an antiviral medication [neuraminidase inhibitor. - Mod.SH] active against influenza viruses.2. How does it work?It prevents the early multiplication of viruses in the body, so that cells already infected do not reinfect other cells.3. Why should oseltamivir be used?Oseltamivir is used to prevent the infection of humans with the fowl-plague virus during the fight against the epidemic. This way, the people exposed to the virus through their activities in the infected holdings are protected. Such people include assessors, veterinarians engaged in sample collection and culling activities, or tenants, residents, and laborers on the infected or suspected farms. In some cases the drug may be used to treat people who are already infected with the virus.4. Why should a flu jab [vaccination] be given in addition to oseltamivir?The flu jab is the best way to prevent infection with the currently circulating human influenza virus. This is crucial to prevent the fowl-pest virus and the common [human] virus from co-infecting the same person, enabling the creation of a new virus.5. How long can oseltamivir be taken?No data are available regarding the effects of extended use. Data from prevention studies, however, showed no indications limiting its use for 6 weeks. Under [medical] supervision, the medication can be taken for longer periods.6. Does oseltamivir influence the ability to drive or use machinery?As far as is known, oseltamivir does not affect driving fitness or the ability to operate machinery.7. Are alternative drugs to oseltamivir available?No, at present no other neuraminidase inhibitors are available. [Zanamivir is another neuraminidase inhibitor, introduced before oseltamivir, whose efficacy appears to be similar. - Mod.SH]8. Can oseltamivir be used during pregnancy?No sufficient data on the use of oseltamivir in pregnant women are available. Consequently, its use during pregnancy may be considered only for cases in which the potential benefit for the mother outweighs the potential risk to the fetus.9. Can oseltamivir be used during breast feeding?Here also, oseltamivir can be used only when the potential benefit for the mother justifies the potential risk to the baby.******[4]Date: Wed, 23 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: NRC HANDELSBLAD, 22 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/artikel/1050989242911.html>Confusion following doctor's death of fowl plague-------------------------------------------------The ministries of Public Health [VWS] and of Agriculture [LNV] have different interpretations regarding the scope of the directives for people engaged in the fight against fowl plague.They have announced an inquiry into the death of a 57 year old veterinarian from Rosmalen probably caused by the fowl-plague virus. [see 1]. State-secretary Ross of Public Health [VWS] said on Saturday evening on NOS TV, "Should the veterinarian have taken the drug which is compulsory for everyone in contact with infected birds (åÉ), then he would have been protected against infection."The victim's family said on Monday that no one told the veterinarian he had to take the antiviral drug. He was engaged by the Animal Health Service (GVD) in the fight against fowl plague, participating with 2 other vets in a team which visited a farm to investigate a suspected case, where he obtained several blood samples and took poultry manure [for investigations]. The difference between the interpretations of the 2 ministries relates to the reason for the victim's non-use of the drug. In a directive of 17 Mar 2003, VWS said, "all culling personnel and others who maintain extended, intensive contact with possibly infected chickens (should) receive preventive antiviral medication on a daily basis." The veterinarian did not receive these drugs [from his employer? - Mod.AS].It seems that the words "extended" and "intensive" were differently interpreted. According to a spokesman from the LNV, these terms did not cover the sampling during a first visit to a farm, but applied instead to the culling activities of the National Inspection Service for Livestock and Meat (RVV) and the veterinarians. On the other hand, according to the VWS, any direct contact with (possibly) infected animal is "intensive". The only "non-intensive" contact, according to them, was the installation of the "entrance forbidden" bands (ribbons) around farms.The colleagues of the late veterinarian in the GVD in Deventer decided on Saturday to discontinue their visits to poultry farms until clear directives are available. When the VWS produced its clearer guidelines later that day, they renewed their work.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The current HPAI outbreak, now covering 2 countries and threatening to spread further in Europe, is characterized by its significant zoonotic aspects. The experience gathered in the Netherlands, including the described controversies regarding protection of humans, is unique and might become essential for other countries; therefore it deserves detailed reporting. We shall continue following this emerging outbreak with interest and great concern, wishing the Dutch and Belgian authorities success in their disease-control endeavors. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (08)             20030327.0762Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (07)             20030319.0687Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (06)             20030318.0674Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (05)             20030316.0656Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (04)             20030315.0643Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (03)             20030314.0628Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (02)             20030313.0615Avian influenza, human - Netherlands                  20030311.0594]................arn/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. Archive Number20030424.1008
Published Date24-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (09)
AVIAN INFLUENZA, POULTRY - USA (CT) (09)****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail, a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 22 Apr 2003From: Bruce Sherman <Bruce.Sherman@po.state.ct.us>I was seriously misquoted in a previous posting (Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (07)  20030418.0949) by the referenced article, which originally appeared in the 12 Apr 2003 edition of the Hartford Courant and was written by Andre Bowser. The route of administration of the avian influenza vaccine to be used in Connecticut is subcutaneous.Mr Bowser was interviewing another Connecticut Department of Agriculture official for the article, and I was called in for not more than 3 minutes. I did not specifically tell Mr Bowser the route of administration of the avian influenza vaccine. I was questioned as to the various routes of vaccine administration in poultry and other livestock, and I explained each one. I did not say that "the vaccine would be administered subcutaneously into the muscle"!In addition, the statement "putting the vaccine in feed or water won't work because chickens are notoriously sloppy eaters" cannot be attributed to me. I did not attempt to correct the gross misrepresentation when the article appeared in the Hartford Courant, but I am requesting that ProMED-mail publish the correction.-- Bruce A Sherman, DVM, MPHDirector, Bureau of Regulation and InspectionConnecticut Department of AgricultureHartford, CT<bruce.sherman@po.state.ct.us>[ProMED-mail appreciates the clarification. Although the misquote was not originally ours, we are happy to issue a correction. - Mod.TG][see also:Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (08)  20030422.0985Avian influenza, poultry - USA (CT) (07)  20030418.0949].....................tg/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030425.1011
Published Date25-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (12)
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN - NETHERLANDS (12)*****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: 24 Apr 2003From: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>Source: World Health Organization (WHO) Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR), 24 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_04_24/en/>Date:Avian influenza in the Netherlands----------------------------------Outbreaks of a of highly pathogenic strain of avian influenza virus A (H7N7) have been reported in various poultry farms in the Netherlands since February 2003. Recent cases of the disease in poultry have also been reported in Belgium.While avian influenza strains normally infect exclusively poultry, Dutch authorities have reported that the H7N7 strain has now jumped the species barrier, causing one death and more than 80 cases of mild disease in humans. A 57 year old veterinarian who visited a poultry farm affected by the (H7N7) strain died on 17 Apr 2003 of acute respiratory distress syndrome in the Netherlands. H7N7 influenza virus was isolated from the patient. No other respiratory pathogen was detected in a series of laboratory tests.The detection of the H7N7 avian influenza strain in humans is the most recent case in which an avian influenza virus has crossed species to affect humans. In Hong Kong in 1997, the H5N1 strain of avian influenza caused its first outbreak in humans, with 18 cases and 6 deaths. In mid-February 2003, again in Hong Kong, the H5N1 strain infected 2 people, causing one death.Since the H7N7 outbreak began in the Netherlands in late February, there have been 83 confirmed cases of human H7N7. Most of these cases (79) exhibited conjunctivitis, and 13 of them displayed mild influenza-like illness. 3 family members of 2 poultry workers have also fallen ill with a minor respiratory disease, suggesting a possible chain of human-to-human transmission. Affected poultry in the Netherlands are being slaughtered as a control measures. Mass culling of poultry proved effective, in both Hong Kong outbreaks, in preventing further cases in humans.Close investigation, including tracing of the veterinarian's contacts, has not revealed any transmission of the disease (in its severe form, as opposed to the much milder conjunctivitis) to other people. Based on available evidence, WHO concludes that the death is an isolated case, as no efficient human-to-human transmission of the avian H7N7 influenza virus strain has been detected.In accordance with WHO's pandemic preparedness plan for influenza, WHO recommends that in countries where initial cases of H7N7 were detected, surveillance and diagnosis of the avian H7N7 virus should be enhanced in humans and susceptible animals (including chickens, turkeys, and pigs). In addition, countries should initiate specific investigations to increase understanding of possible transmission patterns. Specific personal protection, such as prophylactic use of the antiviral drug oseltamivir for agricultural workers in contact with H7N7-affected poultry, has also been recommended by national authorities in the Netherlands and in Belgium.WHO advises that persons in contact with H7N7-affected poultry flocks should be on guard for any signs and symptoms of respiratory disease. If symptoms arise, the person should consult a doctor, who will then initiate laboratory testing and reporting to health officials. WHO emphasizes that these heightened surveillance measures will help in the timely detection of any further transmission of H7N7 to humans and to prevent its possible spread.The WHO Global Influenza Surveillance Network is currently assembling a test kit for H7N7 that will be ready for use in 3 weeks. As a precautionary measure, the network is also working on the development of a vaccine for H7N7.******[2]Date: 23 Apr 2003From: Pablo Nart <p.nart@virgin.net>Source: BBC NEWS, 22 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/1/hi/business/2967381.stm>"No mutation" in Dutch bird virus---------------------------------A Dutch vet believed to have died of bird flu was not suffering from a mutated form of the virus, the Dutch health ministry has been quoted as saying.The 57 year old vet died of pneumonia last week, sparking fears that the bird flu virus might have mutated into a potentially deadly new human form of flu. But health officials now believe he had contracted only the "normal" form of the bird virus. Officials had stressed that there was little danger to human health. But as well as the death of the vet, dozens of people have now contracted conjunctivitis.Dutch ministers have announced an independent inquiry into the vet's death. "We now know there's no mutation of the virus, we know for sure that the vet died of the original bird flu. It's very good to know that," a health ministry spokesman told Reuters new agency.The vet had not taken anti-viral medicine, as recommended by the government, the spokesman added. "If he had taken his anti-virals he probably wouldn't have died," he said. A government statement issued at the weekend said the direct cause of death was chronic pneumonia, but said bird flu virus was also found in his lungs. "No other cause of death could be detected, a clear indication that the man died as a result of infection from this virus," the statement added. It added that there were no signs that anyone else has caught the virus from the vet.Health officials fear that if the bird flu became mixed with human flu viruses, the result could be a deadly new form of the disease. "The contact between the 2 viruses could produce a new strain," Dutch virologist Albert Osterhaus told Dutch television.Bird flu is highly contagious among chickens, turkeys, and ducks but infects humans only rarely. A 1997 bird flu outbreak in Hong Kong also spread to the human population, killing 6 people. Dutch workers involved in the cull have been vaccinated against the disease, and have been given other medication to help ward off infection. In Belgium, antiviral drugs are being offered to vets and others in contact with infected birds.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The Dutch daily NRC Handelsblad (24 Apr 2003], citing a spokesman of the Dutch Ministry of Health, says that the total number of conjuctivitis cases has risen to 83; 5 of them are veterinarians. It would be helpful to know whether the Dutch workers have fully sequenced the complete genome of the virus from the deceased vet, or merely the H7 and N7 genes. -  Mods.CP/AS][see also:Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11)              20030423.0991Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case  20030420.0967Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case  20030419.0959Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (08)              20030327.0762Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (07)              20030319.0687Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (06)              20030318.0674Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (05)              20030316.0656Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (04)              20030315.0643Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (03)              20030314.0628Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (02)              20030313.0615Avian influenza, human - Netherlands                   20030311.0594].................mpp/arn/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030425.1012
Published Date25-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS**************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 24 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: European Union (EU) Press release IP/03/564, 23 Apr 2003 [edited]Update on avian influenza in the Netherlands and Belgium--------------------------------------------------------The Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health met today to discuss again the avian influenza situation in the Netherlands and Belgium. In general the existing restrictive measures adopted to prevent the spreading of the disease and to eradicate it have been extended until 12 May 2003. The Committee also had an exchange of information with regard to the public health aspects of the current epidemic.The Netherlands---------------Since the beginning of the outbreak of avian influenza (AI) in the Netherlands on 28 Feb 2003, 233 infected holdings have been confirmed and another 23 are seriously suspected to be contaminated. In total, about 18 million birds in about 1000 holdings have been culled.The Committee today voted in favour of a Commission proposal to extend until 12 May 2003 the existing measures to prevent the spreading of the disease and to eradicate it. No live poultry, hatching eggs, or fresh, unprocessed poultry manure or litter may be exported to other member states or third countries and, with some exceptions, no live poultry or hatching eggs may be transported within the Netherlands. The Netherlands shall also ensure that in the buffer zones created around infected areas, all poultry will be culled as soon as possible.In addition to these existing measures, tests will be done on pigs kept on infected holdings, and movement restrictions will apply to pigs in case of positive findings. The Netherlands may also decide to apply vaccination against AI of susceptible birds in zoos.Belgium-------On 15 Apr 2003, avian influenza also spread to Belgium, in the province of Limburg. To date 3 outbreaks have been confirmed and 2 strongly suspected outbreaks are under examination.The Committee extended until 12 May 2003 the measures already adopted by the Commission on 16 Apr 2003 (see IP/03/552), which are similar to those taken in the Netherlands. Furthermore, Belgium shall ensure the preventive depopulation of poultry holdings in the surveillance zone as soon as possible to create a buffer zone. Tests will also be carried out on pigs in infected holdings. Belgium may also decide to apply vaccination against AI of susceptible birds in zoos.Public health aspects---------------------Influenza viruses of avian origin may rarely affect other animals or humans. Usually, the sickness induced in humans by virus strains of avian origin is not serious (conjunctivitis, some respiratory signs). Therefore, Dutch and Belgian authorities advised that veterinarians and other workers or farmers and their families having direct contact with affected poultry take protective measures. Those at risk shall use protective clothes and glasses, receive vaccination against human influenza, and undergo prophylactic treatment with antiviral drugs.A total of 82 human cases of conjunctivitis due to avian influenza have been reported in the Netherlands and one in Belgium. A Dutch veterinarian died on 17 Apr 2003 of influenza-like illness and bilateral pneumonia. Following the postmortem examination, the Dutch authorities have arrived at the conclusion that his death was linked directly to avian influenza virus. It appears, however, that the veterinarian did not take the antiviral drugs.At present avian influenza does not represent a risk to the general public. Furthermore, it must be distinguished from the current outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which is caused by a different virus (most likely a coronavirus).The Commission and the member states urged the Dutch and Belgian authorities to take all protective measures to prevent influenza infections of the workers and other persons at risk. Again, these measures may include the use of protective clothing, gloves, and glasses, as well as vaccination and prophylactic antiviral treatment.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The EU's decision to allow both countries the use of an HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) vaccine in zoos may indicate the availability of a H7N7 vaccine. More information will be appreciated. Animal protection organizations in Germany have recently demanded preventive vaccination of poultry there, to avoid the need for mass slaughter should HPAI be spread from the 2 infected neighboring countries. This issue might be become the subject of public debate.2 additional outbreaks, highly suspected as HPAI, have been reported yesterday, 24 Apr 2003, in Belgium -- namely, in the municipalities Meer and Bree. This brings the total current number of outbreaks in Belgium to 7.The Dutch Ministry of Agriculture reported as of 25 Apr 2003 a cumulative total of 238 confirmed HPAI-infected farms and an additional 24 outbreaks currently regarded as "highly suspected". - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11)             20030423.0991Avian influenza - Belgium (08)                        20030423.0990Avian Influenza - Belgium (07)                        20030420.0971Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed             20030419.0965Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement   20030418.0950Avian influenza - Netherlands (20): OIE               20030416.0929Avian influenza - Netherlands (19)                    20030408.0855Avian influenza - Netherlands (16)                    20030327.0761]....................arn/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030426.1021
Published Date26-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Influenza, vaccinated equines - UK (03)
INFLUENZA, VACCINATED EQUINES - UK (03)***************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat, 26 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: TheHorse.Com, art 4318, 23 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.thehorse.com/viewarticle.asp?fid=4318&dpt=5>Equine influenza spreads in the UK----------------------------------Equine influenza has spread to nearly 20 premises -- mostly thoroughbred training stables -- in the United Kingdom, and it has been detected in the eastern, central, and southern parts of the country. "The reason (it's unusual) is that, despite the fact that horses have been very well vaccinated and have very high antibody levels, they are still becoming infected with this strain of virus," according to James Wood, head of epidemiology at the Animal Health Trust in the UK. He said no racetracks have been affected by the illness.Influenza, while typically not life-threatening, can make a horse uncomfortable and vulnerable to other diseases. Infected horses usually require a minimum of 3 to 4 weeks of rest to avoid long term respiratory problems. Affected horses spread the virus via aerosol droplets or fomites (any objects capable of mechanically transporting an infectious agent, such as brushes or buckets). Horses exposed to transient populations, those stressed by shipping or heavy training schedules, young horses, and seniors are most at risk of contracting influenza. Signs in the current outbreak have included acute coughing, mainly during exercise, and some horses have developed nasal discharge. Fever has been seen, but is not a consistent sign. It's difficult to ascertain how many horses have been exposed to influenza, but veterinarians have continued to sample populations to try and determine the extent of its spread. Wood said 18 to 20 premises are currently affected.Wood explained that the centralized disease reporting system in the UK has been advantageous because all laboratory influenza diagnoses on UK samples are made at the Animal Health Trust. It can be difficult to tally accurate numbers of disease cases when many different diagnostic laboratories are being used, or if there are multiple disease-reporting systems in a country. That is not the case in the United Kingdom. "We work very closely with the industry to try and control these diseases," he said.[byline: Stephanie L Church]-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[2 subtypes of influenza A virus are known to cause influenza in horses, namely the subtypes H7N7 (formerly known as A/equine 1) and H3N8 (formerly known as A/equine 2). In recent years, most outbreaks have been associated with the H3N8 subtype, however serological evidence of H7N7 infections continues to be reported.Although these are not genuine human pathogens, humans can become infected with equine influenza virus subtypes. Such infections are unusual and subclinical, but may represent a potential biohazard to laboratory personnel. An avian influenza strain of H7N7 subtype virus has recently caused human infections in the Netherlands.Information on equine influenza vaccines are available in CHAPTER 2.5.5. of the Manual of standards, Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines 2000 of the OIE <http://www.oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/A_00073.htm> and on the equiflunet: <http://195.224.162.216/equiflunet/equiflunet_vaccines.html>. Data on the virus subtype and strain, currently evolving in the UK "despite the fact that horses have been very well vaccinated and have very high antibody levels," will be appreciated. - Mod.AS][see also:Influenza, vaccinated equines - UK (02) 20030417.0942Influenza, vaccinated equines - UK      20030323.0720]......................arn/pg/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM (09): OIE****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 27 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Office International des Epizooties(OIE), Disease Information [edited]<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_22.HTM#Sec3>AVIAN INFLUENZA IN BELGIUMFollow-up report No. 1 (confirmation of diagnosis)Translation of information received on 23 Apr 2003 from Dr Luc Lengele, Chief Veterinary Officer, Animal Health and Animal Products Department, Federal State Service for Public Health, Food Chain Safety and Environment, Brussels:End of previous report period: 16 Apr 2003 (see Disease Information, 16 [16], 98, dated 18 Apr 2003).End of this report period: 23 Apr 2003.New outbreaks:Reference No./  LocationOutbreak 2003/2 /  Molenbeersel (Kinrooi) district, Limbourg provinceOutbreak 2003/3/  Kinrooi district, Limbourg provinceOutbreak 2003/4/  Bree district, Limbourg provinceDescription of affected population in the new outbreaks: layers and broilers.Total number of animals in the new outbreaks:species / susceptible / cases / deaths / destroyed / slaughteredavi / 64 700 / > 4200 / 2000 / 62 700 / 0Diagnosis:A. Laboratory where diagnosis was confirmed: Veterinary and Agrochemical Research Centre (VAR), Brussels.B. Diagnostic tests used:- RT-PCR(1) (20 Apr 2003);- virus isolation in eggs;- cell cultures found positive on 22 Apr 2003.C. Causal agent: strain H7N7 of the avian influenza virus.Epidemiology:A. Source of agent / origin of infection: unknown.B. Mode of spread: unknown.Control measures during reporting period:- quarantine;- stamping-out policy.Vaccination against the disease remains prohibited.(1) RT-PCR: reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:2003----Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (12) 20030425.1011Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11) 20030423.0991Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium (08) 20030423.0990Avian Influenza - Belgium (07) 20030420.0971Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946Avian influenza - Belgium (04): not, OIE 20030320.0694Avian influenza - Belgium (03): suspected (OIE) 20030318.0671Avian influenza - Belgium (02): suspected 20030313.0614Avian influenza - Belgium: suspected 20030312.0610Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian influenza - Netherlands (19) 20030408.0855Avian influenza - Netherlands (18) 20030405.0834Avian influenza - Netherlands (11) 20030311.0593Avian influenza - Netherlands (07) 20030305.0549Avian influenza - Netherlands (06) 20030304.0546]...... pc/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed.
