Published Date28-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination
  AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS: VACCINATION***************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sun, 27 Apr 2003From: Dave Halvorson <halvo002@umn.edu>[Re the moderator's remark in the said posting]  "The EU's decision to allow both countries the use of an HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) vaccine in zoos may indicate the availability of a H7N7 vaccine. More information will be appreciated":The vaccine is not a HPAI vaccine, but a H7 vaccine. A H7 vaccine has been used in Italy to combat a low-pathogenic H7 outbreak of AI, and a different one is about to be used in Connecticut for the same purpose.--David A. Halvorson, DVM, ACPVExtension Veterinarian - Avian HealthCollege Of Veterinary MedicineUniversity of Minnesota1971 Commonwealth AvenueSaint Paul, Minnesota 55108<halvo002@umn.edu>[Dr Halvorson's much-appreciated remark justifies an update and presentation of clarifying data. The vaccine applied in Northern Italy during the 2000-2002 epizootic caused by an H7N1 HPAI virus was an inactivated, heterologous subtype HPAI vaccine (strain A/Chicken/Pakistan/1995-H7N3). The reason for the selection  of a heterologous vaccine was the possibility of using it as a natural "marker" or a DIVA (differentiating infected from vaccinated animals). This enabled the EU to approve another AI vaccination scheme in Northern Italy that has been operational since 31 Dec 2002, using again a heterologous vaccine, this time an HPAI H7N1 subtype, to protect against the current H7N3 LPAI field strain (see 20021225.6121 and the 2 references).The H7N3 vaccine used in Italy in 2000-2002 is one of the 2 vaccines approved last week by the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture for the vaccination of susceptible animals in zoos (Temporary exemption decree, published on 22 Apr 2003, <http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/persinfo/>).References:1. Capua, I et al,(2003). Development of a DIVA -- differentiating infected from vaccinated animals -- strategy using a vaccine containing a heterologous neuraminidase for the control of avian influenza. Avian Pathology 32, 47-55.2. Capua, I & Marangon, S (2003). Vaccination in the control of avian influenza in the EU. Veterinary Record, 153 (9), 271.- Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands       20030425.10122002----Influenza, avian - Italy: vaccination      20021225.6121]...................arn/pg/tg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030429.1061
Published Date29-APR-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS (02)*******************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Tue, 29 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Pighealth.com, 28 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.pighealth.com/influenza2.htm>Origin of the HPAI H7N7 influenza virus----------------------------------------The origin is uncertain, but we are told by a Dutch epidemiologist that one theory is that the outbreaks may have originated in the southwest of the Netherlands near a lake district called Biesbos. A surveillance survey found 3 poultry farms which were seropositive for low pathogenicity AI (avian influenza virus). One of these farms had free-range poultry and was adjacent to canals with many wild waterfowl. The farm is reported to have had a hatchery service man who also served flocks in the Gelderse Valley. It is possible that the low pathogenicity avian influenza strain mutated to a HPAI strain after infecting poultry in the Gelderse Valley.However, according to virologist Prof Dr A. Osterhaus of the Erasmus University in Rotterdam, his group have previously (1-2 years ago) found the HPAI H7N7 virus type in migrating ducks and waterfowl. It seems likely that wild waterfowl are a reservoir of the virus.Similar virus strains (H7N1, H7N3) have been isolated in Italy over the past 4 years from poultry farms; in Italy turkey flocks have also been reservoirs for the virus.******[2]Date: Tue, 29 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature Management and Fisheries 29 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/dossiers/vogelpest/>Situation 29 April -- infections and suspicions----------------------------------------------The total number of seriously suspected outbreaks of fowl plague [highly pathogenic avian influenza -- HPAI] is currently 15, of which 5 are in non-commercial ("hobby" management) holdings. Since the beginning of the epidemic, 243 holdings have been found definitely infected, of which 19 were diagnosed on non-commercial ("hobby") holdings. 21.0 million AI-susceptible animals have been culled so far.******[3]Date: Tue, 29 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: News24.com, 27 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.news24.com/News24/World/News/0,,2-10-1462_1352636,00.html>Bird flu: Europe on red alert-----------------------------Several western European countries are on red alert as an epidemic of highly contagious bird flu -- which has reportedly killed one person after crossing the species barrier -- continued to take its toll on Dutch and Belgian poultry farms.The Netherlands and Belgium went on slaughtering chickens in a bid to prevent the spread of the avian influenza, and the Netherlands ordered an investigation to assess the impact on people of the viral disease, which is highly contagious to chickens, turkeys, ducks, and other birds.Germany and France, which share borders with the Netherlands and Belgium, were also on guard against a possible spread of the ailment, which has already caused nearly 20 million chickens to be culled.Experts say that the current outbreak, caused by a virus known as H7N7, is not dangerous to people, but that the virus could mutate, triggering a potentially dangerous influenza epidemic.The World Health Organization [WHO], which is preparing a test kit and developing a vaccine for the disease, has advised special vigilance. "Persons in contact with H7N7-affected poultry flocks should be on guard for any signs and symptoms of respiratory disease," it said on Thu, 24 Apr 2003.WHO has said that a 57-year-old Dutch veterinarian, who died on 17 Apr of chronic pneumonia, may have died of bird flu, after traces of the virus were found in his lungs. WHO says his death appeared to be an isolated case."No other cause of death could be detected, a clear indication that the man died as a result of infection from this virus," said a Dutch statement. A further 83 people in the Netherlands have been diagnosed with mild conjunctivitis and flu-like symptoms that have been traced to H7N7, but their cases were not serious, it said.The Dutch health ministry said it would examine some 5000 people who have been in contact with infected birds, some of whom would have to take blood tests. Over 18.5 million chickens [For updated figures, see 2 above] from a population of 100 million have been culled in the Netherlands, where an outbreak of the disease started in late February 2003.  Belgium has slaughtered more than 700 000 in just over one week.Both countries have created buffer zones, and Brussels has slapped even stricter controls on a contaminated area north of the port city of Antwerp. The European Commission has extended bans on the export of live poultry, eggs, or fresh bird meat from the Netherlands and Belgium, until 12 May and 10 May, respectively.Germany, where 100 million chickens are raised, and which shares borders with both the Netherlands and Belgium, has warned farmers to be extremely cautious and request certificates of origin whenever they buy chickens.******[4]Date: Tue, 29 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Reuters via @gWorldwide, 29 Apr 2003 [edited]EU vets to debate vaccination in bird flu fight------------------------------------------------Dutch veterinarians will consult fellow European Union experts next week about using vaccination as a way to stop the spread of the highly contagious bird flu virus, EU officials said on Tue, 29 Apr 2003.At a meeting slated for 6 and 7 May 2003, EU vets from the bloc's 15 member states will hold a debate on aspects of possible vaccination against bird flu -- a move so far ruled out by the Netherlands due to the sheer numbers of birds involved.The debate will focus on eggs produced for consumption, according to the meeting's draft agenda published on Tuesday. Apart from being the world's top egg exporter, the Netherlands is also the EU's biggest poultry exporter.More than 18 million out of the country's more than 100 million birds have now been slaughtered, as authorities battle to suppress the spreading outbreak of bird flu."The Netherlands asked us to put it on the agenda, to have a discussion about it. It's not a formal request to vaccinate ...but they are considering the possibility," said an official at the European Commission."They are not planning to vaccinate, they just want to have a discussion with the member states (about) what the consequences of possible vaccination would be," he said. "And there are voices in the Netherlands asking for this."Last month, Dutch health authorities launched a vaccination programme for farm workers after several suffered from a minor form of bird flu. The eye infections caused by the virus were relatively harmless and easily treated.Dutch authorities ratcheted up their fight against the virus last week, announcing they would slaughter 6 million more birds and set up a new buffer zone in the poultry sector's southern heartland. Belgium has already reported 8 cases.But the practical difficulties in vaccinating millions of birds would be immense, not to mention the impact on exports from the key poultry and egg sector, which has racked up losses in excess of 100 million euros due to the bird flu outbreak.The Netherlands exports some 80 percent of its egg production, which in turn is more than 60 percent of EU exports. Its main export markets are Hong Kong and also Gulf states such as Oman and the United Arab Emirates."If you have to vaccinate 50 million animals, it's practically not possible," the official said. "The disease is spreading very quickly and if you vaccinate, the incubation period is 2 weeks. For bigger birds, they might need a second vaccination."[Byline: Jeremy Smith]--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Following the decision of the Dutch authorities to permit the vaccination of susceptible animals in zoos, a debate on possible vaccination of other animals seems inevitable. The Belgian daily Het Nieuwsblad of 29 Apr 2003 presents the story of the Vermeiren family from Loenhout, who had to cull their entire stock of ostriches -- 144 birds -- because of their proximity to an infected chicken farm. Such birds, as well as "hobby" birds holdings, might be the next to demand vaccination.The vaccines, officially allowed in the decree of 22 Apr 2003 by the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture for restricted use in zoos, are Nobilis Influenza H7 manufactured by Intervet (Boxmeer) and Fluvac H7, manufactured by  Merial B.V. (Amstelveen). Both include a heterologous neuraminidase (not N7), which enables their use as natural "marker" vaccines or DIVA (differentiating infected from vaccinated animals). - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination      20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012].....................arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030501.1087
Published Date01-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (02)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS: VACCINATION (02)********************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Thu 1 May 2003From: Dick Hamilton <rihamilto@shaw.ca>Source: Reuters via Alertnet, 30 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/T203738.htm>A leading influenza expert said on Wed, 30 Apr 2003 that vaccinating flocks against bird flu may not be the best option for Europe, which is battling to halt the spread of the highly contagious disease."If you are vaccinating, then you do not know whether you have eradicated the problem. The virus might be there at low level," Malik Peiris, virology chief at the University of Hong Kong, told Reuters in a telephone interview."Obviously the first option would be to try to stamp out the infection, if it is possible, by detecting affected farms and slaughtering... That is the measure that has been used in the past and it works."Dutch veterinarians are to consult fellow European Union experts next week about using vaccination as a way to stop the spread of the H7N7 flu, which has killed a Dutch veterinarian.More than 18 million of more than 100 million birds have been slaughtered in the Netherlands, the EU's top poultry exporter. [The actual figure, on 29 Apr 2003, reached 21.0 million].Peiris, a Sri Lankan, was one of the first microbiologists to identify the SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) virus, which appeared in southern China in November and has since infected over 5700 people and killed 354 worldwide.But he said avian flu, or bird flu, viruses were completely different from SARS.He has been on the front lines in the fight against avian flu in Hong Kong, where it crossed to humans for the first time in 1997, killing 6 people. He also studied another death here in February caused by the H5N1 bird-flu virus."In Hong Kong, we are in a different situation (from Europe), because we are in the middle of an area where it seems avian flu is completely endemic," he said. "I personally think we have no option but to vaccinate."Hong Kong is evaluating a trial vaccination programme that began following an outbreak in February 2002.The outbreak of avian flu in the Netherlands has spilled into Belgium amid concern that bird and human flu could mix and produce a strain against which humans have no resistance."Certainly such concern is quite justified," Peiris said. "We are concerned that some of these avian flu viruses might adapt to human-to-human transmission."While neither the H5N1 Hong Kong virus nor the Dutch H7N7 virus has acquired genes from human viruses, Peiris said studies had shown one virus could mix gene segments with another virus, which could lead to a big change in the individual gene."We know that, with H5N1 virus in this region, they have been re-assorting and picking up new genes from other avian sources. Up to now, no human genes have gotten picked up," he said."We also know that in 1957 and 1968, the pandemic virus arose by the re-assortment of an avian virus and human virus."  The so-called "Asian flu" outbreak in 1957-1958 killed an estimated one million people worldwide, and the "Hong Kong Flu" claimed another million lives in 1968-1969.The microbiologist said re-assortment of genes was also to blame for the more frequent outbreaks of the avian flu in Hong Kong recently, despite a number of measures introduced after 1997."In 2001, clearly the parent virus re-assorted with other viruses -- like [those from] ducks and aquatic birds.  That has made it far more difficult to keep the virus out of Hong Kong. From that time on, we often found that virus in poultry."[Byline: Nao Nakanishi]--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The strategy adopted in Hong Kong during the recent HPAI outbreak there -- December 2002/January 2003 -- was a combination of "modified stamping out" (culling of all birds in infected farms), quarantine measures, surveillance, and vaccination of farms around the infected ones ("ring vaccination"); see 20030126.0236. An oil-adjuvant H5N1 vaccine was used. Hong-Kong's strategy to control avian influenza was explained in their press release:<http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200301/17/0117191.htm>.In one infected farm (8 Jan 2003), the first step was vaccination of all chickens in unaffected sheds that were segregated from the affected sheds, combined with ring vaccinations (8 farms). Slaughter of birds in the affected sheds was conducted 2 days later.Italy's (see 20030429.1061) and Hong-Kong's recent experience and their respective evaluations are valuable for the deliberations on AI vaccinations, due 5-6 May in Brussels. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE (02)  20030126.0236Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE  20030120.0186Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination  20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02)  20030429.1061Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement  20030418.0950]..................arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030501.1092
Published Date01-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (13)
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN - NETHERLANDS (13)*****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Thu, 1 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly, Vol 7, 18, 1 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030501.asp#1>Update on human infections with highly pathogenic avian influenza virusA/H7N7 during an outbreak in poultry in the Netherlands-----------------------------------------------During the 2003 outbreak of avian influenza caused by highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus A/H7N7 in the Netherlands, human infection with this virus occurred in unexpectedly high numbers. The first signs of human infection were found in a veterinarian who visited several farms with infected poultry and subsequently developed acute conjunctivitis caused by the A/H7N7 virus. Human influenza virus (mostly A/H3N2) was circulating in the community simultaneously. In view of the potential risk of co-infection and reassortment, active case finding among people exposed to infected poultry was implemented immediately.A case of conjunctivitis was defined as a person who had been exposed to contaminated poultry or a confirmed human case of avian influenza A/H7 since 28 Feb 2003 in the Netherlands, with at least 2 of the following symptoms: flow of tears or red or itching or painful or burning eyes or pus or photophobia. A case of influenza-like illness (ILI) was defined as a person who had been exposed to contaminated poultry or a confirmed human case of avian influenza A/H7 since 28 Feb 2003 in the Netherlands with acute illness onset and fever with at least one of the following symptoms: cough, rhinorrhoea, sore throat, myalgia, or headache.Based on the initial findings, all those involved in the culling of poultry were advised to wear protective goggles and face masks, and to wash their hands, especially before returning home from work. In addition, vaccination with the current influenza vaccine and prophylactic treatment with neuraminidase inhibitors of all people exposed to infected poultry was initiated, as well as treatment of all patients reporting to the municipal health services who had been exposed.As of 22 Apr 2003, conjunctival and throat swabs were collected from 293 patients, of whom 260 fit the case definition of conjunctivitis and/or ILI.  78 of 260 cases had H7 positive conjunctival swabs. 8 cases also had an H7-positive throat swab. One had an H7-positive throat swab only. One of the cases presenting with ILI only had an H7-positive conjunctival swab. An additional 2 patients who did not fit the case definition for conjunctivitis had H7-positive lab results. Both complained of 'burning eyes' only. 6 cases had H3-positive throat swabs, but no simultaneous infection with H7 and H3 influenza virus was detected.[Total number H7 positives: 82].Most conjunctivitis cases occurred between 5 and 20 Mar 2003, after which date the number of new cases dropped below 5 reports per day. This was approximately 5 days after implementation of the more stringent precautionary measures, including prophylactic treatment with oseltamivir of all persons exposed to suspected or confirmed infected poultry. 2 weeks later, however, the number of reported and confirmed cases showed a slight increase. Only 8 of 25 new cases (32 percent) claim to have taken oseltamivir prophylaxis in accordance with the guidelines, although all have had prolonged exposure to suspect or confirmed infected poultry. A relevant finding was also the confirmation of A/H7-associated conjunctivitis in 4 poultry workers from Poland and one from Belgium, all involved in the culling. While the risk is low, they do present a possible vector for transmission of avian influenza virus to other areas. This finding was communicated to the health authorities in Poland, Germany, and Belgium.There has been preventive depopulation of poultry flocks in Germany along the border with the Netherlands, although there have so far been no suspected or confirmed AI infections in German poultry. Precautionary measures regarding possible spread of the virus to other farms and among humans are being implemented.3 household contacts of confirmed cases developed A/H7-associated conjunctivitis while they had no direct exposure to infected poultry. All 3 had conjunctivitis as the most prominent presenting symptom, while one (a 12 year old child) additionally developed ILI. These results strongly suggest person to person transmission of avian influenza A/H7N7 virus.On 17 Apr 2003, a veterinarian who had visited a poultry farm infected with HPAI died as the result of acute respiratory distress syndrome, which developed following a one-week episode of ILI. Conjunctivitis was not observed, and the course of illness was protracted, with bilateral pneumonia unresponsive to treatment resulting in death 2 weeks later. The veterinarian had visited an infected flock for sampling, and was not taking prophylactic drugs for reasons that have not yet been clarified. There was no history of underlying illness. The diagnostic evaluation was complicated: throat and conjunctival samples collected after one week of illness tested negative for A/H7 from both labs involved in the testing. A bronchoalveolar lavage collected 2 days later was positive for A/H7. Differential diagnostic tests for legionella, mycoplasma, psittacosis, and other bacterial pathogens were negative. All hospital contacts and the relatives of this person were given oseltamivir prophylaxis, and persons with symptoms were sampled for virological testing. So far no secondary transmissions have been detected.Release of information to the media about the death resulted in an upsurge of reports of possible cases and renewed discussion about the details of the preventive measures. It was reinforced that poultry workers and farmers, including anyone visiting an infected flock, should wear protective clothing, masks to cover the mouth and nose, and eye protection, be vaccinated against influenza, and take prophylactic antiviral medication. Based on the existing information, the consensus is that these measures should prevent serious consequences of A/H7 transmission.At present, a cohort study is being conducted among confirmed cases and their household contacts in order to ascertain the extent of person-to-person transmission of AI and to identify risk factors. Another cohort study among poultry workers and poultry farmers will be conducted in order to study risk factors for transmission of AI from poultry to humans.Our preliminary observations support the hypothesis that infected humans might function as a 'mixing vessel' for generating novel influenza viruses and strongly support a need for active surveillance and pandemic planning.M. Koopmans, R. Fouchier , B. Wilbrink, A.Meijer, G. Natrop, A.D.M.E. Osterhaus, J.E. van Steenbergen, M. du Ry van Beest Holle, M.A.E. Conyn van Spaendonck, A. Bosman <Marion.Koopmans@rivm.nl>[The respective institutions of the authors, a detailed table, and figure are available in the original].--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Influenza, avian - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination  20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands  20030425.1012Avian influenza, human - Netherlands  20030311.0594Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (02)  20030313.0615Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (03)  20030314.0628Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (04)  20030315.0643Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (05)  20030316.0656Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (06)  20030318.0674Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (07)  20030319.0687Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (08)  20030327.0762Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case  20030419.0959Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case  20030420.0967Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11)  20030423.0991Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (12)  20030425.1011]....................mpp/arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS (03)*******************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Thu, 1 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly, Vol 7, 18, 1 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030501.asp#1>European Commission and the World Health Organization respond to risk of spread of avian influenza following outbreak in the Netherlands and Belgium--------------------------------------------------In the Netherlands, existing restrictive measures adopted by the European Commission to control the spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (A/H7N7) have been extended until 12 May 2003. No live poultry, hatching eggs, or fresh, unprocessed poultry manure or litter may be exported to other member states or third countries and, with some exceptions, no live poultry and hatching eggs may be transported within the Netherlands. All poultry in the buffer zones created around infected areas will be culled as soon as possible.In Belgium, where 3 outbreaks have been confirmed, and 2 suspected outbreaks are under investigation, the same measures have been adopted by the Commission as for the Netherlands. In view of the specificity of poultry production, however, the Belgian veterinary authority may authorise certain movements of hatching eggs, day-old chicks, ready-to-lay pullets, and poultry for immediate slaughter within Belgium.The Commission has also reached decisions recommending that the Netherlands and Belgium take appropriate precautionary measures regarding the prevention of influenza infections in poultry workers and other persons at risk, and to impose a serological survey of pigs kept on poultry farms where an avian influenza outbreak is notified. Both countries may also decide to apply vaccination against avian influenza of susceptible birds in zoos.In accordance with its pandemic preparedness plan for influenza, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that in countries where cases of H7N7 are detected, surveillance and diagnosis of the avian H7N7 virus should be enhanced in humans and susceptible animals (including chickens, turkeys, and pigs). In addition, countries should initiate specific investigations to increase understanding of possible transmission patterns.WHO advises that persons in contact with H7N7-affected poultry flocks should be on guard for any signs and symptoms of respiratory disease. If symptoms arise, individuals should consult a doctor, who will then initiate laboratory testing and reporting to health officials.WHO emphasizes that these heightened surveillance measures will help in the timely detection of any further transmission of H7N7 to humans and in the prevention of its possible spread.The WHO Global Influenza Surveillance Network is currently assembling a test kit for H7N7 that will be ready for use in 3 weeks. As a precautionary measure, the network is also working on the development of a vaccine for H7N7.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02)  20030429.1061Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian Influenza - Belgium (07) 20030420.0971Avian influenza - Belgium (08) 20030423.0990Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE 20030428.1040Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (11) 20030423.0991Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (12) 20030425.1011Influenza, avian - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination      20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (02) 20030501.1087]...................mpp/arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. Archive Number20030502.1099
Published Date02-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (03)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS: VACCINATION (03)********************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Fri, 2 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Extracts from a letter VVA. 2003/1391 from the Minister of Agriculture to the Chair, Dutch Parliament, 29 Apr 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03060.htm>Vaccination-----------In response to a parliamentary question of 24 Apr 2003, I have checked the anticipated consequences of protective vaccination -- if performed as in Italy during the AI crisis there in 1999 -- upon the export of table eggs and poultry meat. It appears that the sale and distribution of eggs produced within the vaccination zone was allowed only inside Italy. Poultry meat from the vaccination zone had to be specifically marked, identified as fit for the national market only.In view of my previous information about the drawbacks of vaccination in AI-affected zones [see comment], vaccination can be used only as a preventive measure. Since export of table eggs and poultry meat from vaccinated AI-free zones will not be allowed, such a protective vaccination is presently not an option.I have informed you already about my inquiry into the future possibility of emergency vaccination as a control measure and preventive vaccination in repopulated holdings. Results of the said inquiry are expected during the second half of May, to be discussed with the European Commission and to be reported to you."Hobby (pet) avian holdings" have been found to be infected quite regularly [during this outbreak] and are not to be neglected as a factor in the persistence and spread of the virus. The relevant owner-organizations have suggested eliminating this factor by vaccinating the hobby (pet) poultry.The European Commission has agreed recently to the vaccination of AI-susceptible birds in zoos. Based upon the Ministerial Decree, such vaccinations are allowed, provided some conditions are fulfilled: data on the  vaccinated birds should be maintained for 10 years following the vaccination; results of their serological tests should be kept for 10 years; movement to other zoos is allowed only if officially supervised; and no products derived from such birds are allowed in the food chain.Though their representatives express readiness to comply with all measures, the observance of the Commission's vaccination requirements by thousands of owners of hobby (pet) avians -- whether organized or not -- does not seem feasible.Because no separate status for pet avian holdings is provided in the EU's decision on vaccination, and without the mechanisms to assure/enforce the compliance of the pet animal owners to fulfill the zoo-related requirements, I regard discussing their vaccination with the Commission as untimely.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[In his previous letter, 23 Apr 2003, to the Parliament, Minister Veerman explained his reservations regarding emergency vaccination in the affected zone, namely: it takes 3 weeks for immunity to be established; vaccinations must be repeated to achieve immunity; and vaccination does not stop the spread of the virus. Moreover, the procedure is highly labor-intensive.See also his remarks regarding AI vaccination in his letters of 5 Mar and 7 Apr 2003 in 20030306.0552 and 20030408.0855, respectively.- Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Netherlands (19)  20030408.0855Avian influenza - Netherlands (17)  20030402.0809Avian influenza - Netherlands (08)  20030306.0552Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (02)  20030501.1087Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination  20030428.1047]..............arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - BELGIUM, NETHERLANDS (04)*******************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Sat, 3 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Agrarisch dagblad, 2 May 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited] <http://www.agrarischdagblad.nl/pages/index.asp>AID in search of hidden poultry in the Gelders Valley---------------------------------------------------On Sat 3 May 2003 the General Inspection Service (AID) [in the Ministry of Agriculture] begins a search of "forbidden" pet avians in the Gelders valley. AID agents are visiting addresses suspected of keeping unregistered pet avians.The owners of pet avians were obliged to report their birds to the ministry of agriculture for registration by Fri, 2 May 2003. All pet animals within the [HPAI-infected] Gelders Valley are to be culled. This may seriously affect many who maintain pet chickens, swans, ducks, and other poultry. Some of them have filed a lawsuit against Minister Veerman [Agriculture] demanding that their animals be vaccinated rather than killed. Vaccination is not considered an option in Veerman's HPAI eradication policy.******[2]Date: Sat, 3 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature Management and Fisheries - fowl-plague update, 2 May 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod. AS, edited]<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/dossiers/vogelpest/>Situation 2 May - infections and suspicions--------------------------------------------There are now 12 holdings "seriously suspected" of being infected with fowl plague [highly pathogenic avian influenza -- HPAI], 5 of which consist of pet avians.  249 "definitely infected" holdings have been recorded since the start of the epizootic, including 20 holdings of pet avians.So far, 23.6 million AI-susceptible animals have been killed.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Since the Ministry's previous update, 29 Apr 2003 (see 20030429.1061), 3 new infected holdings have been recorded in the Netherlands and 2.6 million additional avians culled.The vaccination issue is expected to be discussed by the Standing Veterinary Committee of the EU in Brussels during a meeting convened at the request of the Dutch authorities, planned for Tue 6 May, 2003.As reported in the EU's Chronology of Avian Influenza, updated 30 Apr 2003, a total of 8 confirmed outbreaks have been reported in Belgium (4 in the province of Limburg and 4 in the province of Antwerpen). 1.4 million poultry have been culled in Belgium as of that date.<http://europa.eu.int/comm/food/fs/ah_pcad/ah_pcad_77_en.pdf>According to the Belgian press (De Gentenaar, De Standaard, Gazet van Antwerpen) of 3 May 2003, no new poultry cases have been reported there during the last week. Reportedly, the preventive culling in 57 holdings is to be accomplished by Tue 6 May 2003; 45 of them have already been depopulated. 3 poultry owners have begun legal proceedings against the planned preventive culling of their 117 000 animals. The matter is to be heard in court on Mon 5 May 2003. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands  20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02)  20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03)  20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccinatio...  20030501.1087Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination  20030428.1047]....................arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Published Date03-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO> SARS - worldwide (90): background
SARS - WORLDWIDE (90): BACKGROUND*********************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 3 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: NY Times 4 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/04/health/04WHO.html>Health Agency Took Swift Action Against SARS-----------------It took until mid-March [2003] -- nearly 4 months after the first outbreak -- for the world to learn of SARS. Yet a look back at the early days of the epidemic, and at the earliest warnings given to the World Health Organization [WHO], leaves little doubt that the agency acted as swiftly as it could.Some opportunities were missed along the way, and the health agency was led astray by assumptions that later proved wrong. But public health experts say the agency's investigators are only as powerful as the information they have to work with. And from the start, they were frustrated by the lack of official candor in China, where severe acute respiratory syndrome first erupted last November [2002]."WHO did a fantastic job," said Dr. Jack Woodall, the moderator of ProMED, the Federation of American Scientists' [FAS] Program for Monitoring Emerging Diseases [formerly of the FAS, since 1999 a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases - Mod.MPP], which as early as 10 Feb 2003 posted an alert on its Web site about a mysterious outbreak in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou. "They acted marvelously and exemplarily, as fast as they could. But it dragged on and on because China wouldn't cooperate. The World Health Organization isn't the world health police," he continued. "It's a club, like a club in Boston where everyone's a member and they slap each other on the back. Every member's a sovereign country, and if they don't want to report something, they don't."Dr. Barry R. Bloom, dean of the Harvard School of Public Health, said the global alert issued by the health agency on 12 Mar 2003 was "enormously courageous.  They took an enormous risk," he said. "If you ask 'What risk?' I remind you of swine flu."  In 1976, a single death in New Jersey from what was feared to be a genetic echo of the killer swine flu of 1918 engendered a panicky rush for a vaccine. The disease disappeared after infecting only 500 people, the vaccine was abandoned after 32 deaths from side effects, and the director of the federal Centers for Disease Control was dismissed.The Outbreak Center, on the fourth floor of Building L of the WHO campus [in Geneva], began officially querying China about its mysterious epidemic on 10 Feb 2003. As Chinese officials have since acknowledged, the response was a mix of inept diagnoses, outright lies and, finally, stonewalling.  Over the next 2 weeks, Chinese officials said that the outbreak had killed only 5 people and that it had been snuffed out in Guangdong Province, where Guangzhou is. They then said it had been caused by a mycoplasma, then by chlamydia. They then stopped responding and forbade doctors to do so. It was not until 20 Apr 2003 -- when China's health minister was dismissed -- that the epidemic's true scope began to emerge.By 12 Feb 2003, frustrated flu specialists in Hong Kong working with WHO quietly carried out a sort of medical commando raid, slipping into Guangdong hospitals to get tissue samples from dying patients. But because they were mistakenly looking for bird flu viruses, they missed the apparent cause of SARS, a coronavirus.And on 19 Feb 2003, the organization and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sent a joint investigative team to Beijing to find out what was going on in southern China. But Beijing health officials stalled them until they gave up. Permission to visit Guangdong was not given until 2 Apr 2003.There were 2 unlucky misses very early in the epidemic. On 20 Nov 2002, at what is assumed to be the very beginning of the outbreak, a WHO flu specialist who was in Beijing for a vaccine conference heard of a spate of unusual deaths among health care workers in Guangdong, which he now suspects included SARS cases. He requested tissue samples, but the ones he received contained only common flu strains. And on 27 Nov 2002, a report of a "flu outbreak" closing schools and factories was picked up by a Canadian Health Ministry computer [GPHIN - Global Public Health Intelligence Network] that sifts news reports for the WHO, but the report was never translated from the Chinese.More important, investigators mistakenly believed as late as mid-March [2003] that China was secretly and stoically fighting a new bird flu strain, possibly one as lethal as the swine strain, then called "Spanish flu," that killed more than 25 million people in 1918 and 1919.  That erroneous notion was reinforced on 19 Feb 2003, when 2 real cases of bird flu were diagnosed.  "In retrospect, this was a total coincidence," said Dr. Stephen M. Ostroff, deputy director of the CDC's National Center for Infectious Diseases. "But our feeling was that this was the unifying hypothesis behind the outbreaks."The crucial moment that sent the disease caroming around the world, probably a sneeze or cough in Hong Kong's Metropole Hotel, took place on 21 Feb 2003. But that would not be known for weeks, and even Canadian officials say the WHO reacted as quickly as it could."They were working with what they had," said Allison McGeer, a Toronto doctor who later fell ill herself fighting the epidemic, but recovered. "We knew from ProMED that something was going on. But having the announcement a few days earlier would still almost certainly have not been able to prevent initial spread. There were too many things we didn't know."An Illness EmergesOn 20 Nov 2002, Dr. Klaus Stoehr was in Beijing to discuss China's flu vaccination policy. He heads the WHO's flu program, for which 111 laboratories around the world annually scan 200 000 samples from [cases of] flu, looking for candidates for the next year's vaccine. As it happened, the first case of SARS had emerged that month in Guangdong, perhaps in the markets where all sorts of live animals, from chickens to cats, turtles, and badgers, are sold for food. At the meeting in Beijing, Guangdong's representative described a small flu outbreak that had killed several people in one hospital. "I think that was SARS," Dr. Stoehr said in hindsight.At the time, though, there was no particular reason to suspect that the outbreak was anything other than flu, Dr. Stoehr said. In epidemiological terms, "one or 3 or 5 deaths in a province of 55 million is nothing.  But," he said, "I thought, `Let's be on the safe side and get the virus.' "  Tests of samples from Guangdong at the CDC and a Japanese laboratory turned up routine flu strains, he said, so they were discarded.  "If the conference had been in December [2002], and there had been 100 deaths -- I don't know," he said, "but things might have been different."As early as January [2003], hospitals in small cities in Guangdong were telling the provincial health department about clusters of atypical pneumonia. Whether or not those numbers were sent on to Beijing, they were not being disclosed to WHO.  In December [2002] and January [2003], "it was dead silence from China," said Dr. Guenael Rodier, the WHO's chief of communicable disease surveillance. That, epidemiologists said, was not surprising."Numbers on health outbreaks are the most politicized numbers in the world," said Dr. Stephen O. Cunnion, a retired outbreak specialist from the Navy who posted the 10 Feb 2003 warning on ProMED after hearing from friends inside China. "From China, you can't even get an accurate count of how many people have been killed in an earthquake."On 5 Feb 2003, Dr. Stoehr said, panic grew when the Chinese subsidiary of the drug company Roche took out ads saying that its drug Tamiflu worked against bird flu. "That put in the minds of people that a bird flu epidemic had started," he said. The company apologized. No laboratory had by then found bird flu in humans, but southern China is primed to fear it. It lived through an outbreak in 1997 that infected only 18 people but killed 6 of them. The outbreak was stopped by the slaughter of 1.4 million birds. [The outbreak referred to here was confirmed in Hong Kong.  At the time there were rumors of a similar outbreak in southern mainland China, but these were not officially confirmed.  This outbreak was covered in depth on ProMED-mail at the time.  See references below for information on the thread. - Mod.MPP]Moreover, Dr. Stoehr said, in December [2002], an unusually powerful strain killed many wild birds in the Hong Kong Botanic Gardens. Mutating bird flus are an epidemiologist's nightmare. Though most strains that infect humans -- usually poultry farmers -- cause nothing worse than conjunctivitis, the 1997 strain, which the 18 victims all caught from birds, had the same mortality rate as smallpox.  A fatal strain that could be passed from human to human "is the sword of Damocles hanging above all of us," Dr. Rodier said. "The good news about SARS is that it's not a pandemic flu."On 11 Feb 2003, in response to an official WHO inquiry, Beijing tersely replied that an unidentified pneumonia in Guangdong had hospitalized 300 people and killed 5.  Guangdong's Communist Party secretary announced to the news media that "the illness has been effectively treated and controlled."  The next day, said a WHO official, a flu lab in Hong Kong affiliated with the agency was asked to get some samples clandestinely.  The lab's doctors "had friends and relatives working in hospitals in China, so they took the bus or train over and got samples from patients who died," the official said. But because they were looking for bird flu, they found nothing.On 14 Feb 2003, Li Liming, director of the Chinese Center for Disease Control [CDC], said that there had been no new cases since 10 Feb 2003 and that the situation was "under control and not as serious as the rumors say."  On 18 Feb 2003, the Chinese CDC announced that chlamydia bacteria had been found in 2 patients' lungs, and that it must have caused the outbreak.  "We didn't believe it," Dr. Ostroff of the C.D.C. in Atlanta said. Antibiotics also cure chlamydia.A Worrisome TurnOn 19 Feb 2003, the plot took a twist. A Hong Kong laboratory reported on a 33-year-old man and his 9-year-old son who had hurried to Fujian Province to see the man's dying 8-year-old daughter. The father died on his return on 17 Feb 2003; the son was sick. Both had the H5N1 strain of avian influenza. [see ProMED-mail references below on the coverage of the H5N1 human cases. At the time, we noted that the human cases of H5N1 had travelled through Guangdong province en route between Fujian and Hong Kong, and speculated on whether the outbreak in Guangdong might be due to H5N1 infections. - Mod.MPP]Dr. Stoehr said a Hong Kong colleague asked him, "Are you sitting down?" before giving him the news. This might be the nightmare bird flu -- a fatal strain that had passed from human to human. Ultimately, however, that one-family outbreak seems to have spontaneously died out. The cause of the daughter's death remains unknown.  Western officials, now very worried, tried another route. Dr. Keiji Fukuda of the USA CDC and Dr. Hitoshi Oshitani of the WHO were dispatched to Beijing and told to get to southern China.Prompted by the USA CDC, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, pressed China's deputy health minister, then visiting Washington, for permission for the team to visit. Permission was granted, and they arrived 23 Feb 2003.  "But it was the Asian cultural thing of not wanting to say no," said Dr. James W. LeDuc, director of the CDC's division of viral and rickettsial diseases. "Keiji got to Beijing and found out he didn't have an invitation."  The 2 men were left sitting in their hotel rooms for 2 weeks with nothing but routine briefings. In early March [2003], they left in frustration.Investigating outbreaks is always politically touchy, WHO officials said. As a United Nations agency, it has no power to order member states to cooperate.  "If I wasn't happy with the U.S. investigation of SARS cases in Pennsylvania, would I have the right to pop up in Philadelphia?" asked Dr. Michael J. Ryan, coordinator of the WHO's global alert system.Because it has too little money to field its own teams, it must send volunteers. The CDC in Atlanta is the biggest contributor but, WHO officials said, some countries are hardly more eager to see American health inspectors than Iraq was to see American arms inspectors.Facing the FactsWith China uncooperative, momentum stalled. Then on 21 Feb 2003, the disease escaped China when a 64-year-old Guangdong doctor checked into the Metropole in Hong Kong and infected guests who would spread it to Toronto, Hanoi, Singapore, and elsewhere in Hong Kong.The true nature of the disease -- that it was not a flu, but a pneumonia indifferent to antibiotics and antivirals -- was not understood until 11 Mar 2003, when 2 factors merged.  Dr. Carlo Urbani, a WHO clinician, chillingly detailed the outbreak he was fighting in Hanoi. An American businessman who had been in the Metropole had infected 22 hospital workers and 7 at his garment business in Hanoi. (Dr. Urbani himself soon died of the disease.) Tissue samples, flown to Bangkok on a plane chartered by the American Embassy because local airlines refused to carry them, showed no flu. Meanwhile, workers in a Hong Kong hospital were falling sick. A 26-year-old airport worker who had also been in the Metropole had been put on a jet nebulizer to clear his lungs and had infected 112 others. A Hong Kong laboratory found no flu in them.On 12 Mar 2003, the WHO issued a global health alert as a routine press release. With war in Iraq looming, it got relatively little attention. 3 more events prompted its much more emphatic 15 Mar 2003 alert.  The Canadian authorities reading the first announcement recognized that the pneumonias in one Toronto family fit the pattern. The authorities in Singapore said a hospitalized flight attendant who had stayed at the Metropole also did. And then, at 2:30 AM on 15 Mar 2003, Dr. Ryan was awakened by Singaporean officials warning him that a doctor who had treated pneumonia patients there had just left a conference in New York, told relatives he was feeling sick, and boarded a plane home with a stopover somewhere in Europe.  Dr. Ryan spent the next 4 hours frantically hunting down the plane and getting the doctor safely isolated in Frankfurt. That incident galvanized WHO officials into issuing a much more urgent and detailed alert.They also picked a name.  "We have to brand this," said Dr. David L. Heymann, the WHO's chief of infectious diseases. After tries like Atypical Pneumonia Without Diagnosis, they settled on a pronounceable acronym.   Asked if he thought an earlier alert could have saved any lives, Denis G. Aitken, an aide to the WHO's director general, the senior official on hand that day, said he doubted it, noting that the 4 new outbreaks were well under way by early March 2003.  "If you lose sleep over that, you'll become petrified," he said. "You just have to face the facts."[Byline: Donald G. McNeil, Jr. with Lawrence K. Altman]-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This is an interesting review of the background leading up to the recognition of SARS and the confounding factors early on, related to incomplete reporting and simultaneous events such as the H5N1 outbreak in the avian population with 2 confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection. - Mod.MPP][see also:SARS - worldwide (88): cases  20030502.1104SARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics  20030502.1103SARS - worldwide (86): cases  20030502.1100SARS - worldwide (85): clinical aspects  20030501.1094SARS - worldwide (83): cases  20030430.1082SARS - worldwide (80): cases  20030429.1055SARS - worldwide (79): clinical aspects  20030429.1054SARS - worldwide (78): diagnostic testing  20030429.1053SARS - worldwide (77): cases  20030428.1048SARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview  20030411.0878SARS - worldwide (41):overview  20030411.0876SARS - worldwide (38): etiology  20030410.0869SARS - Worldwide (34): etiology  20030408.0857SARS - worldwide (13): etiology  20030327.0758SARS - SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Netherlands (22): pig involvement
AVIAN INFLUENZA - NETHERLANDS (22): PIG INVOLVEMENT****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Tue, 6 Apr 2003From: Jan Braakman <JanBraakman@cs.com>Re: Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Removal of pigs from HPAI-affected farms-------------------------------------------------The moderator's comment to the said posting included the following statement: "Obviously, the recent death of a veterinarian involved in the HPAI [highly pathogenic avian influenza] control activities, has triggered the final decision to cull pigs on infected mixed farms".This conclusion seems to have been based upon the 19 Apr 2003 letter of the Secretary of Health, as cited in the said posting; she wrote: "Following the advice of OMT [Outbreak Management Team Influenza] and BAO [Board of administrators] and after consultation with NLV [Ministry of Agriculture], it has been decided to remove pigs from the relevant farms".However, the Ministry of Health's interpretation of "removal" is not culling; in fact, and as reported in the press, the pigs from 4 of the 5 affected farms (where pigs were found seropositive) were taken, under control, to a slaughterhouse for human consumption. The pigs on the 5th farm remained there, "for scientific reasons".The persons involved in the transport and slaughter of the pigs had to take antiviral medication.To conclude: there is no culling of pigs at infected farms; only poultry is culled. This information is based upon data provided by the Ministers to the Parliament and upon media reports.--Jan Braakman<JanBraakman@cs.com>[Jan Braakman's update is much appreciated. There seems to be a discrepancy between the handling of seropositive pigs (in mixed, infected farms) slaughtered for human consumption, compared to avians, which are destroyed.The Dutch Food and Non-Food Authority (VWA) in the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sports (VWS), forwarded on 15 Apr 2003 several questions to the OMT for their investigation and subsequent advice (see 20030418.0950). The results of the required investigations were expected to help the authorities in deciding upon their public-health-related policy regarding pigs in infected (mixed) farms.A letter of 29 Apr 2003 from the Minister of Agriculture to the Parliament included the paragraph "Results of follow-up investigations on AI in pigs". Minister Veerman wrote [translated]: "Investigations in the mixed infected farms have not indicated that the virus is spreading or had spread at a considerable rate among pigs. Testing of pigs in mixed farms where preventive culling [of poultry] had been carried out, and in farms exclusively raising pigs (totalling 15 farms), have shown non-specific positive reactions in 1.1 percent of the [tested] pigs......  [However], it could be concluded that the test results from uninfected farms are almost certainly not an outcome of exposure to the H7N7 virus but are instead related to non-specific reactions to the test used".<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03141.htm>ProMED-mail will be pleased to disseminate detailed, first-hand results of these and additional investigations, if/when available. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950]....................arn/pg*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030509.1150
Published Date09-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, Germany - suspected
AVIAN INFLUENZA, GERMANY - SUSPECTED************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Fri, 9 Apr 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: AP via The Guardian, 9 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://www.guardian.co.uk/worldlatest/story/0,1280,-2655845,00.html>Bird Flu Case Suspected at German Farm---------------------------------------BERLIN: A farm near Germany's border with the Netherlands was sealed off Friday and 32 000 chickens were ordered slaughtered after a suspected case of bird flu was reported.Bird flu, or avian influenza, is usually harmless to humans but can devastate stocks of domesticated birds. Millions of chickens have beenslaughtered on farms in the eastern Netherlands to prevent the disease from spreading since an outbreak there in late February. Belgium also has been affected, while Germany has seen no confirmed cases.An exclusion zone was set up in a half-mile radius around the farm near the western town of Viersen where the suspected case was reported. A preliminary test for bird flu was positive, but full results won't be available until next week."We're taking this suspicion very seriously," Viersen council member Juergen Karsten told Germany's ARD television. The farm's remaining birds were to be slaughtered as a precautionary measure Friday.The outbreak in the Netherlands is believed to have been caused by contact between wild ducks and farm poultry.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to today's update of the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture (9 Apr 2003), there are presently 11 "highly suspected" holdings in the Netherlands, of which 5 are composed of pet-avians. 250 holdings have been found, so far, definitely infected, of which 20 were pet-avians holdings. The total number of culled birds has reached 25.6 million. -Mod. AS].[see also:Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement  20030418.0950Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands 20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02) 20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03) 20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04) 20030503.1110]-----------------------------arn/dk*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030510.1160
Published Date10-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Germany (02): suspected,OIE
AVIAN INFLUENZA - GERMANY (02): SUSPECTED,OIE*********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 9 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Office International des Epizooties(OIE),  Alert Message [edited]<http://www.oie.int/Messages/030509DEU.htm>Avian Influenza Suspected in Germany(Date of previous outbreak reported to the OIE: 1979)Information received on 9 May 2003 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Head, Animal Health Division, Ministry of Consumer Protection, Food and Agriculture, Bonn:Report date: 9 May 2003.Description of affected population: on the evening of 8 May 2003 a suspected presence of avian influenza was officially recorded in a stock of 30 000 broilers in the municipality of Schwalmtal, district of Viersen, North Rhine-Westphalia. The reason for introduction is not known. Some animals showed clinical signs.Diagnosis: A first PCR was positive. Further tests will be carried out in the Federal Research Centre for Virus Diseases of Animals, Riems (National Reference Laboratory for this disease).Emergency measures:- Absolute standstill with immediate effect on all transports of live poultry and hatching eggs, on events involving poultry as well as on transports and the application of poultry slurry [as fertilizer] in the entire Land (federal state) of North Rhine-Westphalia.- Establishment of an isolation zone of 10 km.- Within a radius of 3 km, stocks of poultry are being destroyed and safely disposed of.- No table eggs may be transferred out of the restricted area.- The ban on free-range poultry production, which had been in place in this region for some time, has been prolonged.Animal Health Information DepartmentOffice international des epizooties (OIE)<information.dept@oie.int>--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Let's hope that quick action will limit spread.  However, the epidemic in both Belgium and the Netherlands has not yielded to control measures easily, so there is reason for some caution in predicting the outcome of  this new outbreak. - Mod PC][see also:Avian influenza, Germany - suspected      20030509.1150Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE       20030428.1040Avian influenza - Belgium (08)            20030423.0990Avian Influenza - Belgium (07)            20030420.0971Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946Avian influenza - Belgium (04): not, OIE  20030320.0694Avian influenza - Belgium (03): suspected (OIE) 20030318.0671Avian influenza - Belgium (02): suspected 20030313.0614Avian influenza - Belgium: suspected      20030312.0610Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02) 20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03) 20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04) 20030503.1110]......pc/pg/dk*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Published Date12-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Influenza H5N1, avian - China: suspected
INFLUENZA H5N1, AVIAN - CHINA: SUSPECTED********************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Mon, 12 May 2003From: Dick Hamilton  <rihamilto@shaw.ca>Source: Reuters via a@ Worldwide, 12 May 2003 [edited]Japan bans imports of Chinese poultry products----------------------------------------------The Japanese government said on Monday it had temporarily banned imports ofpoultry products from China after its quarantine office detected the birdflu virus in imported Chinese duck products.  The Agriculture Ministry saidin a statement that the tests on duck products from China had discoveredthe H5N1 bird flu virus.To prevent the virus from entering Japan, the ministry had imposed animport ban on all poultry products from China, the statement said.China is one of the top broiler exporters to Japan.In calendar year 2002, Japan's broiler imports totalled 524 000 tonnes,including 183 000 tonnes from Thailand, 168 000 tonnes from Brazil, 119 000tonnes from China, and the remainder mostly from the United States.A similar ban by Japan in 2001 that lasted for 2 months caused tight supplyon the domestic market, especially for frozen broilers, and contributed torising trade tensions between the Asian neighbours.The ban could also push broiler prices up in Thailand, Brazil and theUnited States, traders said.An outbreak of highly infectious bird flu in the Netherlands has promptedthe slaughter of millions of poultry, and the disease has spread to otherEuropean nations [Belgium and Germany].There are concerns that the disease could mix with human flu, producing astrain against which humans have no resistance.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[While veterinary authorities may limit or ban the importation ofpotentially HPAI-infected products from infected or suspected countries,testing for the presence of the virus in imported duck products is notknown to be common; rather, it is an exception. Could the said informationbe confirmed? And, if affirmative, what technique has been applied?Japan's alleged caution can be understood in view of unofficial informationon the incidence of avian influenza H5N1 virus in (mainland) Chinesepoultry, demonstrated by the recording, in February 2003, of cases in humansupon their return from mainland China to Hong Kong. Though an OIE membercountry, China's information on reportable epizootics in herterritories is less than satisfactory. China's annual reports to the OIEshow no data on HPAI -- a list A disease -- in 1996, 1997, or 1998 -- butsee 1998 refs. below. The disease was reported absent in 1999, 2000, and2001. Data on China's animal health situation during 2002 might becomeavailable during the 71st General Session of the OIE InternationalCommittee, due in Paris on 18-23 May 2003. - Mod.AS][see also:Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong)      20030219.0428Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030220.0441Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030224.0474Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (04) 20030227.0491Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.05001998----Influenza H5N1, avian - China      19980108.0055Influenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130Influenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142Influenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156]...................arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed
  AVIAN INFLUENZA - GERMANY: CONFIRMED************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Tue, 13 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Reuters via a@ Worldwide, 13 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.agriculture.com/worldwide/IDS/2003-05-13T070957Z_01_L13581531_RTRIDST_0_FOOD-POULTRY-GERMANY-URGENT.html>Germany confirms first case of bird flu---------------------------------------German authorities confirmed on Tuesday the nation's first case of the highly infectious bird flu in the western state of North Rhine-Westphalia.German authorities over the weekend ordered the precautionary slaughter of around 81 000 hens after the case was reported on Fri, 9 May 2003 at a farm in Viersen. "We have confirmed the presence of the bird flu virus," a spokeswoman for the government virology agency told Reuters.Some 25 million birds have been slaughtered in The Netherlands since the disease was confirmed there in early March 2003.  It has recently been found in Belgium, and a spread to Germany had been feared, since it was found on a Dutch farm only 1.5 kilometres from the German border.******[2]Date: Tue, 13 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Agrarisch Dagblad, 13 May 2003 [translated from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]<http://www.agrarischdagblad.nl/pages/index.asp>German state-secretary wants to vaccinate as AI spreads-------------------------------------------------The German State Secretary for Agriculture, Muller, wants to vaccinate animals in Germany to control the virus in case the disease spreads in Germany.  Muller is to present his plans to the national crisis team during its meeting on Tue, 13 May 2003.Muller's vaccination strategy is a shift from his colleagues' non-vaccination policy in The Netherlands and Belgium.  He plans to vaccinate, "corridor-wise", poultry within densely animal-populated  regions, in order to minimize disease pressure [preventing infection in other species, such as pigs? - Mod.AS].  He is aware of the fact that preventive vaccination cannot stop the further spread of the virus completely [see "vaccination" in the letter from the Minister of Agriculture to the Speaker of the Dutch Parliament, article 2 in 20030408.0855].Birds in zoos  and poultry of rare breeds are also to be vaccinated, according to Muller.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza, Germany - suspected         20030509.1150Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02)  20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03)  20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04)  20030503.1110Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination       20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (03)  20030502.1099Avian influenza - Netherlands (08)  20030306.0552]Avian influenza - Netherlands (09)  20030307.0563Avian influenza - Netherlands (19)  20030408.0855]....................mhj/tg/arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed, OIE 
AVIAN INFLUENZA - GERMANY: CONFIRMED, OIE************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date:  13 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Office International des Epizooties (OIE), Alert Message [edited]<http://www.oie.int/Messages/030513DEU.htm>Confirmation of diagnosis of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Germany-----------Information received on 13 May 2003 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Head, Animal Health Division, Ministry of Consumer Protection, Food and Agriculture, Bonn:Date of previous report: alert message dated 9 May 2003.Report date: 13 May 2003.In accordance with the laboratory results of the Federal Research Centre for Virus Diseases of Animals, Riems, highly pathogenic avian influenza was confirmed in Germany.The sequencing of a fragment of the gene region, coding for haemagglutinin, showed a sequence of amino acids at the cleavage site that corresponds to avian influenza virus subtype H7. This sequence section corresponds to the current virus of the disease in the Netherlands.Animal Health Information DepartmentOffice international des epizooties (OIE)<information.dept@oie.int>--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed  20030513.1184Avian influenza - Germany (02): suspected, OIE    20030510.1160Avian influenza - Germany: suspected      20030509.1150Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE 20030428.1040Avian influenza - Belgium (08) 20030423.0990Avian Influenza - Belgium (07) 20030420.0971Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946Avian influenza - Belgium (04): not, OIE 20030320.0694Avian influenza - Belgium (03): suspected (OIE) 20030318.0671Avian influenza - Belgium (02): suspected 20030313.0614Avian influenza - Belgium: suspected      20030312.0610Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02) 20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03) 20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04) 20030503.1110].......................................pc/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Published Date13-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Europe
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE***********************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Mon, 12 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Pighealth.com, 12 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.pighealth.com/influenza2.htm>12 May 2003 - EU Avian Influenza Virus Epidemic Update---------------------------------------------------Germany---------4000 birds now preventively destroyed. Minister Barbel Hohn, from the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia, is requesting EU permission for vaccination of zoo animals. No new suspected cases have been found so far.Belgium:-------2.77 million birds have now been destroyed on 118 farms. Still only 8 outbreaks, affecting 2 regions in the country.Agence France Presse report that Pascal Houbaert, spokesman for the AFSCA food safety agency, said on 11 May 2003 that Belgian authorities preventively killed tens of thousands of poultry over the weekend after authorities identified 10 farms to which the infection may have spread from Germany.  The suspect Belgian farms include 4 in the French-speaking Wallonia region in the south of Belgium.  Previous cases were in the North of Belgium.Netherlands: (situation on 9 May 2003)---------------A total of 26 million animals (mostly birds) destroyed so far; 11 suspected new cases (the number is gradually declining); 250 confirmed cases so far. To prevent the virus returning to the Netherlands from Germany, imports of live poultry from Germany to the Netherlands are now prohibited. As a result of the complete stand-still during the first 3 weeks of the outbreak in the Netherlands, there are no longer any broilers available for slaughter, and there will be almost no fresh poultry meat coming onto the Dutch market. One of the biggest Dutch poultry processors (Storteboom-group) is reported to be in financial difficulties and has ceased all activities until further instructions. --ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture's update of 13 May 2003, a total of 252 holdings have been confirmed definitely infected; 22 were pet-avian, non-commercial holdings.  There are presently 5 "seriously suspected" holdings, of which 2 are pet-animal holdings. The total number of culled "AI-susceptible" animals to date is 25.6 million. - Mod.AS].[see also:Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed, OIE 20030513.1185Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed          20030513.1184Avian influenza - Germany: suspected           20030509.1150Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02) 20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03) 20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04) 20030503.1110Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination      20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (03) 20030502.1099Avian influenza - Netherlands (08) 20030306.0552Avian influenza - Netherlands (09) 20030307.0563Avian influenza - Netherlands (19) 20030408.0855]....................mhj/tg/arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed.
