Archive Number20030514.1196
Published Date14-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Influenza H5N1, avian - China: suspected (02)
INFLUENZA H5N1, AVIAN - CHINA: SUSPECTED (02)*********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Tue 13 May 2003From: David Suarez <dsuarez@seprl.usda.gov>[Re: Influenza H5N1, avian - China: suspected 20030512.1179The following reference has been gratefully received following a request in the above posting. - Mod.AS].Characterization of a highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza A virus isolated from duck meat.  J Virol 2002 Jun;76(12):6344-55. Tumpey TM, Suarez DL, Perkins LE, Senne DA, Lee JG, Lee YJ, Mo IP, Sung HW, Swayne DE.Abstract:Since the 1997 H5N1 influenza virus outbreak in humans and poultry in Hong Kong, the emergence of closely related viruses in poultry has raised concerns that additional zoonotic transmissions of influenza viruses from poultry to humans may occur. In May 2001, an avian H5N1 influenza A virus was isolated from duck meat that had been imported to South Korea from China. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of A/Duck/Anyang/AVL-1/01 showed that the virus clustered with the H5  Goose/Guandong/1/96 lineage and 1997 Hong Kong human isolates and possessed an HA cleavage site sequence identical to these isolates. Following intravenous or intranasal inoculation, this virus was highly pathogenic and replicated to high titers in chickens. The pathogenesis of DK/Anyang/AVL-1/01 virus in Pekin ducks was further characterized and compared with a recent H5N1 isolate, A/Chicken/Hong Kong/317.5/01, and an H5N1 1997 chicken isolate, A/Chicken/Hong Kong/220/97. Although no clinical signs of disease were observed in H5N1 virus-inoculated ducks, infectious virus could be detected in lung tissue, cloacal, and oropharyngeal swabs.The DK/Anyang/AVL-1/01 virus was unique among the H5N1 isolates in that infectious virus and viral antigen could also be detected in muscle and brain tissue of ducks. The pathogenesis of DK/Anyang/AVL-1/01 virus was characterized in BALB/c mice and compared with the other H5N1 isolates. All viruses replicated in mice, but in contrast to the highly lethal CK/HK/220/97 virus, DK/Anyang/AVL-1/01 and CK/HK/317.5/01 viruses remained localized to the respiratory tract. DK/Anyang/AVL-1/01 virus caused weight loss and resulted in 22 to 33 percent mortality, whereas CK/HK/317.5/01-infected mice exhibited no morbidity or mortality. The isolation of a highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus from poultry indicates that such viruses are still circulating in China and may present a risk for transmission of the virus to humans.--David L. SuarezSoutheast Poultry Research LaboratoryU.S. Department of AgricultureAgricultural Research ServiceAthens, Georgia 30605, USA<dsuarez@seprl.usda.gov>[We are very grateful to Dr Suarez for forwarding the said abstract; the full text of the article is available at:<http://jvi.asm.org/cgi/content/full/76/12/6344?view=full&pmid=12021367Text>The authors indicated that in South Korea, consignments of imported poultry meat from China have been quarantined since HPAI virus was isolated in Hong Kong in May 2001. During this quarantine, an influenza A virus was isolated from imported Cherry Valley Pekin duck (_Anas platyrhynchos_) meat, imported from a food factory in Shanghai which processed ducks from regional farms. Complying with procedures required by the South Korean regulation, 5 samples of meat (200 to 500 g) were taken from each shipment container of 7500 duck carcasses. Random sampling was performed on breast, wing, thigh, and back of whole duck carcasses, eventually -- and in cooperation with the Southeast Poultry Research Laboratory -- leading to the described significant results and conclusions, underlining the need for "increased surveillance of poultry meat, especially in ducks."It may be assumed that the Japanese procedures leading to the detection of H5N1 in duck products imported from China might have been in line with the described South Korean ones.  Confirmation or otherwise from our Japanese colleagues will be appreciated. - Mod.AS][see also:Influenza H5N1, avian - China: suspected      20030512.1179Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong)      20030219.0428Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030220.0441Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030224.0474Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (04) 20030227.0491Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.05001998----Influenza H5N1, avian - China      19980108.0055Influenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130Influenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142Influenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156].................................arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030515.1213
Published Date15-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Europe (02)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (02)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>In this update:[1] Advice for poultry producers - UK[2] Situation - Germany[3] Situation - Netherlands[4] EU experts on AI vaccines and vaccination******[1]Date: Thu 15 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Farming Life, 14 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.farminglife.com/fl2/page.cfm?objectid=12955623&method=full&siteid=51658&headline=Advice%20for%20Poultry%20Producers>Advice for Poultry Producers----------------------------The United Kingdom's Chief Veterinary Officer, Jim Scudamore, has advisedpoultry producers to continue to take biosecurity precautions to minimisethe introduction of avian influenza into their flocks.Mr Scudamore said that while the overall risk of the highly pathogenicstrain of avian influenza being introduced from the Netherlands and Belgiumwas judged to be low, he urged producers to follow the Biosecurity Code forpoultry owners. Mr Scudamore praised the industry for its good biosecurity,but said it was important that producers did not relax."Highly pathogenic avian influenza is a contagious notifiable disease whichcan cause high mortality in domestic poultry. Should an outbreak of avianinfluenza occur, it would most likely be as a result of contact with wildbirds, in particular their faeces.  While wild birds are as susceptible asdomestic poultry to the disease, they could carry low-pathogenic strains ofthe virus which, if introduced into domestic poultry, could spread andmutate to the highly pathogenic form. Water fowl, especially ducks, pose apotentially greater risk in that they could carry high-pathogenic strainsof the virus without showing signs of disease.""There are a number of ways in which producers can help protect their birdsagainst infection with avian influenza viruses, such as avoidingcontaminating poultry houses with birds' faecal material on footwear,clothing, and equipment, cleansing and disinfecting clothing carefully, andcleaning up feed spillages quickly to avoid attracting wild birds andvermin.  Poultry keepers whose birds are close to standing water wherewater fowl congregate should be especially mindful of the potential risk,given that these birds could carry highly pathogenic strains of the virus,"he said.Mr Scudamore added it was vital that producers notify their vet immediatelyif they suspect disease or have sick birds on their holding. Early clinicalsigns of avian influenza include increased mortality, falling eggproduction, signs of respiratory disease, and a drop in food consumption.His comments follow preliminary results indicating the first case inGermany within the avian influenza protection zone covering theGerman/Dutch/Belgian borders.******[2]Date: Thu, 15 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Financial Times, 15 May 2003 [edited]<http://news.ft.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=FT.com/StoryFT/FullStory&c=StoryFT&cid=1051390035428&p=1012571727166>Fowl pest outbreak alarms Germany---------------------------------Germany's agriculture committee meets in emergency session today [15 May2003] to discuss the country's first case of fowl pest in 24 years. Thedisease, now raging in the Netherlands, has been detected at a farm inNorth Rhine-Westphalia. More than 80 000 chickens and hens have alreadybeen destroyed and the farm isolated.[Byline: Haig Simonian]******[3]Date: Thu, 15 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: NRC Handelsblad, 15 May 2003 [translated from Dutch and edited]<http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/artikel/1052976821354.html>Animal movement allowed in the Gelders Valley---------------------------------------------Table eggs and broilers may be transported again in the Gelders Valleyand  in the Meuse-Waal country [the HPAI-infected areas] as of thismorning. Trade and transportation are still bound by regulations. Thebroilers may be slaughtered only in a slaughterhouse in Cuijk, and the meatmay not be exported. The previous ban upon animal movements remainsunchanged in the province of Limburg [south Netherlands, bordering Belgiumand Germany].The Ministry of Agriculture has decided to soften the measures it hadpreviously taken, in view of the absence of new fowl-plague outbreaks forsome time. All poultry farms in the Gelders valley and the area ofBeneden-Leeuwen were depopulated a month ago; there are only a fewremaining poultry farms on the edges of that area. According to the farmersorganisation GLTO, some additional time is needed before fullrestoration of the industry's activities. On [some?] premises, somecontaminated manure is still present and should be removed.The Society for Animal Protection, together with the Dutch Association ofPet Animal Owners (NBvH), have delivered today a petition to the Ministerof Agriculture Veerman against the culling of pet chickens and other birds,accompanied by 10 000 signatures.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the daily Agrarisch Dagblad, 15 May 2003, the NBvH -- whichnumbers about 8000 members -- stated:  "The authorities put the interests ofa small group of exporters before the interests of hundreds of thousands ofanimal lovers."  They have urged all animal lovers in The Netherlands toboycott the bio-industry and the products of the relevant egg-producing andbreeding farms (which are to be repopulated, within the infected areas,after the culling of susceptible pet avians in the said areas).The list of AI-susceptible pet avians, according to the Dutch Ministry ofAgriculture, includes the following species: chickens, turkeys,guinea-fowl, quails, pheasants, partridges, peacocks, ducks, geese, swans,pigeons (only _Columbia livia_, excluding carrier-pigeons), ostriches,emus, and common rheas [South American birds, similar to but smaller thanthe ostrich]. - Mod.AS]******[4]Date: Thu, 15 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Report of the EU Scientific Committee on Animal Health and AnimalWelfare  "Diagnostic Techniques and Vaccines for Foot-and-Mouth Disease,Classical Swine Fever, Avian Influenza and some other important OIE List ADiseases", 150 pages; Adopted 24-25 Apr 2003 [edited]<http://europa.eu.int/comm/food/fs/sc/scah/out93_en.pdf>1. AI-related text from the executive Summary (page 112)---------------------------------------------------For AI there are licensed inactivated oil emulsion vaccines only foremergency vaccination available in the EU. The experience gathered duringthe Italian 1999-2001 low-pathogenic AI (LPAI) epidemics suggests that itmay be possible to use the heterologous vaccine approach effectively indifferentiating infected from vaccinated animals ("DIVA"), a vaccinationstrategy for the control of AI in poultry. Research is required in order todetermine the minimum antigen content of haemagglutinin antigen (HA)required in a vaccine for different avian species and to determine the timeinterval between vaccination and the development of protective immunity.Appropriate virus strains to be used in vaccines for AI should beidentified and vaccine banks established, while recombinant neuraminidaseproteins (N1-N9) are needed to differentiate antibodies induced by'vaccine' strains from antibodies against wild-type viruses.2. Types of vaccine (page 80)-----------------------------a. Inactivated homologous vaccinesThese vaccines were originally prepared as 'autogenous' vaccines, i.e,vaccines that contain the same AI strain as the one causing the diseaseoutbreak in the field. They contain an oil emulsion adjuvant. Thedisadvantage of this system is the difficulty of detecting infection in avaccinated population, since the antibody response after infection cannotbe differentiated from that after vaccination. This problem may be partlycompensated for by the use of unvaccinated sentinel birds in the poultryhouse. However, sentinel birds may be [difficult to distinguish from otherbirds], and there is a risk of substitution of birds.b. Inactivated heterologous vaccinesThis vaccine contains the same HA subtype as the field virus causing theoutbreak but has a heterologous NA. In the case of field exposure, clinicalprotection and reduction of viral shedding are ensured by the immunereaction induced by the homologous HA subtype, while the antibodies againstthe NA induced by the field virus can be used as a marker of naturalinfection.c. Live vaccinesDue to the possibility of virus mutation of H5 and H7 subtype viruses, nosuch vaccines are licensed for use in poultry.d. Recombinant vaccinesA recombinant fowlpox virus expressing the H5 antigen has been licensed inMexico and is currently being used there. Experimental data have also beenobtained for fowlpox virus recombinants expressing the H7 antigen.Experimental work has also been successfully undertaken on constructs usinginfectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV) as a vector. No such product hasbeen licensed in the EU.[For the relevant references, please refer to the full text in the originaldocument; see URL above].--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture's update, as of 15 May 2003there are 4  "seriously suspected" HPAI outbreaks, one of which is in petbirds. 252 definitely confirmed outbreaks have been recorded since thebeginning of the epizootic in the Netherlands, 22 of which were innon-commercial pet bird holdings.  25.6 million AI-susceptible animalshave been culled. It seems that the spread in Netherlands has beenhalted; no new cullings in commercial farms have been reported since 8 May2003.The effort of the Dutch authorities to cull susceptible pet birds, inspite of the resistance of owners and animal-protection groups, seems to bemotivated by the need to enable early repopulation of the poultry farms andexports without risking re-infection by carrier pets. Reportedly, 90percent of Dutch-produced eggs are exported. Courts in The Netherlands andBelgium have rejected lawsuits filed by owners of pet birds to prevent thecullings. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Europe                     20030513.1189Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (13)    20030501.1092Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03)  20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04)  20030503.1110Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (02)  20030501.1087Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (03)  20030502.1099Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination       20030428.1047Avian influenza, Germany - suspected         20030509.1150Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed         20030513.1184]...............arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. Published Date16-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Europe (03)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (03)*******************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>In this update:[1] EU commission's update[2] New suspected case in Germany******[1]Date: Fri, 16 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Just-food.com, 16 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.just-food.com/news_detail.asp?art=54119>EU: Commission issues update on avian influenza in Europe--------------------------------------------The EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health met thisweek to discuss again the avian influenza situation in the Netherlands,Belgium, and Germany.In the Netherlands, the existing restrictive measures adopted to preventthe spread of the disease and to eradicate it have been extended until 30May 2003. In Belgium, the restrictive measures will be limited to theprovinces of Antwerp and Limburg, from 27 May onwards. In Germany, themeasures adopted by the European Commission have been confirmed andextended until 30 May 2003, with some new [exceptions] for transportswithin Germany.The Netherlands-------------To date 252 outbreaks of avian influenza have been confirmed in theNetherlands, and another 6 holdings are suspected of having beencontaminated. In total, approximately 28 million birds have been culled.The last outbreak in a commercial poultry farm dates from 29 Apr 2003.The Committee today voted in favour of a Commission proposal to extenduntil 30 May 2003 the existing measures to prevent the spread of thedisease and to eradicate it. No live poultry, hatching eggs, or fresh,unprocessed poultry manure or litter may be exported to other Member Statesor third countries and, with some exceptions, no live poultry or hatchingeggs may be transported within the Netherlands. The exceptions apply tohatching eggs, day-old chicks, ready-to-lay pullets, and poultry forimmediate slaughter.Belgium--------8 outbreaks have been confirmed in Belgium since 16 Apr 2003. However, thelast outbreak dates from 28 Apr 2003, and no new suspicions have beenraised since. The poultry holdings in the established buffer zones havebeen depopulated, and restocking will start only after a waiting period. Intotal, about 3 million birds have been culled. The Committee concluded thatthe disease has been successfully eradicated.The Committee therefore agreed to limit the existing restrictive measuresto the provinces of Antwerp and Limburg from 27 May 2003 onwards, providedthat no new outbreaks are reported before that date. As a result, export oflive poultry and hatching eggs from the rest of Belgium can restart on thatdate. The restrictions in the 2 provinces apply until 30 May 2003.Germany--------A single outbreak of avian influenza has been reported on 9 May 2003 inNorth Rhine-Westphalia in Germany. The Committee today approved andextended until 30 May 2003 the measures adopted by the Commission on 12 May2003. However, the transport of poultry for immediate slaughter and day-oldchicks for breeding originating from an establishment situated east of theRhine in North Rhine-Westphalia to other parts of Germany can be authorisedunder strict conditions. Germany may also decide to apply vaccinationagainst avian influenza of susceptible birds in zoos and in recognisedcentres for endangered species in the area west of the Rhine of NorthRhine-Westphalia.The situation and measures with regard to avian influenza in theNetherlands, Belgium, and Germany will be reviewed at the next meeting ofthe Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health scheduled for 28May 2003.******[2]Date: Fri, 16 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: pighealth.com, 16 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.pighealth.com/influenza2.htm>New suspected outbreak in Germany - 16 May 2003--------------------------------------[There is a] new suspected outbreak of high-pathogenicitiy avian influenza(AI) in Kleve in the northwest of the state of North Rhine-Westphalia(NRW), close to the Dutch border. The poultry flock is very small -- only afew hundred birds.The origin of the virus infection is suspected to be via contact withanother farm. The EU has extended the ban on poultry exports from NRW foranother month.NRW has been given permission to vaccinate zoo birds.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza, Germany - suspected      20030509.1150Avian influenza - Germany (02): OIE       20030510.1160Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed      20030513.1184Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed, OIE      20030513.1185Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213]................tg/arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. AVIAN INFLUENZA - NETHERLANDS (23): OIE***************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat 17 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: OIE Disease Information, Vol. 16, No. 20, 16 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_19.HTM#Sec2>Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in The NetherlandsFollow-up report No. 11---------------------------------------------------Information received on 15 May 2003 from Dr Frederik H. Pluimers, ChiefVeterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature Management andFisheries, The Hague:End of previous report period: 8 May 2003 (see Disease Information, 16[19], 119, dated 9 May 2003). End of this report period: 15 May 2003.New outbreaks:Location/No. of outbreaks:province of North Brabant (Noord Brabant)/1province of Limburg/1Description of affected population in the new outbreaks: two small backyardflocks.Total number of animals in the new outbreaks:species/susceptible/cases/deaths/destroyed/slaughteredavi/37/.../.../37/0--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The existence of backyard flocks (the Dutch terminology may be translatedas  "avians kept by amateurs"), in which small numbers of AI-susceptiblebirds are maintained, is the remaining problem for the Dutch authorities intheir effort to eradicate HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza). -Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Netherlands (20): OIE 20030416.0929Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe (03) 20030516.1219]..............arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030520.1240
Published Date20-MAY-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Netherlands (24): pig involvement
AVIAN INFLUENZA - NETHERLANDS (24): PIG INVOLVEMENT****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Mon, 19 May 2003From: Willie Loeffen <Willie.Loeffen@wur.nl>Avian Influenza (H7N7) in Dutch pigs------------------------------------This is some information on the pig involvement during the avian influenza outbreak in the Netherlands:At the end of February 2003, a highly pathogenic avian influenza was introduced into Dutch poultry. The influenza virus involved turned out to be an H7N7. In early April a serological surveillance program was started to determine whether the virus was also infecting pigs. Infections of pigs may have consequences for both animal and human health.The first part of the surveillance consisted of 13 herds at risk (mixed herds with infected poultry, category 1).[Re categories 2 and 3, see further]. The poultry were culled 3-5 weeks before the pigs were sampled, leaving enough time for any serological responses [to be detected] in case pig infection had taken place. 8 of the [13] herds were sampled according to a representative sampling schedule, allowing for the detection of even small outbreaks (60-118 samples per herd). The 5 [remaining] smallest herds were sampled in their entirety, to allow detecting even very small outbreaks (62-376 samples per herd). The test used was a haemagglutination inhibition (HI) test, using the avian H7N7 as antigen. Sera were pre-treated with cholera toxin and chicken erythrocytes. Based on previous experience with HI tests in swine, a threshold value of [titre] 40 was chosen to determine whether samples were either positive or negative.The results of this first surveillance showed more than one high titer (>40) in 5 of these herds, indicating that the H7N7 virus had been introduced into the swine population. Prevalences in these herds (counting titers of 40 and higher) were 5.1 percent, 5.6 percent, 8.3 percent, 15.0 percent, and 26.0 percent, respectively.The 5 said mixed herds likely to be infected were resampled 11 days after their first sampling. All individual animals above 4 weeks of age were sampled and tested (173-713 per herd, total 2373 samples). Furthermore, 60 oropharyngeal swabs were taken in each herd for antigen detection by RT-PCR (both for influenza-A viruses in general and specific for H7).The results showed no significant increase in seroprevalence in these herds (now 2.5 percent, 7.7 percent, 6.9 percent, 14.0 percent, and 29.0 percent, respectively). In the first 3 herds the seropositives were found scattered across the farms, rarely more than one seropositive pig per pen. In the herd with the highest seroprevalence, these seropositives were correlated with feeding of broken eggs from infected poultry in 2 compartments. Paired blood samples from over 200 individual animals showed 5 conversions from positive to negative and 3 conversions from negative to positive. All other results [were shown] to be reproducible. In all cases the titres of these conversions were around the threshold value of 40, and test variation and non-specific responses were most likely the cause of these "conversions". Finally, all PCR-results on oropharyngeal swabs were negative.In addition, the surveillance was expanded to swine in mixed herds where poultry was preventively culled (category 2) and to exclusive-swine herds (no poultry at all - category 3). All these herds were located in the protection zones, within a 3-kilometer radius of an infected holding. Category 2 included 21 herds and Category 3 a total of 23 herds. In each herd, 60 samples were randomly taken, resulting in a total of 2640 blood samples.The test results showed an overall seroprevalence of 1.1 percent, with no significant difference between categories. Most of the titres found were at the threshold level of 40 and could well be explained by non-specific reactions. To determine whether this was truly possible, the need arose to test a negative [not-exposed] population to determine the test specificity based on the titre 40 threshold level. 969 blood samples from swine herds in the Northern parts of the Netherlands sampled prior to the introduction of H7N7 into the Netherlands were tested. Based on these samples, the specificity of the HI-test was determined at 97.4 percent. Then an additional 457 blood samples were taken on 5 herds from categories 2 and 3, with one or 2 titres >40. 2 percent of these samples were found positive, again with mainly low titres and within what could be expected, based on the specificity of the test.Following these results, it was decided that all category 1 herds (mixed herds with infected poultry) should be tested serologically according to the same representative sampling schedule used during the first part of the surveillance in pigs (60-217 samples per herd). 46 herds in this category have been identified and tested, including the first 13 "category 1" herds that had been tested during the first part of the surveillance. From these 46 herds, 13 herds had a non-significant [sic] number of seropositive pigs, indicating that they were likely infected. In one of these herds having a high seroprevalence (35 percent seropositive), oropharyngeal swabs for RT-PCR were taken from all 63 pigs present. In none of these swabs could antigen be detected.Our conclusions from these results, so far, are:1] Swine in mixed herds with infected poultry are at risk for introduction of the avian influenza, subtype H7N7.2] Swine in mixed herds with no infected poultry or swine in herds with no poultry at all are at no significant risk for introduction of the avian influenza, subtype H7N7.3] No evidence was found for (ongoing) transmission between pigs. Most of the infections seem to be transmitted from poultry to swine, either directly or indirectly.4] No evidence was found that the virus is able to remain for a long period in the swine herds after the removal of the source of infection, namely the infected poultry.5] It seems most likely that no residual avian influenza virus was present in any of the swine herds tested.--Willie Loeffen<willie.loeffen@wur.nl>Guus Koch <guus.koch@wur.nl>CIDC-LelystadThe Netherlands[We are very grateful to Drs Loeffen and Koch for their first-hand, authoritative information on the surveillance carried out by CIDC (Central Institute for Animal Disease Control, Lelystad). This information complements and clarifies the data derived from the Agriculture Minister's letter of 29 Apr 2003 to the Dutch Parliament, which was included in ref 20030507.1134. The said posting dealt with the slaughter for human consumption of pigs from "category 1" holdings.According to the update of the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, as of 19 May 2003 the total number of HPAI "definitely infected" (meaning that HPAI virus has been isolated and identified) holdings has reached 254, including 22 pet avian holdings. There are currently, 2 "seriously suspected" holdings (meaning positive RC-PCR, not yet finally confirmed by virus isolation). - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian influenza - Netherlands (22): pig involvement 20030507.1134Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (09): fatal case 20030419.0959Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967 ]...................................arn/pg/jw*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Germany (05): OIE
AVIAN INFLUENZA - GERMANY (05): OIE**********************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 24 May 2003From: ProMED-mail  <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Office International des Epizooties (OIE), Disease Information[edited]<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_18.HTM#Sec4>Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in GermanyFollow-up report No. 1------------------Information received on 22 May 2003 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Head,Animal Health Division, Ministry of Consumer Protection, Food andAgriculture, Bonn:End of previous report periods: 9 and 13 May 2003End of this report period: 22 May 2003.On 13 May 2003, a case of highly pathogenic avian influenza was detected ina flock of around 30 000 broilers in the municipality of Schwalmtal,district of Viersen, State of North Rhine-Westphalia. No further cases ofhighly pathogenic avian influenza have been detected in Germany.All other states are free from highly pathogenic avian influenza.Consequently, European Commission Decision 2003/358/EC of 16 May 2003(Official Journal No. L 123 p. 55) lays down restriction measures for NorthRhine-Westphalia only. These restriction measures currently apply until 30May 2003.The Ordinance on additional protective measures against highly pathogenicavian influenza of 16 May 2003 (Federal Gazette p. 10949) has incorporatedthe protective measures under Community law into German law. Moreover,additional protective measures have been taken throughout Germany as wellas in North Rhine-Westphalia:- Total standstill imposed on all transport of live poultry, hatching eggs,and poultry slurry.- The entire poultry flock affected by the disease, as well as the contactflocks, were destroyed immediately and safely disposed of after theofficial determination of disease suspicion (approximately 80 000 animals).- Within a radius of 3 km around the outbreak, all poultry flocks weredestroyed and safely disposed of within 48 hours after the suspectedpresence of avian influenza had been established.- Within a radius of 10 km, a protection zone was established, followed bya surveillance zone with a further radius of 10 km, with a total standstillon movements of live poultry.Measures currently in effect in Germany:-------------------------------- Neither live poultry (chickens, guinea fowl, turkeys, ducks, geese,pheasants, partridges, quails, and doves), hatching poultry eggs, noruntreated or non-heat-treated slurry or bedding material from poultryflocks in North Rhine-Westphalia Land may be transported to other regionsof Germany, other European Union Member States, or third countries.Exemptions apply to the region east of the river Rhine for slaughterpoultry and baby chicks, subject to official authorisation.- Fresh poultry meat from the protection zone established in NorthRhine-Westphalia may only be sold within Germany (with specific labelling)and must be produced, cut, transported, and stored separately.- Within North Rhine-Westphalia, all events involving poultry have beenbanned. A ban has been imposed on the free-range husbandry of poultry until9 June 2003 in the regions close to the border between Germany and TheNetherlands.- Table eggs may only be transported from the holdings with laying hens tothe point of packaging either in one-way packages or in containers thathave been cleaned and disinfected before and after use.- Slaughter poultry intended for immediate slaughter may only betransported in lorries and in boxes or cages cleaned and disinfected beforeand after use.- Baby chicks may only be transported in one-way packing material, which isto be destroyed after use.- In addition, the movement of people on poultry farms has been restrictedin North Rhine-Westphalia, and appropriate protective measures have beenadopted for people handling poultry.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Germany (04): confirmed, OIE      20030513.1185Avian influenza - Germany (03): confirmed      20030513.1184Avian influenza - Germany (02): suspected, OIE 20030510.1160Avian influenza - Germany: suspected      20030509.1150Avian influenza - Netherlands (24): pig involvement 20030520.1240Avian influenza - Europe (03) 20030516.1219Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE 20030428.1040Avian influenza - Belgium (0 20030423.0990Avian Influenza - Belgium (07) 20030420.0971Avian Influenza - Belgium (06): confirmed 20030419.0965Avian influenza - Belgium (05): suspected 20030417.0946Avian influenza - Belgium (04): not, OIE 20030320.0694Avian influenza - Belgium (03): suspected (OIE) 20030318.0671Avian influenza - Belgium (02): suspected 20030313.0614Avian influenza - Belgium: suspected      20030312.0610Avian influenza - Netherlands (21): pig involvement 20030418.0950Avian influenza - SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Europe (04)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (04)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Wed, 28 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: MeatNews.Com, 27 May 2003 [edited]<http://www.meatnews.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=PArticle&artNum=5472>Avian flu controls: Netherlands, Germany----------------------------------------Over the last week one more incidence of avian flu has been detected in the Netherlands.Dr Frederik H. Pluimers, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature Management and Fisheries in The Hague told the World Animal Health Organisation (OIE) that there has been one case in the province of Gelderland. The new outbreak was in a flock of layer hens, and all 5000 birds have been destroyed.Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Head, Animal Health Division, Ministry of Consumer Protection, Food and Agriculture in Bonn, Germany told the OIE that a case of highly pathogenic avian influenza was detected in a flock of around 30 000 broilers in the municipality of Schwalmtal, district of Viersen, in North Rhine-Westphalia. No further cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza have been detected in Germany.The European Commission Decision of 16 May 2003 lays down restriction measures for North Rhine-Westphalia only. These restriction measures currently apply until 30 May 2003.However, additional protective measures have been taken throughout Germany as well as in North Rhine-Westphalia. Measures taken in North Rhine-Westphalia include:- Total standstill imposed on all transport of live poultry, hatching eggs, and poultry slurry.- The entire poultry flock affected by the disease, as well as the contact flocks, were destroyed immediately and safely disposed of after the official determination of disease suspicion (approximately 80 000 animals).- Within a radius of 3 km around the outbreak, all poultry flocks were destroyed and safely disposed of within 48 hours after the suspected presence of avian influenza had been established.- Within a radius of 10 km, a protection zone was established, followed by a surveillance zone with a further radius of 10 km, with a total standstill on movements of live poultry.Measures currently in effect across Germany include:- Live poultry (chickens, guinea fowl, turkeys, ducks, geese, pheasants, partridges, quails, and doves), hatching poultry eggs, nor untreated or non heat-treated slurry or bedding material from poultry flocks in North Rhine-Westphalia Land may be dispatched to other regions of Germany, other European Union Member States, or third countries. Exemptions apply to the region east of the river Rhine for slaughter poultry and baby chicks, subject to official authorisation.- Fresh poultry meat from the protection zone established in North Rhine-Westphalia may be sold only within Germany (with specific labelling) and must be produced, cut, transported, and stored separately.- Within North Rhine-Westphalia, all events involving poultry have been banned. A ban has been imposed on the free-range husbandry of poultry until 9 Jun 2003 in the regions close to the border between Germany and The Netherlands.- Table eggs may only be transported from the holdings with laying hens to the point of packaging either in one-way packages or in containers that have been cleaned and disinfected before and after use.- Slaughter poultry intended for immediate slaughter may only be transported in lorries and in boxes or cages cleaned and disinfected before and after use.- Baby chicks may only be transported in one-way packing material, which is to be destroyed after use.- In addition, the movement of people on poultry farms has been restricted in North Rhine-Westphalia, and appropriate protective measures have been adopted for people handling poultry.******[2]Date: Wed, 28 May 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: AP via CNN.COM/WORLD, 27 May 2003 [edited]<http://edition.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/europe/05/27/eu.birdflu.ap/>Belgium winning bird flu battle-------------------------------European Union officials gave most Belgian poultry farms permission Tuesday to resume exports of live animals and hatching eggs that were imposed following outbreaks of avian influenza last month. The European Commission said farms everywhere in Belgium except the provinces of Antwerp and Limburg can resume exports. It credited the "rapid and effective action taken by the Belgium authorities allowed to control and limit the outbreaks."EU health officials on Wednesday were to review the situation and measures regarding the disease, also known as bird flu, in the 2 remaining Belgian provinces, as well as in the Netherlands and Germany's North Rhine-Westphalia state.Bird flu is usually harmless for humans but can devastate stocks of domesticated birds. The outbreak is believed to have been caused by contact between wild ducks and farm poultry in the Netherlands, and spread despite the culling of millions of chickens in affected areas.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the last update -- 27 May 2003 -- of the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, the number of "definitely infected" fowl holdings, since the start of the epizootic that began at the end of February 2003, is 255; there are currently no AI-suspected premises in the Netherlands. 22 of the 255 foci involved pet avians (the Dutch term is "hobbydieren"). For the Ministry's list of AI-susceptible pet avians, see "Situation - Netherlands" in Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213. According to the Dutch press, an unspecified number of AI-susceptible pet avians, kept by about 1100 owners in 9 municipalities in Limburg, were destroyed in mid-May 2003. The Ministry claimed that this step was necessary to enable repopulation of the commercial poultry farms, regaining the country's disease-free status and renewal of exports. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe (03) 20030516.1219Avian influenza - Netherlands: suspected      20030301.0503]...................arn/pg/mpp*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030604.1372
Published Date04-JUN-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Europe (05)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (05)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Wed, 4 Jun 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: De Volkskrant, 4 Jun 2003 [translated from Dutch and edited]<http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/1054616677695.html>End of the fowl plague outbreak in sight----------------------------------------The last outbreak of fowl plague [highly pathogenic avian influenza, HPAI], affecting a commercial poultry holding in Kelpen (Limburg), was confirmed on 23 May 2003. In a letter of Tue, 3 Jun 2003 by Minister of Agriculture Veerman to the Parliament, he described the improved situation while indicating that a new outbreak is still a possibility.<http://www.minlnv.nl/infomart/parlemnt/2003/par03173.htm>Veterinary experts regard the mean incubation period of HPAI in poultry to be 10 days. In view of the period elapsed since the last dates of suspected as well as confirmed outbreaks, the poultry sector can breathe a sigh of relief.Alertness, though, must be maintained since the virus can survive in litter and manure longer than a month. For this reason, Veerman wants all litter and manure from infected poultry farms to be transported, until the end of next week, to 2 designated dumping locations. The manure will be kept covered for 120 days and then released for use [as fertilizer].Next week, the remaining susceptible pet-avians should be culled in the areas previously affected by HPAI. The Gelders valley is already "empty," and in North-Brabant and Limburg the gassing of the birds is almost accomplished. The remaining private addresses of owners will soon be visited by the culling teams. According to the Dutch Association of Pet Avians Owners [Vereniging van Hobbydierhouders], quite a number of pet chickens and ducks have been hidden by their owners.Subsequent to the removal of manure and pet avians, the poultry owners in the affected areas should disinfect their premises. This is required to be carried out twice, 5 days apart. The following step, intended to verify the absence of the virus on the premises, will be carried out by the introduction of several (1 percent of the holding's normal poultry population) susceptible sentinel chickens, which will be allowed to move around the holding for 3 weeks. Should they remain healthy, then all production activities can be renewed. In view of all these measures, the ministry does not envisage the renewal of production earlier than the end of July 2003. A condition is that the EU Commission agree to waive the limiting measures, including the export ban. Until then, the entire poultry sector in the affected region is inactive.The HPAI outbreak has cost the life of almost 30 million chickens on 255 poultry holdings (including 22 pet-avians premises). The poultry owners association is of the opinion that some of these farms will never return to business.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[A set of measures to be carried out before the restrictions in the surveillance zones (minimum 10 km around confirmed outbreaks) may be lifted has been agreed upon by the Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health in its last meeting, 28 May 2003. See: Avian influenza: Further easing of restrictions,<http://europa.eu.int/rapid/start/cgi/guesten.ksh?p_action.gettxt=gt&doc=IP/03/775|0|RAPID&lg=EN&display>Animal feed, litter, and manure from infected holdings has to be removed and destroyed. The repopulation of these holdings can only take place after the introduction of sentinel birds has demonstrated the absence of any avian influenza virus.The situation and measures with regard to avian influenza will be reviewed at the next meeting of the Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health, scheduled for 13 Jun 2003. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe (03) 20030516.1219Avian influenza - Europe (04) 20030528.1305]...............arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030616.1486
Published Date16-JUN-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Europe (06)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (06)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Mon,16 Jun 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: European Union Press release IP/03/837 , 13 Jun 2003 [edited]<http://europa.eu.int/rapid/start/cgi/guesten.ksh?p_action.gettxt=gt&doc=IP/03/837|0|RAPID&lg=EN&display>Avian influenza: first easing of restrictions in the Netherlands----------------------------------------------------------------The Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health today agreed to reauthorise as of 18 Jun 2003 the export of live poultry and hatching eggs from certain parts of the Netherlands, provided no further outbreaks or suspicions are recorded. Restrictions remain in place for the 5 provinces with surveillance zones. No further decisions were taken for Belgium and Germany.The NetherlandsSince the start of the avian influenza epidemic in the Netherlands on 28 Feb 2003, no live poultry, hatching eggs and fresh, unprocessed poultry manure or litter may be exported to other member states or third countries and, with some derogations, no live poultry and hatching eggs may be transported within the Netherlands. The derogations apply to day-old chicks, pullets, and poultry for immediate slaughter. As no new outbreaks have been confirmed in the Netherlands since early May, the Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health voted today unanimously in favour of a European Commission proposal to limit these restrictions to certain provinces of the Netherlands as of 18 Jun: Flevoland, Gelderland, Limburg, Noord-Brabant, and Utrecht.Belgium and GermanyAs agreed in the Committee meeting of 28 May, the restrictions still applicable in the provinces of Antwerp and Limburg have expired on 11 Jun 2003. They now only apply in the surveillance zones (10 km zones around the outbreaks). In Germany the restrictive measures will continue to apply in the part of North Rhine-Westphalia west of the Rhine until 24 Jun 2003.  From 25 June onwards they will only apply in the surveillance zone established around the single outbreak that had been recorded in Germany.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Europe (05) 20030604.1372Avian influenza - Europe (04) 20030528.1305Avian influenza - Europe (03) 20030516.1219Avian influenza - Europe (02) 20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe      20030513.1189]..................arn/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030620.1517
Published Date20-JUN-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Paramyxovirus infection, budgerigars - UK (susp.)
PARAMYXOVIRUS INFECTION, BUDGERIGARS - UK (SUSPECTED)****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Fri, 20 Jun, 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: The Independent, 20 Jun 2003 [edited]http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/environment/story.jsp?story=417215Budgerigar fanciers in crisis after mystery virus sweeps UK-----------------------------------------------------------Budgerigar fanciers all over Britain are facing a crisis after a mysterious virus left hundreds of birds dead. Yesterday the Budgerigar Society advised its members to stop trading birds and cancel shows. The decision was made after one breeder in Middlesbrough lost his entire collection of more than 200 budgerigars, a stock he had built up over several years.One senior figure within budgerigar circles said the mounting fear among fanciers was similar to that felt by farmers afraid their animals would be struck down during the foot and mouth disease epidemic. There have been unconfirmed reports of outbreaks in Teeside, Humberside, East Anglia, West Midlands, and the West Country. "This is a problem that has never occurred before in our history," said David Whittaker, general secretary of the Budgerigar Society. "We have had to ask members to stop showing birds and to stop people moving their birds around until we can identify this virus."There was no known cure for the condition and experts did not know how it was transmitted, he said, adding: "It could be an existing virus which has mutated. Work is carrying on at the moment and as soon as we know we will post it on our website." Mr Whittaker asked people to check the website,  [see 2 further]. He appealed for fanciers to share information and not to try to hide if they believed their birds might be affected. "Only by working together, and fanciers admitting they have a problem, will the society be able to address the situation properly. Anyone making contact can be reassured that their situation will be treated with the strictest confidence."Roy Cooke, secretary of the Northern Budgerigar Society, said the disease was similar to influenza. He added: "It is scary because it is a bit like foot and mouth disease, you don't know when it is going to strike. It is something that has come out of the blue and it can mean a lifetime's work is thrown away."[byline: Michael McCarthy, environment editor]******[2]Date:From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: The Budgerigar Society website - News, 20 Jun 2003 [edited]<http://www.budgerigarsociety.com>The new budgerigar disease--------------------------Dr Baker has advised that since the membership has become more aware of the situation they are speaking to him more freely and sharing information. He is also receiving more specimens, which will greatly assist in identifying the disease and members should continue to contact the Office and or Dr Baker direct to continue this trend.He has indicated the disease is very probably caused by a paramyxovirus infection (PMV), however, he still awaits confirmation of this. There are at least 9 types of paramyxovirus and in many of these there are a large number of subtypes, all of which can infect birds. The classical type affecting budgerigars is type 5 (also known as Kinitachi virus) which caused high mortality in aviaries in Japan in the mid 1970s; there was also a small outbreak of this in the UK in 1993. Budgerigars are also susceptible to PMV type 1 which is the cause of Newcastle disease, there is a subtype of type 1 which affects pigeons; homing pigeons have to be vaccinated against this if they take part in competitions. Two fanciers have independently commented on the large number of domestic pigeons around at the time of the outbreak but this may just be coincidence, PMV2 and PMV3 have also been seen in psittacine birds including budgerigars.Dr Baker further advises that it is important to identify the type of PMV involved and this will be done. If it is type 1 of either the Newcastle disease type or the pigeon type vaccination should be available with commercially available vaccines, although these are not licensed for budgerigars this should not be a major problem. Indeed one fancier who almost certainly has the disease has very recently vaccinated his birds with the pigeon vaccine, it will be interesting to see how he gets on.There is no treatment for the other types apart from supportive therapy. There is no information on carriers with regard to PMV5 or the other strains in psittacines. In domestic poultry carriers do occur but not usually beyond 2 months after infection although prolonged carriage for over a year has been reported. The strain of PMV1 affecting pigeons does produce carriers but not for more than one month after infection.Dr Baker has also confirmed that the disease is transmitted "bird to bird" and it can be carried on shoes and clothing. Extreme care should be taken in this respect at all times. Further information will be communicated as soon as we receive it from Dr Baker and I once again thank you for your support over this stressful period.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Budgerigars, small parrots (family Psittacidae, subfamily Psittacinae) are natives of the drier parts of Australia, found in the wild in great numbers and now adopted worldwide as a very popular pet bird. Most probably, the British veterinary authorities are currently seriously engaged in investigating this outbreak. They should exclude at least two List A diseases, namely Newcastle disease and avian influenza, and rule out any possible public health risks. The identification of the involved disease agent is anticipated with interest and concern. - Mod.AS]...................mhj/arn/sh*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks inusing information posted or archived by  ProMED-mail. Archive Number20030627.1584
Published Date27-JUN-2003
SubjectPRO/AH/EDR> Paramyxovirus infection, budgerigars - UK (susp.) (02)
PARAMYXOVIRUS INFECTION, BUDGERIGARS -UK (SUSPECTED) (02)*********************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: Thu, 26 Jun 2003From: Ian Brown <i.h.brown@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>[We are very grateful to Ian Brown and Ruth Manvell for their following expedient response to our enquiry. Mods. AS/CP].To date 4 submissions from budgerigars showing this clinical condition have been received at VLA Weybridge. From 3 we have isolated an apparently non-haemagglutinating cytopathic agent on chick embryo primary cells and Vero cells, but so far we have been unable to type/identify the agent. It did not grow in embryonated eggs inoculated by the allantoic route. We are working on characterisation: electron microscopy suggests there may be a 'paramyxovirus like agent' present. It seems extremely unlikely that the causative agent is APMV-1, APMV-2, or APMV-3. Currently 9 types of avian paramyxovirus (APMV-1 to -9) have been recognised and in some of these there are a large number of subtypes. In the past APMV-1, APMV-2, APMV-3 and APMV-5 viruses have been isolated from naturally infected caged birds, including budgerigars. Whilst in the past isolation of APMV-1, APMV-2, and APMV-3 has always been relatively straight forward, APMV-5 has proved to be more difficult.--Ian Brown/Ruth ManvellAvian VirologyVLA-Weybridge<i.h.brown@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>******[2]Date: Fri, 27 Jun 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: The budgerigarsociety.com, circulated with the March 2003 issue ofThe Budgerigar, updated 13 Jun 2003 [edited]<http://www.budgerigarsociety.com/>[This is an earlier communication on the current Budgerigar syndrome, including data which may help clarifying the chronology and spread of the condition. - Mod. AS].The "new" virus disease affecting budgerigars -- by John R Baker----------------------------------------------------------------There appears to be a new virus disease of budgerigars which could possibly become widespread in the population.The disease was first seen in mid-November 2002 and, with the exception of a possible case still under investigation, all the fanciers involved purchased birds from a large supplier in the south east. Of the 6 cases known to the writer [in March 2003] 4 are in that area, and 1 possibly 2 cases may have occurred in the East Riding of Yorkshire although I have not personally been involved with these å  the information I have is that one of the owners again purchased birds from the same supplier in the south east. Obviously there may be other cases I am not aware of. So far as I know there has been no spread from these original cases to the budgerigar population as a whole, with the possible exception of a disease outbreak still under investigation. The supplier of the birds has also had an outbreak of the disease which presumably came to his premises with a bird or birds which were obtained from elsewhere.The disease is characterised by a very high death rate and in one case in a large stud birds were dying at the rate of 6 birds a day. It appears to be either stressful or immunosuppressive as the dying birds frequently have other, secondary, conditions. Tests have been carried out to try and establish the cause of the condition. Bacteriology, except in the case of secondary infection, has been unrewarding; in one case Chlamydophila was present but only as a secondary infection. Tests for polyoma virus, psittacine beak and feather disease and Pachecos disease have been negative, although further results for the last one are pending. No evidence of fungi was found. It is assumed that disease is caused by another virus but this has not been proven.If this disease becomes widespread in the budgerigar population, which is not yet the case, the effects could be serious. So steps need to be taken to limit the spread of the infection.[Elementary bio-security measures, including hygiene requirements, decontamination and isolation measures are omitted here; they can be seen at the <http://www.budgerigarsociety.com/> web-site - Mod. AS].----- It is hoped that by instigating the above control measures the disease will be kept under control and not become the potential threat to the budgerigar fancy that it could be if no controls were used.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[It seems that the budgerigars disease, which remains so far undiagnosed, has begun its unnoticed spread in the UK more than 7 months ago. This should not  surprise those familiar with the pet-animal multi-billion industry. There are abundant examples of the uncontrolled evolvement of diseases in pets, be they terrestrial, avian or marine. Fanciers and, epidemiologically more important, handlers -- tend to keep health problems to themselves, as reflected in the fact that only 4 submissions of affected birds have reached the VLA avian-virology lab so far. Though the import of budgerigars into the UK as family pets is legally regulated (see DEFRA's document "Information about importing family pet birds into the UK" <http://www.defra.gov.uk/corporate/regulat/forms/ahealth/inttrade/im98a.pdf>), it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to effectively monitor their health status and control their movements. Official or reliable data on the number of pets and their owners are lacking; anecdotal, unofficial figures from the UK mention 750 000 households with budgerigars and 260 000 with canaries.Disease outbreaks in pets come to light, in many cases, only when farm-animals or humans get involved. The diseases may spread within and between countries. Two recent examples may be mentioned, monkeypox (spread by prairie dogs) in the USA and avian influenza (involving numerous pet-avian holdings)in the Netherlands. There are many more.Additional information from practitioners and bona-fide animal-holders/fanciers or handlers, and more samples available for lab investigations, might help in limiting further spread and losses. The alertness of veterinary authorities and practitioners to similar incidents in imported or endemic budgerigars in other countries is called upon. - Mod. AS].[The 9 types (species) of avian paramyxoviruses. which belong to the sub-family _Paramyxovirinae_ , are obvious candidates for the etiologic agent of the budgerigar disease. However, the family _Paramyxoviridae_ has a second subfamily -- _Pneumovirinae_, with an additional potential candidate, the avian metapneumovirus. This virus originally designated Turkey rhinotracheitis virus but is now known also to be a pathogen of chickens, and to infect pheasants and other birds. There are 4 genotypes of avian metapneumovirus, one of which is closely related to the human metapneumovirus recently discovered in the Netherlands. It is certainly another virus that should be considered, together with the avian coronaviruses. - Mod. CP][see also:Paramyxovirus infection, budgerigars - UK (susp.) 20030620.1517].................arn/cp/mpp*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Germany (06): OIE
AVIAN INFLUENZA - GERMANY (06): OIE************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat, 28 Jun 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: OIE Disease Information Vol 16, No 26, 27 Jun 2003 [edited]<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_13.HTM#Sec2>Highly pathogenic avian influenza in Germany: Lifting of restriction measures------------------------------------------------------------------------------(follow-up report no. 3)Information received on 25 Jun 2003 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Head, Animal Health Division, Ministry of Consumer Protection, Food and Agriculture, Bonn:End of previous report period: 4 Jun 2003End of this report period: 25 Jun 2003.No further cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) have been reported in Germany since 13 May 2003.In accordance with European Commission (EC) Decision 2003/428/EC, 400 sentinel birds (laying hens), aged 5.5 weeks, were placed in the cleaned and disinfected affected holding in the district of Viersen on 30 May 2003. In the process, 160 blood samples were taken, which tested negative in a serological blood examination. The animals were subjected to clinical tests every day, with no clinical signs suggestive of the presence of HPAI being detected.Upon the expiry of a period of 21 days (on 20 Jun 2003), the birds were examined for the presence of avian influenza viruses and specific antibodies, pursuant to subparagraph 9 of the Annex to the aforementioned Decision. Two random tests were performed to meet the requirements laid down in the EC Decision. For this purpose, 60 blood samples were tested for antibodies and 60 carcasses were subjected to virological tests (polymerase chain reaction = PCR), i.e. a total of 120 animals. All tests yielded negative findings.The remaining 280 animals, which did not display any clinical signs, were culled and safely disposed of on 20 Jun 2003.Germany has therefore fulfilled all the requirements in relation to Decision 2003/428/EC and all restriction measures were lifted as of 24 Jun 2003.The Community measures in relation to avian influenza laid down in Decision 2003/358/EC, last amended by Decision 2003/386/EC, which were still applicable to the western part of North-Rhine Westphalia, have been lifted.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Germany (05): OIE 20030524.1283Avian influenza - Germany (02): OIE 20030510.1160Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed 20030513.1184Avian influenza - Germany: confirmed, OIE 20030513.1185Avian influenza - Germany: suspected 20030509.1150]..........................arn/mpp*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Europe (07)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (07)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Thu, 3 Jul 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: EU Midday Express press release, 2 Jul 2003 [edited]<http://europa.eu.int/comm/dgs/health_consumer/library/press/press297_en.pdf>Avian influenza: crisis over in the Netherlands-----------------------------------------------At the Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health on 1 Jul 2003, the 3 Member States previously affected by avian influenza gave an overview of their situation. Since there have been no new outbreaks in the Netherlands for the whole month of June, the protection measures for the Netherlands were not prolonged, as is already the case for Belgium and the Land of North-Rhine Westphalia in Germany.This means that all restrictions will be lifted in the Netherlands as of 11 Jul 2003 except in the surveillance zones around the outbreaks. Restrictions in the surveillance zones may only be lifted once "sentinel birds" have been placed in the affected holdings and demonstrated that the virus is no longer present. [For the details of this procedure see 20030628.1591. - Mod.AS]Since the start of the avian influenza epidemic in the Netherlands on 28 Feb 2003, no exports from the Netherlands were allowed for live poultry, hatching eggs, nor for fresh, unprocessed poultry manure and litter. There were also restrictions on the transport of live poultry and hatching eggs within the Netherlands, with some exceptions. Some of these restrictions were eased on 13 Jun 2003, but restrictions still remained in place for the 5 affected provinces: Flevoland, Gelderland, Limburg, Noord-Brabant, and Utrecht.The positive report by the Dutch authorities yesterday shows that the crisis is now over and trade activities can resume as normal throughout the country, except in the surveillance zones, as of 11 Jul 2003.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands      20030425.1012Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (02) 20030429.1061Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (03) 20030501.1093Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands (04) 20030503.1110Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccinatio... 20030501.1087,20030502.1099Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination      20030428.1047Avian influenza - Europe (05) 20030604.1372Avian influenza - Europe (06) 20030616.1486Avian influenza - Germany (06): OIE 20030628.1591Avian influenza - Netherlands (24): pig involvement 20030520.1240Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case 20030420.0967Avian influenza, human - Netherlands (13) 20030501.1092].....................arn/pg/lm*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Archive Number20030715.1739
Published Date15-JUL-2003
SubjectPRO/AH> Avian influenza - Europe (08)
AVIAN INFLUENZA - EUROPE (08)*****************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Tue, 15 Jul 2003From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: EU Midday Experss, 11 Jul 2003 [edited]<http://europa.eu.int/comm/dgs/health_consumer/library/press/press302_en.pdf>Avian influenza: crisis over----------------------------Today all restrictions imposed after outbreaks of avian influenza in the Netherlands will expire except in the surveillance zones around the outbreaks. Starting from tomorrow, exports of live poultry, hatching eggs and fresh, unprocessed poultry manure and litter can restart from the whole country. Repopulation of the affected holdings is now taking place after "sentinel birds" demonstrate that the virus is not longer present in the holding. Restrictions in Belgium and the Land of North-Rhine Westphalia in Germany were lifted in June. The avian influenza crisis, that started at the end of February with outbreaks in the Netherlands, can now be considered as over.-- ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This major outbreak, which reportedly began 28 Feb 2003, severely affected the Netherlands with a limited spread to Belgium and Germany. About 30 million birds had to be killed. The causative agent was a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H7N7 influenza A virus. ProMED-mail dedicated more than 60 postings to the issue.The following issues which characterized this epizootic, might be illustrative during future national and international deliberations regarding the need for changes in the structure of the farming industry and policies for the control animal disease. Others may be added.- difficulties in containing the epizootic within a very densely maintained, multi-species poultry population, where the free-roaming birds in commercial farms may readily contact infected, wild water-birds;- zoonotic aspects (almost 100 human infections, including one fatal case);- the possible incidental spread of the virus by human contacts;- a close field/laboratory collaboration with a continuous follow up in animals (avian and mammal) and humans by the 2 reference laboratories;- the role played by pet birds in the evolution of the epizootic;- debates about the feasibility and need for emergency and preventive vaccinations in view of ethical considerations, public opinion and their implications upon international trade;- debates about the killing of pet birds as a precautionary measure;- the strong involvement of the political establishment, especially related to the above two controversial issues and underlined by the zoonotic aspects of the outbreak. - Mod.AS].[see also:Avian influenza - Europe (07)                            20030703.1642Avian influenza - Germany (06): OIE                      20030628.1591Avian influenza - Europe (05)                            20030604.1372Avian influenza - Netherlands (24): pig involvement      20030520.1240Avian influenza - Europe (02)                            20030515.1213Avian influenza - Europe                                 20030513.1189Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination (03) 20030502.1099Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccinatio...    20030501.1087Avian influenza - Belgium, Netherlands: vaccination      20030428.1047Avian influenza - Belgium (09): OIE                      20030428.1040Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (10): fatal case    20030420.0967Avian Influenza, human - Netherlands (08)                20030327.0762Avian influenza -
